title: Susan Collins Will Vote to Acquit Trump in Senate Impeachment Trial; Maine lawmaker joins a few other GOP senators who are critical of president's effort in Ukraine, but who say it doesn't justify his ouster
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—Sen. Susan Collins said President Trump's efforts
to press Ukraine to open an investigation
into a Democratic presidential candidate were "improper and demonstrated poor judgment" but didn't warrant forcing him from office, joining a handful of Republican lawmakers who have criticized his actions while arguing they aren't impeachable.
"I do not believe that the House has met its burden of showing that the president's conduct, however flawed, warrants the extreme step of immediate removal from office," said the Maine senator, who faces a tough re-election battle, in a speech Tuesday on the Senate floor.
The GOP-controlled Senate is expected to acquit Mr. Trump in a final vote Wednesday afternoon on two articles of impeachment alleging abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. Conviction would require a two-thirds majority, or 67 senators, and Senate Republicans have remained united in rejecting Democrats' impeachment push.
But Ms. Collins and a number of other GOP senators have criticized Mr. Trump's conduct in strong terms on the Senate floor, in op-eds and in remarks to reporters in recent days. Their disapproval is focused on a July 25 phone call in which Mr. Trump asked Ukranian President Volodymyr Zelensky for an investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden, who is currently seeking the Democratic presidential nomination, and his son Hunter. Mr. Trump has defended the call as "perfect" and has said he did nothing wrong regarding Ukraine, dismissing the impeachment process as a partisan hoax.
"The president's actions were not 'perfect.' Some were inappropriate," said Sen. Pat Toomey (R., Pa.) in
an opinion article published in the Philadelphia Inquirer
on Tuesday. He said the actions didn't rise to an impeachable offense.
Sen. Rob Portman (R., Ohio) condemned Mr. Trump's July call as "inappropriate and wrong" in a speech on the Senate floor on Tuesday. "While I don't condone this behavior, these actions do not rise to removing the president from office and taking him off the ballot in a presidential election year that is already well under way," he said.
More on the Trump Impeachment Trial
*
Trump, Democrats Press Their Case as Impeachment Trial Nears Its End

*
Senate Rejects Witnesses in Trump Impeachment Trial

*
How Republicans Scotched the Idea of Witnesses in Impeachment Trial

"The president's behavior was shameful and wrong," said Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R., Alaska) in her own speech on Monday night. "His personal interests do not take precedence over those of this great nation."
In her speech on Tuesday, Ms. Collins said: "It was wrong for President Trump to mention former Vice President Joe Biden on that phone call, and it was wrong for him to ask a foreign country to investigate a political rival."
Mr. Trump and his GOP allies have alleged that it was corrupt for Mr. Biden during the Obama administration to seek the ouster of a Ukrainian prosecutor who had once investigated a Ukrainian gas company where Hunter Biden sat on the board. Mr. Biden sought the prosecutor's removal as part of a broad international effort to combat corruption in Ukraine.
The Bidens have denied any wrongdoing.
Hunter Biden has said it was poor judgment
on his part to serve on the Burisma board while his father was involved with Ukraine policy as vice president.
In her speech on Tuesday, Ms. Collins also reminded listeners that she had voted to acquit former President Clinton, a Democrat, in his impeachment trial in 1999.
"This decision is not about whether you like or dislike this president, or agree with or oppose his policies," she said. "Rather it is about whether the charges meet the very high constitutional standard of treason, bribery or other high crimes or misdemeanors." She said Mr. Trump's actions didn't meet that threshold.
After her speech, Ms. Collins told reporters she might have been open to censuring Mr. Trump,
a proposal floated by Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin
of West Virginia. Republican Senate leaders have dismissed this idea.
"It's something that I would have looked at. At this point, the fact is the president has been impeached—only the third president to be actually impeached," Ms. Collins said. "That both Republican senators such as myself and Democratic senators have criticized his conduct strikes me as a reprimand."
Republican Sen. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, who also has said Mr. Trump's conduct was inappropriate, told reporters on Tuesday that he hopes the refusal of GOP senators to convict and remove Mr. Trump will discourage future Houses from sending impeachment articles to the Senate that don't have bipartisan support.
Write to Natalie Andrews at
Natalie.Andrews@wsj.com
and Lindsay Wise at
lindsay.wise@wsj.com

title: Paris Mayoral Candidates Ditch the Usual Kiss on the Cheek as Coronavirus Spreads; The race to see who governs France's capital mirrors how politicians across the world now have to figure out new ways to drum up votes on the campaign trail
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
PARIS—Mayor Anne Hidalgo was on the stump in an outdoor market, seeking a second term, but there was no pressing the flesh with the public—and certainly no cheek-to-cheek kisses.
"I say to Parisians, I would love to kiss them and take them in my arms, but I cannot do it because I need to lead by example," the 60-year old mayor said on a recent morning.
French politicians have long prided themselves on their willingness to get up close and personal with voters, greeting supporters with a peck on the cheek or wading into crowds. In recent weeks, however, Ms. Hidalgo and her rivals have begun to keep their distance, in some cases canceling campaign events.
Politicians from many countries are learning to make similar adjustments—including candidates campaigning in the
U.S. presidential primary elections
. Democratic presidential candidates Sen. Bernie Sanders and former Vice President Joe Biden canceled rallies in Cleveland, ahead of Ohio's primary next week, citing concerns about the coronavirus. The British government Friday said local elections in England, including the ballot to select London's mayor, will be postponed for a year.
Voters across France are preparing to hit the polls in two rounds of local elections on March 15 and 22 just as France is coping with a sharp increase in the number of infections.
So far , authorities have identified 3,661 cases across the country, and 79 patients infected with the virus have died. While voting is going ahead as planned—French President Emmanuel Macron decided to proceed after consulting with a team of scientists on Thursday—authorities are urging candidates to forego shaking hands and give up the bise, as the greeting by kiss is called.
Ms. Hidalgo has a lot riding on this election. She's among the last members of the Socialist Party to hold a major office after the party was stung by a string of defeats in the 2017 presidential and National Assembly elections.
But so does Mr. Macron. His centrist party, Republic on the Move, gambled in its decision to tap French Health Minister Agnès Buzyn to run for mayor of Paris on Feb. 16 after Mr. Macron's initial choice
abruptly quit the race
following allegations he had sent a woman sexually explicit messages, just as the coronavirus was beginning to course through France.
"It breaks my heart to leave, but I will be up to the task," said Ms. Buzyn, a trained physician, when she accepted the candidacy.
But the sudden substitution put an immediate target on her back.
"Why didn't you stay at the health ministry?" Ms. Hidalgo asked Ms. Buzyn during a recent televised debate, adding that "it seems like a shame to leave at this point."
"Maybe it was a presidential instruction?" said Cédric Villani, a celebrated mathematician and lawmaker from Mr. Macron's party who has defied the president by refusing to drop out of the mayoral race.
"Because I want to be mayor, that's why I left the health ministry," Ms. Buzyn responded.
Mr. Macron and his party, Republic on the Move, triumphed in the 2017 elections, but establishing local roots through contests such as the Paris mayoral election is essential to its long-term survival. Municipalities and other local governments provide a power base for political parties. Government ministers are allowed to run for local posts such as mayor, providing them with a political fallback if they lose national office. Local officials also elect lawmakers in the Senate, where Republic on the Move is in the minority.
Polls show Ms. Hidalgo in the lead with 26% of the vote while Ms. Buzyn 19% and Mr. Villani has 7%.
The coronavirus epidemic makes for a challenging campaign, with difficult decisions to make. On Tuesday, center-right candidate Rachida Dati, who is polling at 23%, decided to go ahead with her own rally. She made a point of counting supporters who lined up at the entrance, limiting the crowd inside to 900 people—just under the 1,000 allowed under public health restrictions at the time. The limit was lowered to 100 people Friday.
Meanwhile, Ms. Buzyn remains focused on meeting Parisians, and tries to make the best of a bad situation. Instead of kissing or shaking their hands, she bumps elbows with Parisians in cafes and markets.
When offered a hand or a cheek, Ms. Buzyn explains it is ill-advised, adding: "Parisians will change their ways."
Get an early-morning coronavirus briefing each weekday, plus a health-news update Fridays.
Sign up
.
Write to Noemie Bisserbe at
noemie.bisserbe@wsj.com

title: Moderate Democrats Stress Over Crowded Center Lane; There is no single centrist rival to front-runner Bernie Sanders, and party leaders are bracing for a protracted nomination fight
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit





From left: Michael Bloomberg, Sen. Amy Klobuchar, Pete Buttigieg and Joe Biden. PHOTO: Photo Illustration: WSJ; Photos: Gabriela Bhaskar for The Wall Street Journal, Associated Press (3)
NASHUA, N.H.—Democrats in search of a centrist nominee to challenge President Trump are increasingly worried after contests in
Iowa
and
New Hampshire
consolidated liberal support behind Bernie Sanders and divided the larger moderate vote among multiple candidates.
The party's center lane is crowded with the rising former South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg, Sen. Amy Klobuchar and former Vice President Joe Biden. Looming in the
March 3 Super Tuesday states
and beyond is former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg, buoyed by
campaign spending that dwarfs all his opponents combined
.
With no clear centrist front-runner, vulnerable freshman Democrats in Congress are texting each other anxiously, a Biden-allied fundraiser warns of a "doomsday scenario" and party strategists fret about what mixed early-state turnout means for November.
Predictions about which candidates are the most electable and which will prevail through a long primary season have proven unreliable in the past, particularly at this early stage of the process, before voting in the diverse states of South Carolina and Nevada. Barack Obama faced intraparty doubts in 2008, as did Mr. Trump in 2016.
With multiple contenders vowing to stay in the race, party leaders are yet again bracing for the likelihood of a protracted fight for the nomination that may not be settled by the time of the July convention in Milwaukee.
Adding to some Democrats' worries is the president's
acquittal from impeachment
and his strength among his most fervent supporters, as evidenced by the more than 11,000 who turned out for his
Monday night rally in Manchester, N.H.
, a larger crowd than any assembled by a Democrat campaigning in the state.
"There is one thing that's universal, and that is anxiety," said Rufus Gifford, who served as finance director for President Obama's re-election campaign and has contributed to several campaigns. 





Pete Buttigieg spoke at a rally in Nashua, N.H., on Sunday. PHOTO: Gabriela Bhaskar for The Wall Street Journal
The fear among some Democrats is predicated on the idea that Mr. Sanders, the Vermont senator and self-described democratic socialist, would struggle to defeat Mr. Trump in November. Mr. Sanders and his supporters believe the party could unite around him if he is the nominee and that he could energize young voters and those in crucial Rust Belt states who swung to the GOP in 2016.
The Sanders campaign disputed the notion he would hurt Democrats in swing districts, noting that candidates in states that will be crucial in 2020 had requested his help during 2018 midterms.
Mr. Sanders and Mr. Buttigieg, a 38-year-old newcomer to the national scene, essentially tied in Iowa and finished one-two in New Hampshire. Ms. Warren has faded in the first two contests but is pressing forward, while Ms. Klobuchar, the No. 3 finisher in Iowa, is eyeing delegates when her home state of Minnesota votes on March 3.
If Mr. Biden has a strong showing in South Carolina and Nevada, he could regain lost momentum and potentially persuade wavering Democrats to stick with him through subsequent states.
Mr. Bloomberg meanwhile has poured more than $350 million of his fortune into a series of March states, including California, Texas and North Carolina.
Philip Levine, a former mayor of Miami Beach, Fla., who supports Mr. Bloomberg, said in an interview he received "an avalanche" of phone calls and emails Wednesday from donors asking how they could help, and from elected officials, whom he didn't name, asking his advice on "how to tactfully retract" their endorsements of Mr. Biden and shift their support to Mr. Bloomberg.
Some Democratic donors say privately there will be a lot of pressure for Mr. Biden to get out after South Carolina if he performs poorly there.
"We are going to compete in Super Tuesday states," said Rep. Cedric Richmond of Louisiana, a Biden campaign co-chairman. "Bloomberg is spending an awful lot of money, but he's also not had his turn in the barrel. He has not been on the debate stage. He's untested."
Larry Rasky, who leads a pro-Biden super PAC called Unite the Country, sought to rally Biden donors in a fundraising memo Sunday by telling them that if they hedge their bets on Mr. Biden because of Mr. Bloomberg, they could be creating a "doomsday scenario."
"The Sanders-Warren wing of the Party is ready for the Bloomberg fight. Democrats cannot afford a split Convention. Do you really think the Sanders voters wing will support Mike Bloomberg? Do you think all the camps who have busted their butts and played by the rules will happily sign on" to Mr. Bloomberg's campaign, he wrote.
The party's attempt to present itself as a steady, competent alternative to Mr. Trump has been
marred by the chaotic Iowa caucuses
, where more than a week later Mr. Sanders narrowly trails Mr. Buttigieg in state delegates, but Mr. Sanders leads in the popular vote. Both candidates have requested a recanvassing of certain precincts.
Party strategists are watching early-state turnout closely for clues about whether Democrats are energized to vote. 





Sen. Bernie Sanders drew crowds at a rally at the University of New Hampshire on Monday. PHOTO: Gabriela Bhaskar for The Wall Street Journal
More than 176,000 people participated in the Iowa Democratic caucuses this year, a slight increase from four years ago but well behind the nearly 240,000 who caucused in 2008. New Hampshire was a brighter spot for Democrats: Turnout reached about 297,000 voters in the Democratic primary, compared with about 255,000 in 2016 and nearly 290,000 in 2008.
"Everything is splintered," said Chris Kofinis, a Democratic strategist and former adviser to West Virginia Sen. Joe Manchin. "And it just shows that voters aren't falling in love with any of these candidates, and that's a problem."
Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster who has conducted focus groups in early-voting states and general-election battlegrounds, said she has been struck by "the duality of who you like and who you think can beat Trump. And they're not necessarily the same thing." 





Joe Biden, seen speaking in Iowa earlier this month, has faltered in the first two primary contests. PHOTO: Christopher Lee for The Wall Street Journal
In a sign of Democrats' interest in finding an alternative to Mr. Biden, some moderate House Democrats have embraced Mr. Bloomberg, including Reps. Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey, Haley Stevens of Michigan and Scott Peters of California. On Wednesday, two African-American members of Congress, Reps. Lucy McBath (D., Ga.) and Gregory Meeks (D., N.Y.) said they were backing Mr. Bloomberg. All are members of the centrist New Democrat Coalition.
Rep. Stephanie Murphy, the chairwoman of the centrist Blue Dog Coalition caucus, said Mr. Sanders wouldn't be able to win over swing voters, and if he becomes the party's nominee, he could put the new House majority at risk. "For many moderate districts and Trump-won districts, Bernie Sanders at the top of the ticket would create headwinds for house members running for re-election," she said.
Related
*
Candidates Set for Long Haul Following Sanders's New Hampshire Win

*
New Hampshire Primary: Top Takeaways

*
Buttigieg Faces Tough Path in Next Democratic Contests

*
How Iowa and New Hampshire Have Reshaped Democratic Race

*
Iowa Democratic Party Chairman to Resign Position After Caucus Debacle

Former Goldman Sachs Chief Executive Lloyd Blankfein, who supported Hillary Clinton in 2016, said in a tweet Tuesday that "Sanders is just as polarizing as Trump AND he'll ruin our economy." Mr. Sanders's campaign manager tweeted back: "This is what panic from the Wall Street elite looks and sounds like."
For most of the campaign, Mr. Biden has presented himself as the candidate best able to win states narrowly carried by Mr. Trump, including his boyhood state of Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin.
"He did not have a shot to win Iowa or do well in Iowa," said Rep. Tim Ryan (D., Ohio), who endorsed Mr. Biden after his own candidacy failed. "His two strongest groups are communities of color and older voters, and both are pretty much excluded from the caucus process."
Mr. Biden and his wife, Dr. Jill Biden, joined a conference call with the campaign's top financial donors on Wednesday afternoon, according to three participants, and noted the campaign's strength in Nevada and South Carolina among Latinos and African-Americans.
Polls indicate that Mr. Buttigieg and Ms. Klobuchar both have struggled to appeal to African-American voters. Mr. Bloomberg apologized for a second time Tuesday amid a fresh round of criticism for his support of stop-and-frisk policing in New York City.
Mr. Sanders has argued that Democrats must nominate someone who can generate enthusiasm and mobilize young people and infrequent voters who were turned off by their choices in the 2016 election. The senator has arguably the best ability to command large crowds, evidenced by more than 7,500 people who showed up for a primary eve rally and concert at the University of New Hampshire.
In the last week, Mr. Sanders has taken the lead in the RealClearPolitics average of national Democratic primary polls, after Mr. Biden had led for months.
While Mr. Biden's candidacy has foundered, Mr. Bloomberg has courted members of Congress. In January, Mr. Bloomberg flew to Salt Lake City where Rep. Ben McAdams (D., Utah) hosted the former mayor at his home with local Democrats and Republicans. Mr. Bloomberg talked about his hope for a pragmatic government and answered questions on climate change and fiscal responsibility.
Mr. McAdams said he was looking for someone he could support, but also said he was looking for someone who understood a congressional district like his own, which the president carried by 7 percentage points in 2016.
About a week later, he endorsed Mr. Bloomberg.
Tarini Parti contributed to this article.
Share Your Thoughts
Which moderate in the Democratic primary race do you think could hold their own in a general election against President Trump? Why? Join the conversation below.
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com
and Natalie Andrews at
Natalie.Andrews@wsj.com

title: Trump Acquitted --- Senate decides against removing the president from office. Romney is the only Republican to join Democrats in voting guilty. President plans to address the impeachment verdict on Thursday.
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON -- The Republican-led Senate acquitted President Trump of charges stemming from his efforts to press Ukraine to announce investigations that would benefit him politically, bringing to a close a bruising four-month battle fought almost entirely along party lines.
The third presidential impeachment in U.S. history intensified the nation's sharp divide over Mr. Trump and previewed many of the arguments likely to be heard ahead of the election this fall. During the trial, Democrats said the Republican president was trying to cheat in the coming election by trying to damage a potential opponent. Republicans said that Democrats were improperly inflating missteps into impeachable offenses and trying to overturn the results of the 2016 election.
The Senate vote to acquit marked a clear victory for the president, underscoring his primacy in the GOP and the end to a process that had hung over the past several months of his presidency. But while Mr. Trump had hoped for a forceful display of unity from Republicans in defense of his actions, he got something less: GOP senators strongly supported his acquittal, but several said the Democrats had proved that he acted improperly -- though not in a manner deserving of impeachment -- regarding Ukraine.
Mr. Trump was also denied a unanimous not-guilty verdict from Republican senators when Mitt Romney of Utah voted to convict on the first article of impeachment.
Given the GOP's 53-47 majority in the Senate and the Constitution's requirement that two-thirds of the Senate is required to convict, Mr. Trump's chance of acquittal was always strong. Mr. Trump now becomes the first president to run for re-election after having been impeached.
Mr. Trump and his campaign sought throughout the process to turn impeachment to his political advantage, frequently using his attacks on the investigation in fundraising emails.
On the first article of impeachment, abuse of power, all 47 Democratic-aligned senators and Mr. Romney voted to convict, falling short of the 67 needed to remove the president from office. On the obstruction of Congress article, the vote also failed, with all Democrats and no Republicans finding the president guilty.
The senators read their votes aloud from their desks, and Chief Justice John Roberts announced the outcome. "Donald John Trump, president of the United States. . .is hereby acquitted," he said.
Mr. Trump, in a tweet after the vote, declared "our Country's VICTORY on the Impeachment Hoax" and wrote that he would make a public statement about his acquittal on Thursday.
Republicans' arguments in favor of acquittal split broadly into two camps. Some argued that House impeachment managers' case was half-baked and that they should have gone to court to pursue the testimony of further witnesses who had been told by the White House not to cooperate. Others in the party said House Democrats had proved their case but that the president's conduct wasn't impeachable.
The impeachment probe grew out of a phone call last summer in which Mr. Trump asked President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine to announce an investigation into Joe Biden, a top Democratic presidential contender, while holding up congressionally approved aid to the country. Mr. Trump has defended the call as "perfect" and has said he did nothing wrong regarding Ukraine. The aid was later released after bipartisan outcry from lawmakers.
The most dramatic moment of the day came two hours before the acquittal vote, when Mr. Romney said in a floor speech that he had decided to vote to convict the president on the first article. "The president is guilty of an appalling abuse of public trust," he said.
Mr. Romney was the first senator in U.S. history to vote to convict a president of his own party. In the impeachment trials of Democratic presidents Andrew Johnson and Bill Clinton, no Democratic senators voted to convict.
The White House, which as late as Wednesday morning had been predicting that all Republican senators would vote to acquit the president, was caught off-guard by Mr. Romney's announcement, aides said.
Immediately after Mr. Romney announced his vote, White House aides began planning to intensify attacks on the senator. Later that evening, Mr. Trump tweeted a video accusing Mr. Romney, the 2012 GOP presidential nominee, of "posing as a Republican" and trying to "infiltrate" the Trump administration.
Democrats said the acquittal amounted to a defeat for the institution of Congress and they warned that leaving Mr. Trump in office would make him free to abuse power again.
"The verdict of this kangaroo court will be meaningless," said Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, on Wednesday. "You cannot be on the side of this president and be on the side of truth."
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) said Democrats used impeachment for political goals. "We should all agree that this is the precisely the type of recklessness that the Senate was created to stop," he said on the floor. "The response to losing one election cannot be to attack the office of the presidency."
In a news conference later in the day, Mr. McConnell declined to answer questions about whether he found the president's conduct appropriate.
In the months after House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) opened the inquiry in September, the Democratic-led House called 17 witnesses and compiled hundreds of documents to build its case, formally impeaching the president in December. A month later, it handed the articles over to the Senate, which heard arguments from House impeachment managers and Mr. Trump's defense team but rejected calling witnesses it said the House should have pursued.
The tightly choreographed Senate trial was upended late last month by new revelations from former national security adviser John Bolton about the president's pressure campaign on Ukraine. The former official's revelations in a yet-unpublished memoir briefly raised the possibility a sufficient number of Republicans would join with Democrats to vote in favor of new witness testimony. But Republicans ultimately voted nearly in unison to oppose hearing from Mr. Bolton and other witnesses.
"Unless there's some bipartisan consensus of treason, bribery or other high crimes and misdemeanors, as there was in the Nixon case, then there shouldn't be an impeachment," Sen. Lamar Alexander (R., Tenn.) said on Tuesday.
While a majority of voters in a recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll said they believed Mr. Trump abused his power and obstructed Congress, some 49% of respondents said he should be allowed to finish his term, compared with 46% who said he should be removed.
Impeachment also made little impact on Mr. Trump's job-approval rating, which stood at 46% in the January poll -- in line with his rating throughout his presidency.
Democrats made clear the trial settled nothing for them, with members of House leadership saying they would likely keep investigating. Rep. Jerrold Nadler (D., N.Y.) said Wednesday the House would likely subpoena Mr. Bolton and continue the investigation. Mr. Bolton's spokeswoman declined to comment on whether he would comply with any subpoena.
Despite his public attacks on the impeachment process, Mr. Trump stayed -- at Mr. McConnell's urging -- largely on the sidelines of Republican efforts to rally lawmakers against voting for new witnesses and approached his own legal team with a fairly light touch.
The president's sole recommendation to his team came after the defense's first day of arguments, an administration official said. After his lawyers argued for two hours, he called with a request: Put Pam Bondi on TV more. He told the team he wanted Ms. Bondi, a former Florida attorney general who joined the White House last fall as an adviser on impeachment, to continue arguing his case on TV in the evenings.
Instead, Mr. Trump focused his attention elsewhere. As the trial unfolded last week, White House officials huddled with GOP House members and their aides in a small room in the vice president's office in the Capitol that one GOP aide described as "mission control." The president, the aide said, insisted advisers not call it a "war room," which he said wrongly suggested Republicans were embattled and that impeachment was an actual crisis.
---
Michael C. Bender contributed to this article.

title: Mike Bloomberg's Campaign Giving $18 Million to Democratic National Committee; Billionaire's advisers had been working on a way to absorb his presidential campaign operations into an outside entity, but decided to change course
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Michael Bloomberg said he would transfer $18 million from his presidential campaign to the Democratic National Committee, boosting the party's operations instead of forming his own super PAC.
The investment is aimed at strengthening the DNC's battleground program, which includes 12 states and is run in coordination with the state party committees. Mr. Bloomberg has also offered to transfer the ownership of many of his field offices to state party committees, according to a Democratic official, who said that the former New York City mayor's contributions would help speed up their hiring for positions in organizing, data and operations.
The multimillion-dollar boost to the party's field organizing program could serve as a
major asset to the Democratic nominee
. Former Vice President Joe Biden is leading the delegate count and has struggled to amass a large campaign war chest. Sen. Bernie Sanders is still in the race, but Mr. Biden's campaign is preparing to build out a larger staff for the general election while grappling with the new realities of campaigning during the coronavirus pandemic.
President Trump's team has built a large campaign organization and
is planning an extensive operation of field organizers
and digital outreach to voters. Mr. Trump and the Republican National Committee had more than $225 million in the bank at the end of February.
After launching his long-shot White House bid in late November, Mr. Bloomberg committed to keeping his staff on the payroll and field offices open in at least six competitive general-election states, even if he wasn't the party's nominee.
The billionaire
dropped out
after giving his own campaign more than $935 million, an unprecedented amount in just 100 days, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission on Friday that show his spending through the end of February. He earned only 61 delegates on Super Tuesday, meaning he spent at least $15.3 million per delegate.
Since he exited the race, Mr. Bloomberg's advisers had been working on a way to absorb his campaign operations into an outside entity that would boost Mr. Biden. He said in the statement Friday they had ultimately decided to change course.
"While we considered creating our own independent entity to support the nominee and hold the President accountable, this race is too important to have many competing groups with good intentions but that are not coordinated and united in strategy and execution," Mr. Bloomberg wrote in a memo to DNC Chairman Tom Perez that was made public Friday.
"The dynamics of the race have also fundamentally changed, and it is critically important that we all do everything we can to support our eventual nominee and scale the Democratic Party's general-election efforts," Mr. Bloomberg said.
The shift in thinking was fueled by a few factors, according to a campaign aide. Mr. Bloomberg and his advisers had been expecting a more prolonged primary contest and believed a new outside group could keep the focus on anti-Trump efforts while the remaining candidates battled for the nomination, the aide said.
But with Mr. Biden appearing on track to secure the nomination, they started at looking at ways of funding more coordinated efforts to support his campaign and discovered the presidential campaign could make an unlimited contribution to the DNC.
While individuals have limits on how much they can give to party committees, presidential campaign committees can transfer unlimited amounts—even if they are solely funded, as in Mr. Bloomberg's case, by one person.
In a roughly six-minute phone call with staffers, Dan Kanninen, states director for the campaign, said Mr. Bloomberg's team had considered what his general-election operation might look like, but was more focused on competing on Super Tuesday, according to a person on the call. Mr. Kanninen said
Mr. Biden's performance that day
changed their calculation.
"An independent effort would simply not be as effective or as efficient in our goal of beating President Trump in November," Mr. Kanninen said, according to a person on the call. "I want to be clear: It was impossible for us to predict the events of last month politically."
The aide said that
the coronavirus outbreak
also played a role in changing their plans. Although some of the field work conducted by Mr. Bloomberg's staffers in battleground states can still be done through digital platforms and phone banking, campaigns will be unable to carry out one of their biggest organizing activities—knocking on doors—for an unknown period of time.
"The Democratic Party stands united and fully committed to defeating the most dangerous president in modern history, and we welcome the announcement of Mayor Bloomberg's extraordinary investment to ensure that happens," Kate Bedingfield, a spokeswoman for Mr. Biden's campaign, said in a statement.
Hawkfish LLC, Mr. Bloomberg's digital startup, will continue its operations.
Mr. Bloomberg's campaign told staff in the six battleground states where he had committed to continuing operations that they would be paid through the first week in April and have full benefits through the end of April. They will now have to reapply for positions through the DNC's program, according to the Democratic official.
Mr. Bloomberg's campaign staffers—many of whom believed, based on the candidate's public comments and private conversations with the campaign, that they were guaranteed jobs through November—were informed in a call Friday morning about the billionaire's decision not to form a new super PAC and keep them on payroll. Many were surprised by the news and concerned about finding new jobs in a market roiled by the coronavirus pandemic.
"There has been no sensitivity," said one of the staffers on the call. "It's been all about beating Trump and not about the people who worked" for Mr. Bloomberg.
The Bloomberg campaign aide said they have provided names of their staff to the DNC with the hope that they will use the new funding to hire them.
The former New York City mayor's contribution to the DNC will be the largest transfer from a presidential campaign in recent history. Following the 2016 election, Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign made a transfer of $3.8 million in cash and in-kind contributions, the DNC said.
"With this transfer from the Bloomberg campaign, Mayor Bloomberg and his team are making good on their commitment to beating Donald Trump," Mr. Perez said in a statement. "This will help us invest in more organizers across the country to elect the next president and help Democrats win up and down the ballot."
Write to Tarini Parti at
Tarini.Parti@wsj.com
and Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com

title: How South Carolina Saved Joe Biden; The former vice president got the lifeline he needed from a familiar state and its African-American voters. Now he's hoping for a Super Tuesday boost.
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
COLUMBIA, S.C.—In good times and bad, Joe Biden has taken refuge in South Carolina, often joking that when he dies, he hopes to be reborn in Charleston.
So when his struggling presidential campaign needed a lift, he turned to the state for a lifeline Saturday, notching a burst of momentum and a chance to become the alternative to Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders in the race for the Democratic nomination.
"I told you all that you could launch a candidacy. You launched Bill Clinton, Barack Obama to the presidency. Now you've launched our campaign on the path to defeating Donald Trump. This campaign is taking off," Mr. Biden said, pumping his fists.

Mr. Biden's blowout victory over Mr. Sanders
in South Carolina's primary, his first-ever win during three presidential campaigns, could offer the former vice president a springboard into several Southern states holding contests on Super Tuesday's 14-state bonanza of delegates.
Mr. Biden, who served alongside President Obama for eight years, has repeatedly pointed to his support among African-Americans as he seeks the nomination. Exit polls in South Carolina, where African-Americans made up more than half of the primary electorate, showed him receiving well over half of black voters, far ahead of Mr. Sanders.
With only three days until Super Tuesday, Mr. Biden is now banking on black voters—and momentum from South Carolina—to propel him forward in states such as North Carolina, where he held a rally earlier Saturday, and Virginia, where he will campaign Sunday with Sen. Tim Kaine, Hillary Clinton's running mate in 2016. Former Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe, who considered a presidential bid, announced his endorsement of Mr. Biden as the South Carolina results trickled in and plans to join Mr. Biden and Mr. Kaine on Sunday.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
What do you see as Joe Biden's next steps after South Carolina? Join the conversation below.
Mr. Biden also plans to travel to Alabama, Texas and California in the coming days, seeking to consolidate support among moderate Democrats who fear a Sanders nomination will hurt the party up-and-down the ballot against President Trump.
Yet after spending much of last year as the leading contender in national polls, Mr. Biden faces a daunting challenge against Mr. Sanders and former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, the billionaire who has blanketed Super Tuesday states with more than $160 million in advertising.
Mr. Biden's poor performances
in Iowa
and New Hampshire forced him to campaign extensively in Nevada, where he placed second, and in South Carolina.
The footprint of his campaign's organization in Tuesday's contests is much smaller than that of Mr. Sanders, who aims to build a large delegate lead with victories in California and several states on Tuesday.
Mr. Bloomberg, meanwhile, has assiduously courted black voters in states such as North Carolina, Arkansas, Tennessee and Alabama, putting pressure on Mr. Biden. In a sign of his sway, Mr. Bloomberg's campaign was holding more than 2,400 events in 30 states during the weekend to boost voter turnout.
Mr. Biden has also struggled to keep pace with his rivals in fundraising, ending January with about $7 million in the bank, limiting his ability to advertise extensively.
His campaign is devoting about $2.2 million in ads across eight states ahead of Tuesday's vote, a fraction of Mr. Bloomberg's spending. Ahead of Mr. Biden's victory, Unite the Country, a pro-Biden super PAC, placed a $1.2 million ad buy in six Super Tuesday states, according to Federal Election Commission filings.
Mr. Biden told reporters Saturday outside a polling location in Greenville, S.C., that he had been raising about $1 million a day "for the last week or so," and hoped South Carolina's outcome would improve his standing.
"The bigger the win, the bigger the bump," he said.
During the final week before South Carolina's primary, Mr. Biden frequently cited Mr. Sanders's support for a Medicare-for-all health care system, which he said would undermine the Obamacare law.
The tougher critique of Mr. Sanders—along with criticism of Mr. Bloomberg—is likely to serve as a template for Mr. Biden's push into the March contests.
"Look, this nation isn't looking for a revolution," Mr. Biden said Friday in Sumter, S.C. "They're looking for progress. They're looking for results."
During his final days in the state, Mr. Sanders lengthened his criticism of Mr. Biden's record as senator, saying he didn't think the former vice president could beat Mr. Trump when voters learned more about his past.
"Joe Biden is a good friend of mine. I've known Joe for many years, he's a decent guy, but I don't believe that Joe can beat Trump when people learn that he voted for the war in Iraq," Mr. Sanders said in Spartanburg on Thursday.
Mr. Biden has long engaged in a personal brand of politics, and his carefully cultivated relationships in South Carolina served as an asset before the primary.
His supporters said those connections mattered in a state that has often displayed a contrarian streak in presidential politics.
"It wasn't done in three or four days. It was done over 30 years," said Fran Person, a former personal aide to Mr. Biden who lives in South Carolina.
During more than four decades in public office, he made repeated trips to South Carolina, building relationships with black churches and faith-based communities, which play an outsize role in state politics. He worked closely with state officials on local projects such as the dredging of Charleston's port.
When his 46-year-old son, Beau Biden, died of brain cancer in 2015, Mr. Biden's extended family mourned together on Kiawah Island, where the Bidens frequently vacation.
Residents here recalled that Mr. Biden interrupted that trip to privately meet with parishioners of Mother Emanuel A.M.E. church in Charleston after the shooting deaths of nine people during Bible study. The church massacre happened in the weeks after Beau Biden's death.
"Joe Biden, who was suffering his own loss at that time, gave comfort to those families who had lost loved ones," said Fletcher Smith Jr., a former state representative from Greenville.
In his speech Saturday night, as Mr. Biden recalled how he and his family sought comfort from the congregation, his wife, Jill, and daughter, Ashley, grew emotional, wiping away tears.
"We needed to heal, too," Mr. Biden said in a nod to the church. "We left here having arrived in overwhelming pain thinking, 'We can do this. We'll get through this.'"
Mr. Biden's connection to the state was on raw display last week, when he won the coveted endorsement of Rep. James Clyburn, the highest-ranking black lawmaker in Congress who is considered a kingmaker in South Carolina politics. Exit polls showed the endorsement of Mr. Clyburn was significant to nearly half of the electorate.
Mr. Biden bowed his head and grew emotional as the congressman announced his decision, which he said was made in part because his wife, Emily Clyburn, who died last September, had been so fond of Mr. Biden.
"I know Joe," Mr. Clyburn said. "We know Joe. But most importantly, Joe knows us."
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com

title: Buttigieg, Sanders Take Lead in Iowa
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
DES MOINES, Iowa -- After a day of confusion and recriminations over a technical mishap that snarled the vote count, the first wave of delayed results from Iowa's presidential caucuses showed Pete Buttigieg and Sen. Bernie Sanders at the top of the Democratic pack.
The early numbers, representing nearly three-quarters of precincts, suggested a possible split verdict that could have one candidate winning the popular vote and another securing the most delegates, the measure state and national party officials have said should determine the victor.
A close finish between Mr. Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Ind., and Mr. Sanders, of Vermont, also would underscore the larger Democratic primary battle between progressives and more moderate candidates in a field still totaling close to a dozen.
More broadly, the muddled results and fallout from the chaotic count stoked tensions among the candidates and concerns among party officials that the process is doing little to find a strong nominee who can unite the party.
Former Vice President Joe Biden, a longtime front-runner who has built his campaign on the idea that he is that candidate, appeared headed for a worse-than-expected finish. He is competing with Mr. Buttigieg and Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota among the more moderate candidates, and the Iowa results suggest he was beaten by Mr. Buttigieg who was barely known a year ago and who has never governed anything larger than a city of about 100,000 people.
The moderate contenders also face a growing challenge from billionaire Michael Bloomberg, who wasn't on the ballot but who has risen in polls after spending several hundred million dollars on advertising. Mr. Bloomberg said on Tuesday that he would further step up spending and hiring.
Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, representing the more liberal wing of the party, was below Mr. Buttigieg in the early results but above Mr. Biden.
Ms. Klobuchar, who frequently says on the campaign trail that she has never lost an election since fourth grade, appeared headed for a fifth-place finish in Iowa.
Though the state's population is small and not very diverse, Iowa's caucuses have had a reasonably good record in recent history of picking the eventual winner of the Democratic nomination: Al Gore in 2000, John Kerry in 2004, Barack Obama in 2008 and Hillary Clinton in 2016.
The caucuses have been less predictive among Republicans in recent election cycles.
There are indications the Democratic Party is unlikely to resolve its debate over candidates and vision anytime soon. All four of the top candidates heading into the caucuses had campaign war chests large enough to sustain them through February, including the New Hampshire primary next week.
A self-described democratic socialist, Mr. Sanders has recently shown strength in national polls. That has triggered concerns among centrist Democrats who worry President Trump, a Republican, would use Mr. Sanders's political identity to damage the party's prospects in November.
The release of the results followed a brief news conference Tuesday afternoon with Iowa Democratic Party Chairman Troy Price, who said the nearly one-day delay for even partial results was unacceptable and happened because of "multiple reporting challenges" as about 1,700 precincts began to feed results into state party headquarters.
Mr. Price declined to say when all of the state's results would be made public. "We're going to take the time we need," he said.
The state party is collecting paper records completed during the precinct meetings. It has attributed the holdup to a software glitch that triggered inconsistencies in data obtained from a mobile app used to report vote tallies.
"We know this data is accurate," Mr. Price said. "We also have a paper trail."
With 71% of precincts reporting, Mr. Buttigieg had the largest share of delegates to the state party convention, while Mr. Sanders had the second most. But Mr. Sanders led in the raw vote so far, followed by Mr. Buttigieg.
Ms. Warren and Mr. Biden were third and fourth respectively in both counts.
Mr. Buttigieg, a 38-year-old openly gay man who is the youngest in the race, could see a bump following what appears to be the best showing of any moderate in the race. He has positioned himself as a voice for generational change -- most of his top opponents are septuagenarians -- who is willing to work across the political aisle.
In New Hampshire, Mr. Buttigieg has also recorded strong support in polls, but he faces a stiffer challenge in the more ethnically diverse states of Nevada and South Carolina this month, as he has so far received virtually no support in polls from black and Latino voters.
The muddled reporting gave all the top candidates room to frame the result as a win.
Speaking to reporters Tuesday evening in New Hampshire after the release of some Iowa results, Mr. Buttigieg was asked what it would mean to his candidacy if he ends up finishing in second or third place. "It still amounts to an astonishing victory for our vision," he said.
In a statement, a senior adviser to Mr. Sanders called the early numbers gratifying. "In the partial data released so far, it's clear that in the first and second round more people voted for Bernie than any other candidate in the field," Jeff Weaver said.
Ms. Warren said at her first New Hampshire event on Tuesday, "We know that three of us will be dividing up most of the delegates coming out of Iowa. I'm feeling good."
Mr. Biden during an appearance in Nashua, N.H., expressed optimism after arriving from Iowa. "It's like my mother said, 'Hope springs eternal,'" Mr. Biden said. "We're not giving up."
State party officials in Nevada, where the second caucus of the nominating season will be held, on Feb. 22, pledged that they wouldn't experience the same failures as Iowa.
"We will not be employing the same app or vendor used in the Iowa caucus," Nevada State Democratic Party Chair William McCurdy said in a statement. "We had already developed a series of backups and redundant reporting systems, and are currently evaluating the best path forward."
Meanwhile, Mr. Trump pounced on the uncertainty, calling the Democratic caucuses an "unmitigated disaster" in a Tuesday morning tweet, ahead of his State of the Union address scheduled for that evening.
The reporting was complicated in this year's caucuses by additional data.
In response to calls for greater transparency following the close 2016 contest between Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton, the state party was to release for the first time the raw total for votes from both rounds of voting, along with the traditional share of delegates won.
Mr. Sanders has been ahead of his rivals in recent state polls in New Hampshire but Ms. Warren, Mr. Biden and Mr. Buttigieg have been within striking distance.
New Hampshire Democratic Party Chairman Raymond Buckley said it is "highly unusual to have at this point so many competitive campaigns. Usually we are down to three at the most."
---
Eliza Collins, Joshua Jamerson, Ken Thomas, Sabrina Siddiqui and Tarini Parti contributed to this article.
---
Partial Results
Of Iowa Caucus
With 62% of precincts reporting. Percentages reflect number of state convention delegates candidates will receive based on the results of each precinct caucus.

Pete Buttigieg 26.9%
Bernie Sanders 25.1%
Elizabeth Warren 18.3%
Joe Biden 15.6%
Amy Klobuchar 12.6%

title: House Sends Trump Impeachment Case to Senate for Trial; Seven impeachment managers selected by Speaker Nancy Pelosi are approved by House in near party-line vote
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—The House delivered two articles of impeachment against President Trump to the Senate on Wednesday, after voting to
approve seven Democratic managers
to prosecute the case before the Republican-controlled chamber.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said that she stressed litigation experience in choosing managers to handle the trial over alleged presidential abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. Senators are expected to be sworn in on Thursday, and the proceedings are scheduled to get under way in earnest on Tuesday.
"The emphasis is making the strongest possible case to protect and defend our Constitution, to seek the truth for the American people," Mrs. Pelosi (D., Calif.) said.
"President Trump has done nothing wrong," White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham said, adding that he "expects to be fully exonerated."
The managers aim to advance Democrats' arguments that Mr. Trump should be removed from office. The group comprises House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerrold Nadler of New York, Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff of California, Democratic Caucus Chairman Hakeem Jeffries of New York and Reps. Zoe Lofgren of California, Val Demings of Florida, Sylvia Garcia of Texas and Jason Crow of Colorado.
After a brief debate, the House approved the managers, 228 to 193, almost entirely along party lines. One Democrat, Rep. Collin Peterson of Minnesota, broke with the party and voted against the resolution. He had also opposed both articles of impeachment. Rep. Justin Amash of Michigan, an independent who left the GOP last year, supported the resolution.
The Democratic-led House
voted to impeach Mr. Trump
last month. The first article of impeachment stems from Mr. Trump
pressing Ukraine to investigate
former Vice President Joe Biden, a leading candidate for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, including by
withholding almost $400 million in aid
to help Kyiv combat Russian aggression. The second article accuses Mr. Trump of impeding Congress's investigation by preventing witnesses from testifying and defying subpoenas for documentary evidence.
After the House impeached Mr. Trump, Mrs. Pelosi held off on naming the managers for nearly a month, as Democrats unsuccessfully sought guarantees from Senate Republicans that new witnesses would be heard and new evidence presented. She relented this week, after Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) ratcheted up the pressure on her by signing on to a resolution to dismiss the case.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
What's your assessment of the managers picked to oversee the impeachment trial? Join the conversation below.
House Democratic leaders argue the delay paid off, as new emails and documents related to the case emerged in recent weeks, as well as documents showing the effort to undermine the then-U.S. ambassador to the country.
"It made sense to wait a while, as even more evidence piled up, but we have to proceed, because…the integrity of the election is at stake," said Mr. Nadler, referring to the November presidential election.
The White House doesn't believe there is a need to hear witness testimony in the Senate trial, a senior administration official said. The official said the White House considers it "extraordinarily unlikely" that the trial would last longer than two weeks.
But several Republican senators, including Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, have said they would be open to hearing from new witnesses, and Mr. McConnell has ruled out a quick dismissal of the case.
Witnesses sought by Democrats
include former national security adviser John Bolton and acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney, who were directed by the White House not to testify before the House inquiry.
Votes on witnesses and documents could extend the trial beyond the two-week time frame, potentially extending it through the Iowa caucuses on Feb. 3—the first nominating contest in the 2020 Democratic presidential race—and Mr. Trump's State of the Union address, scheduled for Feb. 4.
"If people decide they want to call witnesses, it probably could go on for a while," Sen. John Thune (R., S.D.), the No. 2 Senate Republican, said on Tuesday. He said that wrapping up the trial by Mr. Trump's State of the Union address "seems like a fairly tight deadline given what we are facing."
Related
*
Bios of Seven Democratic Impeachment Managers

*
Senate Impeachment Trial Likely to Start Next Tuesday, McConnell Says

*
New Documents From Giuliani Associate Parnas Submitted for Impeachment Trial

*
Russians Breached Burisma During Trump Impeachment Probe

Republican senators briefed on a GOP draft of rules for the trial said it likely will include
a guaranteed vote on witnesses
and documents after opening arguments and a period for written questions. Moderate Republicans had been pushing for such a vote, putting them at odds with Mr. Trump, who recently renewed his call to dismiss the articles without a trial.
Some GOP senators are pushing reciprocity of witnesses, so that if Democrats hear from Mr. Bolton, Republicans would push to hear from Mr. Biden's son, Hunter Biden, according to a person familiar with the matter. The younger Mr. Biden served on the board of a Ukrainian energy company that Mr. Trump asked Ukraine's leader to investigate—one of the acts at the center of the House's impeachment case.
"If [Democrats] end up getting witnesses, I'm going to insist there be a motion that the president gets to call anybody deemed to be necessary to his defense," said Sen. Rand Paul (R., Ky.) in an interview.
Both Bidens have denied any wrongdoing, and in the Democratic debate Tuesday night, Joe Biden called allegations from Mr. Trump and his allies "flat-out lies."
Mrs. Pelosi signed the articles of impeachment in a ceremony at the Capitol on Wednesday. Flanked by the leaders of several House committees and the impeachment managers, she again laid out the case for impeaching Mr. Trump, accusing him of abusing his oath of office and obstructing Congress. She then sat to formally sign the articles of impeachment, cycling through about a dozen pens emblazoned with her name as she did so, and finally handing one of the pens to each of the lawmakers gathered. She kept one for herself.
The House's clerk and the sergeant at arms, accompanied by all seven Democratic impeachment managers, then walked the articles to the Senate, along with a message that the House has appointed managers to exhibit the articles of impeachment.
In the Senate chamber, the camera flashes first came into view through the filigreed windows of the Senate door. At 5:34 p.m., the procession of seven House Democrats appeared at the door, met by Laura Dove, secretary for the Republicans, who signaled the group to head to the back wall.
The managers entered, single file, and walked to their places. At their desks inside the chamber, 27 Senate Democrats sat in their seats. Mr. McConnell and Sen. Kevin Cramer (R., N.D.) were in the room to bear witness.
"Mr. President, a message from the House of Representatives," Ms. Dove told Sen. Chuck Grassley (R., Iowa), the Senate's president pro tempore, who presided over the chamber.
Mr. McConnell acknowledged the message and said the Senate will receive the managers to present the articles of impeachment at noon Thursday.
"This is a difficult time for our country, but this is precisely the kind of time for which the framers created the Senate," he said.
On Thursday, Chief Justice John Roberts, who will preside over the trial, is to be sworn in by Mr. Grassley. Mr. Roberts is then expected to administer the same oath, to do "impartial justice," to all 100 senators, who will act as the jury. At least two-thirds of the senators would have to vote to convict Mr. Trump to remove him from office.
Mr. Trump will be summoned and given time to respond. Then the Senate is expected to break for the holiday weekend before reconvening to start the trial.
Proposed restrictions on press access during the trial have become a point of contention, with fewer ways for reporters to speak to senators and increased security within the Senate Press Gallery.
Rebecca Ballhaus, Siobhan Hughes and Andrew Duehren contributed to this article.
Capital Journal In Your Inbox

Sign up.

title: Foreign Threats More Numerous, Sophisticated as 2020 Election Looms, Official Says; Concerns about Russia interference rose anew this week after experts reported hackers had targeted company caught up in Trump impeachment
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—The top U.S. intelligence official for election security warned that adversaries seeking to interfere in the 2020 elections have become "more sophisticated" as states prepare to hold the voting season's first primaries and caucuses next month.
Shelby Pierson, the principal adviser on election threats in the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, said Tuesday that actors intent on spreading malign influence have become more numerous and potent since Russia's breaches in the 2016 election. She included Iran, China and North Korea, as well as Russia and hackers unaffiliated with governments, on the threat list.
"The threats as we go into 2020 are frankly more sophisticated," said Mrs. Pierson in a speech at a conference for election administrators. "They have sharpened their own capabilities," she said about foreign adversaries without elaborating.
U.S. intelligence agencies have concluded that the Russian government directed hacking and social media campaigns to disrupt the presidential election in 2016. Concerns about Russian interference rose anew this week after a cybersecurity firm reported that Russian hackers had
targeted a Ukrainian gas company caught up in the impeachment inquiry
into President Trump.
Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Tuesday that she was alarmed by the report that hackers connected to Russia's military intelligence recently breached Burisma Holdings, the Ukrainian energy firm where a son of Joe Biden, the former vice president and a Democratic candidate for president, once served on the board.
Mrs. Pelosi told reporters at the Capitol that House Democrats discussed the alleged hacking during a closed-door caucus meeting. A House Intelligence Committee official also said the panel has asked the intelligence community for more information.
Mrs. Pierson declined to comment on Burisma when asked by reporters.
In her remarks at the conference, she described 2016 as a watershed for the intelligence community, which, she said, has since marshaled its expertise on cybersecurity and foreign adversaries to counter the threat.
"This is not a Russia-only problem," Mrs. Pierson said. "Russia, China, Iran, North Korea, nonstate hacktivists all have opportunity, means and potentially motive to come after the United States in the 2020 election to accomplish their goals."
Voting systems in the U.S. are run by state and local governments across the country, posing a challenge to protecting them from breaches. Among recent security improvements are the use of more secure voting machines, testing by third-party experts and training sessions with national security agencies.
Election officials at the conference on Tuesday said that they are better prepared to ward off cyber threats, but also that they expect adversaries to try to find new ways to interfere.
"We better all be on our toes," said Vermont Secretary of State Jim Condos in remarks to the conference. "They're coming at us this year."
Dustin Volz contributed to this article.

title: Race Moves to New Hampshire as Iowa Remains in Flux; Sanders, Buttigieg, Warren and Biden are in tight race leading up to state's Democratic primary vote
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
LACONIA, N.H.—Democratic presidential candidates arrived in New Hampshire with busy campaign schedules but locked in a race denied any clear sense of direction by
the caucus problems
in Iowa.
As the Iowa Democratic Party began releasing results late Tuesday, people in line for a Pete Buttigieg town hall in central New Hampshire were live-streaming cable news on their phones. One man yelled, "We won," as the initial tallies showed the former South Bend, Ind., mayor in the lead.
At Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren's morning event in Keene, voters predicted the confusion from Monday night in Iowa would focus even more attention on the nation's first voting primary.
"Everyone's eyes are here now," said Christine Hansen, a 64-year-old retired physical-therapy assistant.
Mr. Buttigieg had told supporters as he arrived in the state early Tuesday that he was optimistic about his results in Iowa—and his chances in New Hampshire. Four-term Nashua, N.H., Mayor Jim Donchess endorsed Mr. Buttigieg on Tuesday morning, saying mayors "get results."
The initial results from Iowa showed Mr. Buttigieg in a close race for first place with Sen. Bernie Sanders (I., Vt.). Mr. Sanders was scheduled to hold a rally Tuesday night in Milford, N.H., shortly before President Trump was to deliver his State of the Union address in Washington.
Former Vice President Joe Biden, in comments in Nashua, said his campaign officials "don't know precisely" how many delegates he earned in Iowa, but he said he felt good about getting "more than our fair share."
"Now it's time for New Hampshire to speak and speak loudly," he said.
New Hampshire Democratic officials said their election night would be far smoother next Tuesday; voters cast secret ballots rather than engaging in the complex process used by Iowa.
Results for the Iowa race weren't released on Monday as expected, with the Iowa Democratic Party attributing the problem to inconsistencies in data reported through t
he election app
used to report vote tallies. The party began putting out tallies around 5 p.m. Eastern time, reporting 62% of its total, with promises of additional updates.
Just as in Iowa, polls in New Hampshire aren't foreshadowing a runaway winner. Rather, four candidates—Messrs. Biden, Sanders, Buttigieg and Ms. Warren—have been well ahead of the other candidates in recent state polls, and often within single digits of each other.
Mr. Sanders led at 24%, topping Mr. Biden by six percentage points in a Boston Globe/WBZ-TV/Suffolk University poll of likely New Hampshire Democratic voters released late Monday. Ms. Warren and Mr. Buttigieg polled in the low double-digits in that survey, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 4.4 percentage points.
Complicating the forecast in the state, almost half of New Hampshire residents registered to vote identify not as Democrats or Republicans, but as undeclared, according to statistics kept by the secretary of state. Both undeclared and Democratic registrants can vote in the primary, making it difficult to predict which voters will turn out and which candidate will prevail.
At political events across the state on Monday, residents said they were eager to see what Iowans had decided and would look to the Friday debate in New Hampshire for guidance.
"I have my favorites, but it depends on the day," said Kelly Zeilman, a sophomore at Dartmouth College in Hanover, before listing what she viewed as positive attributes of six of the 11 candidates still in the race, as well as one whom she said she still liked even though he had dropped out months ago.
Others said the New Hampshire voting would be more straightforward than Iowa's caucuses.
"You don't get an individual vote, it's all by consensus, which doesn't seem prudent in 2020," said Nancy Bonell, a 62-year-old retired YMCA official attending Ms. Warren's Tuesday event. She said she found the Iowa process daunting.
Share Your Thoughts
How might the delay of Iowa caucus results affect the New Hampshire primary? Join the conversation below.
The state's populous liberal enclaves, such as Concord and Manchester, helped push Mr. Sanders, from neighboring Vermont, to a 22-point victory over Hillary Clinton four years ago. That win turbocharged his fundraising and momentum, ensuring a long primary.
Joshua Adjutant, a Sanders supporter and a young state representative from Grafton, N.H., praised Mr. Sanders for moving the Democratic Party to the left on issues like health care. "The longer he's in sight, the more people like him," Mr. Adjutant said.
In polls, Mr. Sanders has mostly held a narrow lead over rivals, though sometimes they have topped him. He replaced his top strategist and campaign manager in the state in September.
Mr. Buttigieg has made an aggressive play for voters in areas that have leaned more independent or Republican, including Wolfeboro, where 2012 GOP nominee Mitt Romney has a summer home.
Sue Prentiss, the former mayor of Lebanon and a Republican until Mr. Trump's election, said voters like her have been looking at both Mr. Buttigieg and Mr. Biden. She backs Mr. Buttigieg, but said she understood why "people consider Joe Biden a safe space."
"The question everyone is asking is, 'Who has what it takes to beat Donald Trump?' " she said.
Ms. Warren has a robust network of volunteers who have been pitching her for more than a year. Her campaign also advocated for candidates in local races to build Democratic relationships. Ms. Warren is from neighboring Massachusetts, but she hasn't advertised in the pricey Boston television market, which bleeds into New Hampshire, since her 2012 Senate race. She only began advertising here in mid-January.
The candidates and political groups involved in the race have bombarded the state with about $40 million in TV and radio ads, with more likely to come in this final week, according to ad tracker Kantar/CMAG. Billionaire self-funded candidate Tom Steyer accounts for half of that spending, but he hasn't been registering in polls.
Mr. Sanders has spent about $6 million on ads, far more than Ms. Warren's $1.5 million. Mr. Buttigieg has spent about $3.3 million on ads.
Neither Mr. Biden nor the super PAC backing him have put significant money into TV or radio here. Mr. Biden and his supporters have instead poured resources into other early primary states, such as South Carolina, where his commanding support from African-American voters has given him an edge.
Former Massachusetts Gov. Deval Patrick and Colorado Sen. Michael Bennet both largely sidestepped Iowa and are betting on New Hampshire voters to lift their longshot campaigns out of obscurity. A super PAC backing Mr. Patrick, called Reason to Believe, has put almost $2 million into a New Hampshire TV and radio ad plan, Kantar/CMAG shows.
At a campaign event Monday afternoon in Hanover, Mr. Patrick faced a pointed question from Gail Murray, of Canaan, N.H., who said she found his November entry into an already crowded primary puzzling. "What the heck?" she asked.
"Have you decided, by the way?" Mr. Patrick shot back.
"I have not," she admitted.
"I'm not too late for you," he said.
More
*
Democrats Call for End of Iowa Caucuses After Results Debacle

*
Iowa Democratic Caucuses Result? More Uncertainty

*
Iowa's Tally-by-App Experiment Fails

Write to Julie Bykowicz at
julie.bykowicz@wsj.com
and Joshua Jamerson at
joshua.jamerson@wsj.com

title: Democrats, Trump Team Make Final Arguments in Impeachment Trial; President is set to be acquitted by Senate later this week after vote not to seek new witnesses or documents
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—House Democrats and President Trump's defense team concluded their closing arguments to the Senate, the last major step in the
impeachment trial
before an expected acquittal this week on
charges
of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.
The two sides gave their final pitches Monday to the jury of 100 senators who had largely made up their minds on impeachment, broadly unmoved by three weeks of presentations and arguments. They used their final two hours apiece to issue warnings: Democrats focused on what they saw as the danger to democracy presented by Mr. Trump remaining in office, while the Trump legal team decried what it called the use of impeachment as a political weapon.
The vote on the two articles of impeachment will be on Wednesday. The first article stems from
Mr. Trump pressing Ukraine
to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a top Democratic presidential candidate, which Democrats allege amounted to attempted interference in the 2020 election. The second article accuses Mr. Trump of obstructing Congress's investigation by preventing witnesses from testifying and defying subpoenas for documentary evidence.
More on the Trump Impeachment Trial
*
Trump, Democrats Press Their Case as Impeachment Trial Nears Its End

*
Senate Rejects Witnesses in Trump Impeachment Trial

*
How Republicans Scotched the Idea of Witnesses in Impeachment Trial

In the trial proceedings Monday, House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D., Calif.), the lead impeachment manager, again urged senators to convict Mr. Trump. Mr. Schiff warned of a "runaway presidency" and argued that Mr. Trump's removal was needed now, rather than waiting for the 2020 election to decide his fate.
"He has betrayed our national security and he will do so again," Mr. Schiff said. "He has compromised our elections and he will do so again. You will not change him.…Now do impartial justice and convict him."
Mr. Trump has denied wrongdoing and again called impeachment a hoax on Twitter on Monday. His legal team, in their presentation, painted the Democrats' pursuit of impeachment as purely political, driven by a longstanding dislike of the president.
"At the end of the day, this is an effort to overturn the results of one election and to try to interfere in the coming election that begins today in Iowa," said White House counsel Pat Cipollone.
Iowa's caucuses
Monday evening kick off the Democratic and Republican nominating contests.
"What the House Democrats have done to this nation, to the Constitution, to the office of the president, to the president himself and to this body is outrageous," said another Trump team lawyer, Jay Sekulow.
Mr. Trump and his allies have argued that Mr. Trump's interest in Mr. Biden was legitimate, alleging it was corrupt for Mr. Biden during the Obama administration to seek the ouster of a Ukrainian prosecutor who had once investigated a Ukrainian gas company where Mr. Biden's son Hunter sat on the board. Mr. Biden sought the prosecutor's removal as part of a broad international effort to combat corruption in Ukraine. The Bidens have denied wrongdoing. Hunter Biden has said it was poor judgment on his part to serve on the Burisma board while his father was involved with Ukraine policy as vice president.
An acquittal for Mr. Trump is all but certain, following the
Senate's vote
last week to not seek new witnesses or documents and as Republicans defended the president's actions. Twenty Republicans would have to join the entire Democratic caucus to vote to remove the president. No Republicans have said they favor impeachment, and just two supported the Democrats' effort last week to seek more evidence in the trial, which failed 51-49.
What isn't clear is whether the acquittal vote will be bipartisan. Some Democratic senators, such as Joe Manchin of West Virginia, Doug Jones of Alabama and Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, are undecided. Mr. Jones, representing a state that backed President Trump by 28 points in the 2016 election, is
the most vulnerable Democratic senator
this cycle.
The president is scheduled to give his State of the Union speech on Tuesday, in the chamber where the House approved two articles of impeachment against him in December. Some Republicans hoped that the president would move forward past impeachment in the annual speech.
"There are a lot of really great things he should talk about, and stay away from maybe what the proceedings are," said Sen. Joni Ernst (R., Iowa). "Let's focus on the things that can bring us together. What does he want to see coming up next? We've got infrastructure we need to be working on. I think we really need something that will pull Democrats and Republicans back together again."
But Sen. Angus King (I., Maine), who caucuses with the Democrats, said he expects Mr. Trump to be emboldened as he heads into the State of the Union address, and beyond.
"He's expressed no remorse or understanding that he did anything wrong, so why should he hold back? That's what worries me," Mr. King said.
A new
Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll
published on Sunday found a majority of voters said they believed Mr. Trump abused his power by asking Ukraine to investigate a potential political opponent in order to influence the coming election, and that Mr. Trump obstructed Congress by not cooperating with the impeachment inquiry.
But there wasn't majority support for removing him from office. The poll found 49% said he should be allowed to finish his term, compared with 46% who said he should be removed. Mr. Trump's job approval in the January poll stood at 46%, with 51% disapproving, in line with results throughout the Trump presidency.
Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.
Capital Journal In Your Inbox
Get the latest scoops, analysis and insights driving Washington from the WSJ's D.C. bureau, with Capital Journal.
Sign up.

Natalie.Andrews@wsj.com
