title: The Moments That Mattered in the January Democratic Debate; Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders sparred over whether a woman could be president
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
The
impending impeachment trial
, the U.S. troop presence in the Middle East and whether a woman can win the White House were among the topics six Democratic presidential contenders
addressed during the last debate
before voters start selecting a nominee to face the president in November.
"Look at the men on this stage. Collectively, they have lost 10 elections. The only people on this stage who have won every single election that they've been in are the women: Amy and me."—Sen. Elizabeth Warren
Tension has been brewing between Sens. Warren and Sanders, who share much of the Democratic liberal base.

Ms. Warren said earlier this week
that Mr. Sanders told her during a private 2018 meeting that a woman couldn't win the presidency. Mr. Sanders has repeatedly denied that, including during the debate. Though Ms. Warren called Mr. Sanders "a friend" when asked about the event, she pointed out the records of the two women Democratic contenders compared with the four male candidates. After the debate ended Ms. Warren refused Mr. Sanders' handshake, leading to a terse exchange between the two on stage, though it was unclear what was said.
Why this matters: The recent disputes have further divided the two campaigns, but the candidates kept it mostly friendly during the debate. Ms. Warren and Mr. Sanders have since pointed out that any infighting could ultimately help Mr. Trump. Still, there are concerns that if Mr. Sanders's campaign is too divisive, his supporters may not rally around any other potential nominee—and that could lead to a repeat of what happened in the 2016 election with Hillary Clinton.
"The American people are sick and tired of endless wars which have cost us trillions of dollars."—Sen. Bernie Sanders
President Trump's decision to authorize an airstrike that
resulted in the death
of Iranian Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani has reignited a debate over America's military footprint in the Middle East.
The candidates were near unanimous in arguing for a diminished U.S. military presence in the region. But they differed sharply on a timeline for withdrawing troops, with Sens. Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders suggesting the U.S. should pull out of the Middle East entirely.
"We should stop asking our military to solve problems that cannot be solved militarily," Ms. Warren said.
Former Vice President Joe Biden and Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar disagreed, suggesting it was impossible to remove all troops from the Middle East. Former South Bend, Ind. Mayor Pete Buttigieg, a veteran of the Afghanistan war, said he favored taking a more limited approach and called for further military action to be authorized by Congress.
Why this matters: Foreign policy has largely taken a back seat in the Democratic primary in favor of domestic priorities such as health care and the economy. But Mr. Trump's recent actions in Iran have forced Democrats to contend with circumstances under which the U.S. could be fighting another ground war.
Mr. Biden's opponents have zeroed in on his vote in favor of the Iraq war, which the former vice president now acknowledges was "a mistake." Mr. Sanders, who opposed the war, said it was "the worst foreign policy blunder in modern American history." So far, Mr. Biden's Iraq war vote hasn't proved as much a liability as it was for Hillary Clinton in 2008.
"I don't know that there's any trade agreement that [Mr. Sanders] would ever think it made any sense."—Former Vice President Joe Biden
Mr. Trump is poised to sign a
preliminary trade deal with China
on Wednesday, paving the way for a temporary detente in the continuing trade war between the world's two largest economies. The Senate also is gearing up for a vote to ratify the revamped North American trade deal, known as the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement,
which was passed by the House of Representatives last month
. All of the Democratic candidates onstage—with the exception of Mr. Sanders and billionaire environmentalist Tom Steyer—said they supported the USMCA despite their broader reservations over Mr. Trump's handling of trade policy.
Why this matters: Democrats have grown increasingly critical of international trade agreements amid pressure from labor unions and environmental groups. But ongoing divisions within the party over how to revamp existing trade deals were laid bare on Tuesday, as candidates sparred over the impact on American workers.
Ms. Warren, in a split with her liberal rival Mr. Sanders, backed the USMCA as "a modest improvement" that will provide temporary relief to farmers she said were hurting as a result of Mr. Trump's tariffs. Citing environmental concerns, Mr. Sanders maintained his opposition to the deal, stating: "The answer is we can do much better than a Trump-led trade deal."
Mr. Biden vowed there would be no trade agreements signed in his administration "without environmentalists and labor at the table," but warned against isolating the U.S. economy by refusing to forge trade partnerships with international allies. Mr. Buttigieg said much of the "fear and frustration" over U.S. trade policy stemmed from a sentiment among American workers, in regions such as the industrial Midwest, that they had been left behind by previous trade deals.
The issue of trade is especially salient in Iowa, the first state in the Democratic nominating contest, where the agricultural industry has been disrupted by Mr. Trump's trade war with China.
"We've asked for only four people as witnesses. And if our Republican colleagues won't allow those witnesses, they may as well give the president a crown and a scepter; they may as well make him king."—Sen. Amy Klobuchar
The Democratic-led House
last month voted to impeach
Mr. Trump on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, for just the third time in the nation's history.
Mr. Trump, who has denied any wrongdoing, has urged the Senate to dismiss the articles of impeachment without a trial. But moderate Republicans have been pushing hard behind the scenes to allow a vote on witnesses and documents.
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, who has been coordinating with the White House on impeachment strategy, has said he has enough Republican support to move forward on the proceedings without bipartisan agreement on the trial's structure. Under his plan, senators would wait to determine whether to include witnesses until after the trial begins, which he
expects will be next Tuesday.

Republican senators briefed on draft rules for the trial have said they would likely guarantee a vote on witnesses and documents after opening arguments and a period for written questions.
Why this matters: Democrats have demanded the ability to call witnesses and subpoena documents to gather more information than what came out during the House investigation.
Meanwhile, after a weekslong wait the House plans to vote Wednesday to name the Democrats who will argue the case for Mr. Trump's removal. The chamber will then send the articles over to the Senate.
Sens. Sanders, Warren and Klobuchar have said they would fulfill their senatorial duties and participate in any trial. Sen. Michael Bennet of Colorado, who didn't qualify for Tuesday's debate, would also be affected. The senators have said they would use surrogates on the campaign trail.
"This debate isn't real."—Sen. Amy Klobuchar
The Democratic presidential candidates again sparred over health care reform.
Ms. Klobuchar said many members of Congress and Democratic governors don't support Medicare for All and a public option should be pursued in addition to coverage for mental health, disabilities and long-term care insurance.
Health care was expected to come up in the debate after Mr. Trump this week tweeted that he had saved pre-existing conditions. The Trump administration has backed a lawsuit that would invalidate the Affordable Care Act, which bars insurers from denying people health coverage because of past and current medical issues.
The administration is also arguing against having the Supreme Court fast-track consideration of the lawsuit, so the court may not decide until after the 2020 presidential election.
Why this matters: Polls show voters are more eager to hear concrete ideas about lowering health costs, particularly for prescription drugs, even though the debate again focused heavily on Medicare for All compared to the public option.
Candidates sparred over the costs of their proposals, with Mr. Sanders saying the average family would ultimately benefit from Medicare for All whereas Mr. Biden called for reinstating Obamacare with the addition of a public option.
Ms. Klobuchar's point, echoing that of many moderate critics, was that the debate over Medicare for All was largely irrelevant because it is so unlikely to ever pass through Congress.
Write to Sabrina Siddiqui at
Sabrina.Siddiqui@wsj.com
and Emily Glazer at
emily.glazer@wsj.com

Share Your Thoughts
Which candidate made the strongest pitch for their campaign? Join the conversation below.

title: U.S. News: How Democrats, Trump Lawyers Made Case
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON -- In six days of arguments on the Senate floor, Democrats and the White House defense team sparred over whether the president abused the power of his office and obstructed Congress -- and whether those actions would merit his removal from office.
In one major development after the Democrats finished their arguments, the New York Times revealed that former national security adviser John Bolton, in a draft of his forthcoming book, wrote that President Trump told him aid to Ukraine was conditioned on investigations.
Here is a breakdown of the arguments the House Democratic impeachment managers made on key points, and how the Trump team responded:
Ukraine Aid
Impeachment Managers: The Democrats alleged Mr. Trump leveraged nearly $400 million in aid to Ukraine to pressure Kyiv to undertake investigations that could benefit him politically. Democrats said that amounted to an effort to interfere in the 2020 election. The aid was released after pressure from Congress.
Trump's Defense: Mr. Trump's team noted the aid to Ukraine was released in September without any announcement of investigations by Ukraine. President Trump denied the conversation Mr. Bolton described in his book.
July 25 Call
Impeachment Managers: Democrats said the White House sought to cover up a July 25 phone call with the Ukrainian president -- in which Mr. Trump asked him to investigate Democrat Joe Biden and his son and alleged election interference -- by moving the transcript to a classified server typically reserved for the nation's top secrets.
Trump Defense: Lawyers said the White House wasn't seeking to hide the transcript of the July 25 phone call because it was both preserved on a White House server and, in September, made public. The lawyers also pointed to the fact that Mr. Trump didn't link aid to investigations on the call.
Articles of Impeachment
Impeachment Managers: Aside from blocking aid, Democrats said, the president obstructed the impeachment investigation by blocking evidence and testimony sought by House investigators.
Trump's Defense: The president's team argued the articles of impeachment are constitutionally deficient and overly broad. The lawyers also argued that Democrats don't allege that the president committed a crime, which they said is necessary to warrant removal from office.
Removal From Office
Impeachment Managers: The president poses a national security threat to the country and, said Rep. Adam Schiff (D., Calif.), an "imminent threat to the integrity of our democracy" and therefore must be removed prior to the 2020 election.
Trump's Defense: Mr. Trump's lawyers said the president is up for re-election in less than 10 months and the choice should be left to the voters. The lawyers also countered Democrats' calls for urgency in removing the president from office by noting that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) waited a month to turn over the articles of impeachment to the Senate.
Senate Witnesses
Impeachment Managers: Democrats argued the Senate should call new witnesses who could offer first-hand accounts of the president's motivation for holding up aid to Ukraine.
Trump's Defense: The president's team said the House was responsible for collecting testimony and documents, and in voting for the articles of impeachment determined it had enough evidence to warrant the president's removal from office.

title: For Business, Does Biden Mean Four More Years of Obama? The former vice president is a pro-worker candidate who criticizes stock buybacks, but at heart he's a pragmatist friendly to business interests.
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Editor's note: This is an excerpt from our newsletter, "
2020 Election+Business
," a weekly dive into the intersection of business, finance and the 2020 election.
You can sign up here
.
Super Tuesday propelled Joe Biden into a two-way race for the Democratic nomination with Bernie Sanders, and
last night's series of victorie
s strengthened the former vice president's standing in the race for the Democratic nomination. While we watch to see if the surge lifts him to the nomination and then the White House, let's take a look at what business can expect from Mr. Biden.
Would it simply be a continuation of policies pursued during President Barack Obama's eight years in office?
Mr. Biden's tenure as vice president, of course, started amid a crippling financial crisis and was followed by a long period of slow-growth recovery.
At the time,
executives often complained
about the buildup of new regulations. Politicians
criticized companies for underinvesting
, hiring too slowly and hoarding corporate cash overseas.
Now, he's running against the more liberal Sen. Bernie Sanders. The emergence of "middle-of-the-road Joe" is seen as positive for business by comparison, said Ed Mills, Washington policy analyst for Raymond James Financial Inc.
But every candidate needs to build coalitions. Winning the support of progressive voters could force Mr. Biden to adopt more aggressive positions on taxation or workers' rights.
Today, Mr. Biden is campaigning as an ardently pro-worker candidate who criticizes practices like stock buybacks and excessive executive compensation. His record suggests that, at heart, he's a pragmatist reasonably friendly to business interests.
Which Joe Biden would business get if he wins the White House? Here's where he stands on key issues:
Trade: Mr. Biden was among the Democrats voting in favor of the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993, and played a key role in the Obama administration's support for the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
Mr. Biden now says he would renegotiate TPP as a counterweight to China. He has indicated the U.S. does need to remain tough on China—particularly in areas of intellectual property theft or technology transfers—but advocates for a broader coalition of support among trading partners.
Mr. Biden wouldn't completely abandon tariffs as a stick or quotas on carbon-intensive goods from countries failing to meet environmental obligations.
Taxes: If Mr. Biden wins the nomination, taxes are one of the areas where business leaders should feel they "dodged a bullet compared with Sanders or Elizabeth Warren," said Allison Schrager, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute. Mr. Biden's plan picks up certain proposals from the end of the Obama administration that Mr. Trump killed.
While Mr. Biden wants to increase the corporate tax rate—from 21%, where Mr. Trump's 2017 tax cut has left it—he doesn't want to return to the 35% precut rate. He proposes a 28% income-tax rate on companies and a 15% minimum tax on global book income with a credit for foreign taxes paid, according to the
Urban Institute's analysis
.
Credits would limit some of the increase. These include tax credits targeting communities hit hard by mass layoffs; electric-car and solar subsidies; and enhanced incentives for carbon capture. Mr. Biden's plan would eliminate certain tax benefits for the real-estate industry, fossil-fuel companies and pharmaceutical companies.
Environment: Mr. Biden has said he wants to rejoin the Paris Climate Accord and sees the Green New Deal as a "framework" for progress. He plans to hold oil executives accountable to commitments to alternative energy.
But "he's not an ideologue," Mr. Mills said. Other analysts agree, saying Mr. Biden is more of an incrementalist, meaning his climate commitment may be more accommodating to economic growth and corporate profits.
Uncertainty: Mr. Trump's erratic tweeting and trade wars create confusion even when the economy is strong, some business leaders say. Concern about the coronavirus has slowed growth, and the election is sure to feature questions about who can restore confidence.
Mr. Biden is "more predictable than Trump—at least he's on the spectrum of what we consider normal for communication styles," Ms. Schrager said. This makes a difference for companies making long-term investment decisions.
Workers: Mr. Biden has said
employees don't have enough leverage
, partially because of globalization and partially because declining unionization has weakened their bargaining power with management.
Mr. Biden favors a $15 per hour minimum wage (a proposal often opposed by business trade groups) and wants to revise worker classifications that determines who receives overtime pay.
For more news and analysis like this, sign up for our Election+Business newsletter
here
.
Write to John D. Stoll at
john.stoll@wsj.com

title: Joe Biden Wins South Carolina Democratic Presidential Primary
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit





Joe Biden at his primary night event at the University of South Carolina. PHOTO: Victor J. Blue for The Wall Street Journal
WASHINGTON—Former Vice President Joe Biden won the South Carolina Democratic presidential primary, giving him a much-needed boost in a race that had been dominated by front-runner Bernie Sanders.
Mr. Biden's victory in South Carolina marked the first time he has won a presidential contest after two unsuccessful runs for the Democratic nomination in 1988 and 2008. The former vice president, who found himself in a tenuous position after
disappointing showings in Iowa
and New Hampshire this year, said he was staging a comeback in the Democratic primaries, declaring Saturday night that "for all those of you who have been knocked down, counted out and left behind, this is your campaign."
"Now, thanks to all of you, the heart of the Democratic Party, we just won, and we won big because of you," Mr. Biden, flanked by members of his family and Rep. James Clyburn, the top African-American serving in the House, said to cheers at a party in Columbia, S.C. "We are very much alive."
The results Saturday could help the former vice president's chances in 14 states that head to the polls next week on what's known as Super Tuesday, when more than a third of the delegates to the Democratic National Convention will be at stake.
Mr. Biden is part of a still-crowded field of Democrats competing for the party's nomination to challenge President Trump in November. Mr. Sanders emerged out of the first three states to vote
as a clear front-runner
, leaving more moderate Democrats anxious about the potential of nominating a self-described democratic socialist.
On Sunday, the Sanders campaign announced it raised $46.5 million in February from more than 2.2 million donations. That number dwarfs the $25 million Mr. Sanders
raised in January
. In the year since he announced, Mr. Sanders has brought in more than $167 million from over 8.7 million individual donations.
Mr. Biden on Saturday urged the party to rally behind his candidacy, calling himself a "lifelong Democrat, a proud Democrat, an Obama-Biden Democrat."
"We have an option of winning big or losing big, that's the choice," Mr. Biden said.
Addressing supporters in Virginia Beach Saturday night, Mr. Sanders, who appeared poised to finish second in South Carolina with 86% of precincts reporting, reminded them that he won the popular vote in Iowa and
held up his victories in the New Hampshire primary
and Nevada caucuses.
"But you cannot win 'em all … and tonight, we did not win in South Carolina," Mr. Sanders said, adding it wouldn't be "the only defeat."
"There are a lot of states in this country. Nobody wins 'em all," he said to boos. "I want to congratulate Joe Biden on his victory tonight. And now we head to Super Tuesday."
Billionaire Tom Steyer, who had dedicated much of his resources to South Carolina, said he was
dropping out of the race
after appearing set to place third.
"I said if I didn't see a path to winning that I'd suspend my campaign, and honestly, I can't see a path where I can win the presidency," Mr. Steyer told supporters in Columbia, S.C.
Mr. Biden's South Carolina win could help him convince voters that he is the moderate Democrat best positioned to slow Mr. Sanders's rise and to face Mr. Trump. Former South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar have also been competing in the same lane.
Most of Mr. Biden's rivals spent less time than he did in South Carolina, due in part to the former vice president's strength in the state. He has long had the most support among African-American voters who make up a significant chunk of the state's Democratic electorate, and
exit poll data
from the Washington Post showed he maintained a big lead with that group.
Several Democrats were already pivoting to Super Tuesday states as results came in on Saturday.
Mr. Sanders campaigned in Massachusetts and Virginia; Ms. Klobuchar made stops in Tennessee, Virginia, Maine and North Carolina; Mr. Buttigieg held a virtual town-hall meeting in South Carolina but was otherwise in Tennessee and North Carolina; and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren traveled to Arkansas and Texas.
Ms. Warren, speaking to supporters in Texas, which votes on Super Tuesday, congratulated Mr. Biden and reiterated that she planned to stay in the race for "the long haul."
"I'll be the first to say that the first four contests haven't gone exactly as I'd hoped. We want to gain as many delegates to the convention as we can—from California to right here in Texas," Ms. Warren said in Houston. "It may take days or even longer to know the full results from Super Tuesday, but they will be critical in sorting out who our nominee will be this year."
Former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who wasn't on the ballot in South Carolina and has instead
poured millions of dollars into states
that vote Tuesday, held events in Virginia and North Carolina.
In response to Mr. Biden's victory on Saturday, Mr. Bloomberg's campaign emphasized that the former mayor hadn't yet been on the ballot.
"Mike is the only candidate to campaign in all fourteen Super Tuesday states over the last two months and we look forward to Tuesday," Mr. Bloomberg's campaign manager, Kevin Sheekey, said in a statement. "Mike's record of successfully leading and managing through crises and challenges is exactly what Americans are looking for in a new President."
A Bloomberg campaign aide cited internal data showing that if he dropped out, it would put Mr. Sanders on a stronger path to a pledged delegate majority.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
To what extent will Joe Biden's performance Saturday in South Carolina determine his fate in the Democratic nomination race? Join the conversation below.
Mr. Biden, who had camped out in South Carolina after placing second in the Nevada caucuses, campaigned extensively among black voters in the final days before the state's primary. He has argued that other centrist candidates, such as Mr. Buttigieg and Ms. Klobuchar, lack sufficient support from nonwhite voters to have a plausible path to the nomination.
Although Mr. Biden has so far avoided publicly calling on his rivals to step aside, his campaign began suggesting members of the field should reconsider their futures after his South Carolina victory.
"If you are a candidate and you have not shown that you can get traction with the core of the Democratic Party, with African-American voters, then you have to take a hard look at your path and what your goals are," said T.J. Ducklo, a Biden spokesman.
In the days leading up to the primary, Mr. Biden earned
Mr. Clyburn's influential endorsement
, as well as that of Virginia Sen. Tim Kaine, a former governor and vice-presidential candidate who is popular in his home state, which votes on Tuesday.
Former Virginia Gov. Terry McAuliffe also threw his support behind Mr. Biden following his victory in South Carolina.
"We can't afford four more years of Donald Trump's hate-driven chaos and Joe Biden is the candidate with the character, experience, and broad appeal to defeat him," Mr. McAuliffe, who served as Virginia's governor from 2014 to 2018, said in a statement. "I've always said that our best leader is one who can build a broad coalition, including African-American voters who are the heart of the Democratic Party. After South Carolina, it is clear Joe Biden is that leader."
Unite the Country, a political-action committee supporting Mr. Biden's candidacy, has put more than $1.2 million into advertising in the Super Tuesday states of Arkansas, Alabama, North Carolina, Tennessee, Texas and Virginia, according to Federal Election Commission filings.
At Mr. Biden's South Carolina primary celebration, his supporters were jubilant as they awaited the results and counted down the final seconds before the polls closed. 





Supporters celebrate as the South Carolina primary is called for Joe Biden at his election night watch party. PHOTO: Victor J. Blue for The Wall Street Journal
When the broadcast networks immediately called the primary for Mr. Biden, the crowd erupted, waving American flags and blue Biden campaign posters.
"I figured when he got to South Carolina, he would do a lot better," said Brandon Koon, who raised a Biden campaign sign. "He was a loyal vice president to Obama, and I liked Obama a whole lot."
"He's a good, decent, honest man," he added of Mr. Biden.
It is too soon to tell whether the South Carolina results will reshape the trajectory of a race that many Democrats previously believed was Mr. Sanders's to lose.
Mr. Sanders held a Saturday afternoon rally in Boston, where he didn't mention the vote under way in South Carolina despite suggesting in recent days that he had a shot at winning the state. In 2016, Mr. Sanders lost South Carolina to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton by 48 points.
Voters who attended Mr. Sanders's rally in Boston played down the significance of South Carolina.
"I don't think it matters," said Bill Shine, a 62-year-old doctor from Shrewsbury, Mass.
At a Saturday afternoon rally in Raleigh, N.C., Mr. Biden said a victory in South Carolina would reverberate in coming contests on March 3.
"I'll tell you what, the full comeback starts in South Carolina," he told a boisterous crowd of about 1,000 at St. Augustine's University. "We're going to win here as well, and then it's a straight path to the nomination for president of the United States of America."
Chad Day, Eliza Collins in Boston, John McCormick in Charleston, S.C., Joshua Jamerson in Houston and Tarini Parti in Charlotte, N.C., contributed to this article.
Write to Sabrina Siddiqui at
Sabrina.Siddiqui@wsj.com
and Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com

title: Sanders Vows to Stay in Race, as Biden Looks to Unite Democrats; Two powerful liberal groups declare former vice president the likely party nominee
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Bernie Sanders made a case for continuing in the 2020 race, challenging his front-running rival, Joe Biden, to embrace a series of liberal causes, as the former vice president sought to unite the Democratic Party behind his presidential bid.
Mr. Sanders told reporters in Burlington, Vt., that Tuesday "was not a good night for our campaign." However, he said he still intended to debate the former vice president
Sunday in Phoenix
and press him on climate change, income inequality and more.
The Vermont senator touted the popularity of some of his ideas with Democrats but said his campaign often hears that voters see Mr. Biden as a better bet against President Trump in the November election.
"While our campaign has won the ideological debate, we are losing the debate over electability," Mr. Sanders said.
The frank assessment of his campaign came as Mr. Biden strengthened his pathway to the Democratic presidential nomination with his series of victories Tuesday.
Mr. Biden
won in the key battleground state of Michigan
and in Missouri, Mississippi and Idaho with a coalition of African-Americans, suburbanites and older voters. It was a further sign of Mr. Biden's surge in just a matter of weeks from a candidate who appeared headed for a third failed presidential bid to the delegate leader and front-runner. The wins also prompted calls from inside the party to unite around his candidacy and direct its full attention to Mr. Trump.
"Last night, Joe Biden expanded his coalition and continues to demonstrate he is the candidate who can unite the Democratic Party," T.J. Ducklo, a Biden campaign spokesman, said Wednesday. "Our campaign is focused on the task at hand: defeating Donald Trump, so we can make real, lasting progressive change in this country and in people's lives."
The former vice president's turnaround has reordered the contest for the Democratic nomination over the past few weeks and put pressure on Mr. Sanders to prove he has a viable path forward.
On Wednesday morning, Mr. Sanders was declared the winner of the North Dakota caucuses, while the two candidates were locked in a tight race in Washington state. With 67% of precincts reporting, each candidate had about a third of the vote in that state.
Tad Devine, the chief strategist of Mr. Sanders's 2016 campaign who most recently helped the presidential campaign of Andrew Yang, said in an interview he didn't see "a realistic pathway to the nomination" for Mr. Sanders.
More
*
Takeaways From Tuesday's Election Contests

*
Biden Notches Key Win in Michigan Primary

*
Tracking the Delegate Counts

"The question he has to confront this time, which was not on the play last time, is are you going to enable another four years of Donald Trump by participating in this process longer? And are you going to handicap Biden's ability to defeat Trump? That's a very big issue," said Mr. Devine, who noted he had not spoken to the senator since the last presidential bid.
Mr. Biden reached out to the Vermont senator's supporters Tuesday evening as he sought to position himself as a Democratic candidate the party could rally around.
"I want to thank Bernie Sanders and his supporters for their tireless energy and their passion," Mr. Biden said in Philadelphia. "We share a common goal and together, we'll defeat Donald Trump. We'll defeat him together."
Encouraged by Tuesday's results, Mr. Biden's allies began making plans for a monthslong battle against Mr. Trump. Unite the Country, a pro-Biden super PAC, said in a memo to supporters that "the functional primary phase of this election is over."
The group said it had raised nearly $10 million, "with triple that in commitments," during the past 10 days.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
How do you expect Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders to adjust their campaign strategies before their Sunday debate? Join the conversation below.
Mr. Biden's strong performance, after
winning 10 states just a week ago on Super Tuesday
, also spurred two deep-pocketed liberal groups to get behind him and say the general-election campaign against Mr. Trump was starting. Priorities USA and American Bridge had remained neutral throughout the primary.
"The math is now clear. Joe Biden is going to be the Democratic nominee for President and @prioritiesUSA is going to do everything we can to help him defeat Donald Trump in November," tweeted Priorities USA Chairman Guy Cecil just minutes before the Associated Press declared Mr. Biden the winner in the Michigan primary.
American Bridge announced a $2.2 million ad buy in Pennsylvania as it declared it was "all in" for Mr. Biden.
With those groups lining up behind Mr. Biden, Sunday's debate took on more importance, as it will be the first time the two men will go head-to-head.
Rep. Tim Ryan (D., Ohio), a Biden supporter, said on CNN that he would welcome a debate of ideas this weekend but cautioned that Mr. Sanders shouldn't use the opportunity to tear down Mr. Biden.
"I think at this point, trashing each other is not in the best interest of, not just the Democratic Party, but bringing some unity to this country," he said.
But Biden deputy campaign manager Kate Bedingfield said Wednesday on CNN that the campaign wouldn't tell Mr. Sanders what to do. Instead, she made an appeal to his supporters and young voters.
"I think there is a tremendous amount that we agree on, and I would say to Bernie Sanders supporters that if they're looking for a home, they've got one with Joe Biden," Ms. Bedingfield said.
Mr. Biden has presented himself as the Democrat best able to challenge Mr. Trump in general-election battlegrounds such as Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan, which was the first of those states to weigh in on the Democratic race. With 99% of precincts reporting, Mr. Biden had about 53% of the vote to about 37% for Mr. Sanders. Mr. Sanders narrowly defeated Hillary Clinton in the state in the 2016 nominating contest.
Mr. Biden was projected the winner in Mississippi, Missouri and Michigan shortly after the states' polls closed, an early sign of his clout in three states with large African-American voting blocs. Black voters made up about two-thirds of the electorate in Mississippi, exit polls showed. Mr. Biden had won more than 80% of support in the state, with about 98% of precincts reporting.
The former vice president campaigned ahead of the Missouri primary among African-Americans in St. Louis and Kansas City. With about 100% of precincts reporting, Mr. Biden had about 60% of the vote in Missouri.
Mr. Biden's delegate edge early Wednesday was 843 to 681 over Mr. Sanders, according to a Wall Street Journal delegate tracker, even as Super Tuesday states such as California and Colorado, which Mr. Sanders carried, continue to process election results.
The campaigns have competed for votes against the backdrop of growing economic concerns over the
spread of the coronavirus
. Both candidates have questioned Mr. Trump's handling of the crisis in recent days, and on Tuesday they each canceled rallies in Cleveland, ahead of Ohio's primary next week, citing public-health concerns.
In response to the threat of the virus, the Democratic National Committee also decided to
forgo an audience at Sunday's debate.

Mr. Biden's campaign announced Wednesday it had formed a health advisory committee of medical and national security experts to advise it on the steps it should take "to minimize health risks for the candidate, staff and supporters." Based on conversations with the committee and elected officials in Illinois and Florida, the campaign said it decided not to hold large gatherings in those states ahead of next week's primaries. Instead, the campaign will hold virtual events.
Mr. Biden is also expected to address the response to the novel coronavirus during remarks in Wilmington, Del., on Thursday.
Exit polls coming in with the results showed Mr. Biden winning handily among black and older voters and performing well with those who had at least a college degree. Mr. Biden was also prevailing in cities such as St. Louis, Kansas City and Detroit and in their surrounding areas—including Oakland County, Mich., a general-election battleground.
Mr. Sanders maintained a substantial advantage over Mr. Biden among young voters, exit polls showed. The Vermont senator staked much of his campaign on motivating the young as well as others disenchanted with current politics to come to the polls.
Sabrina Siddiqui and Eliza Collins in Burlington, Vt., contributed to this article.
Write to Chad Day at
Chad.Day@wsj.com
and Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com

title: Top Takeaways From Tuesday's House, Senate Primaries; House Democrats hope to maintain and expand on 2018 gains this fall; Republicans look to defend Senate majority
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—As former Vice President Joe Biden revived his presidential campaign with a
string of victories on Tuesday
, candidates in congressional primaries also advanced to the next round of voting in a number of closely watched contests.
House Democrats hope to maintain and even expand on the ground they gained in the 2018 midterm elections this fall, while Republicans aim to defend their 53-seat Senate majority.
Here are some top takeaways from last night's results:
Loyalty to Trump Remains Central to Success in GOP
Former Attorney General Jeff Sessions will advance to a March 31 runoff in the Republican primary race to win back his old Senate seat in Alabama. That election has become a contest of

fealty to President Trump
. Tommy Tuberville, the former Auburn University football head coach, will face Mr. Sessions in the runoff at the end of March.
Mr. Sessions has been the subject of ridicule from Mr. Trump over his decision to recuse himself from the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election. While he refrained from criticizing Mr. Sessions during the initial phase of the race, the president took to Twitter on Wednesday morning to attack him.
Mr. Sessions didn't "have the wisdom or courage to stare down & end the phony Russia Witch Hunt." The eventual Republican nominee will face Democratic Sen. Doug Jones, who won the Alabama Senate seat in 2017 by less than 2 percentage points after the Republican candidate, Roy Moore, was accused by several women of sexual misconduct.
In a congressional seat in the Houston area, a grandson of former President George H.W. Bush won't advance to a May 26 runoff in the Republican race to succeed Rep. Pete Olson (R., Texas), who is retiring after this term. Pierce Bush fell short against Troy Nehls, a county sheriff, and Kathaleen Wall, who spent heavily to broadcast support for building a border wall.
Mr. Trump's endorsement of Ronny Jackson, formerly the White House physician, helped carry him to a runoff in another Texas congressional district. But Mr. Jackson still trailed the lead Republican, Josh Winegarner, 38.9% to 19.8% in the crowded primary to succeed Rep. Mac Thornberry (R., Texas).
Incumbents Survive Primary Challenges
Rep. Kay Granger (R., Texas), the top Republican on the House Appropriations Committee, survived a primary challenge backed by heavy outside spending. She faced a conservative challenger, Chris Putnam, who had attacked her as a Washington insider insufficiently supportive of President Trump.
The race had pit several outside conservative groups against each other, with the political wing of the conservative Club For Growth spending heavily to oppose Ms. Granger. The Congressional Leadership Fund, a super political-action committee affiliated with House GOP leadership, spent more than $1.3 million defending Ms. Granger.
Further south in Texas, Rep. Henry Cuellar (D., Texas) narrowly beat Jessica Cisneros, a 26-year-old who has
criticized Mr. Cuellar as too conservative
and who received financial support from several national groups, the Associated Press projected.
Several other incumbents in both the House and Senate facing challengers emerged from Tuesday unscathed.
Senate Democrats' Favored Candidates Advance
In North Carolina, Cal Cunningham, a former state lawmaker and Army veteran, won the Democratic nomination to run against Republican Sen. Thom Tillis this fall. Mr. Cunningham had the support of national Democrats, and national Republicans ran advertisements boosting one of Mr. Cunningham's competitors in the primary.
North Carolina will be one of a handful of deeply competitive Senate races this fall, with Democrats hoping to also compete in a number of other states that have traditionally leaned more conservative.
Related
*
Michael Bloomberg Ends Presidential Bid and Endorses Joe Biden

*
Where the Democratic Presidential Race Goes From Here

*
The Top Takeaways From Super Tuesday

*
Down-Ballot Democrats Turn to Joe Biden

*
Moderate Democrats Consolidate Around Biden Ahead of Super Tuesday

*
Congressional Primaries to Watch on Super Tuesday

In Texas, Senate candidate M.J. Hegar is set to advance to a May 26 runoff in the Democratic primary, though whom she will face in the next contest is still unclear. Like Mr. Cunningham, Ms. Hegar has the support of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. She will aim to take on Republican Sen. John Cornyn, one of the top Republicans in the Senate, after Sen. Ted Cruz (R., Texas) narrowly beat back a Democratic challenge in 2018.
House Republicans Efforts to Improve Diversity See Gains
Republican efforts to recruit more women and people of color as candidates got a boost on Tuesday. Lynda Bennett, who won the endorsement of Rep. Mark Meadows (R., N.C.), will move on to the runoff in the race to succeed Mr. Meadows, who is stepping down from the seat.
Wesley Hunt, an African-American Army veteran, won the Republican nomination in a Houston-area congressional district. He will face Rep. Lizzie Fletcher (D., Texas), who flipped the seat in 2018.
Top Republicans, including House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, had singled out Mr. Hunt as an example of the type of candidate Republicans need to recruit to gain back ground in suburban areas in 2020. National Republicans had hoped Mr. Hunt would be able to avoid a runoff in a seat seen as a bellwether for GOP efforts to regain support in 2020.
Write to Andrew Duehren at
andrew.duehren@wsj.com

title: Primaries Go Forward as Voters Face Coronavirus; Polls suggest Joe Biden is poised to dominate the day's voting
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
The first primary elections since
the coronavirus pandemic
engulfed the nation were winding down Tuesday in Florida and Illinois and continuing in Arizona as candidates, voters and election officials tried to navigate a new and challenging environment.

Polls indicated former Vice President Joe Biden was poised to dominate
the day's voting
, potentially adding significantly to his delegate advantage over Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders in a Democratic presidential nomination race that appeared to be winding down.

Ohio 

pushed back a primary
scheduled for Tuesday because of concerns about the virus, joining a growing list of states that have delayed their contests until May or June in hopes the situation will improve.

On the eve of the balloting, an Ohio court rejected a request to postpone the state's primary until June 2 as Republican Gov. Mike DeWine had recommended. The in-person voting was subsequently placed on hold after the state's top health official ordered polls closed.

The Ohio Supreme Court denied a last-minute legal challenge to the postponement, and county election boards were deluged with phone calls from confused, frustrated voters.

In a statement released late Tuesday, Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez called for states with upcoming primaries and caucuses to use vote by mail and other alternatives to casting ballots in person.

"What happened in Ohio last night has only bred more chaos and confusion," he said. "States that have not yet held primary elections should focus on implementing the aforementioned measures to make it easier and safer for voters to exercise their constitutional right to vote, instead of moving primaries to later in the cycle when timing around the virus remains unpredictable."

If the former vice president performs well, he could have a majority of the delegates awarded so far and more than half of the 1,991 needed to win the nomination.

A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released Sunday showed
Mr. Biden was favored nationally, 61% to 32%
, among those who have already voted in the Democratic primary or plan to do so.

Mr. Biden has already begun trying to unify the party behind him, endorsing policy proposals related to bankruptcy laws and college tuition
in a bid to woo liberals
. Mr. Sanders acknowledged last week that he was losing the "debate over electability" among Democratic voters. He could face more pressure to get out of the race if Mr. Biden has a strong showing Tuesday so that the party can focus on competing against President Trump in November.

Florida and Arizona are battleground states, so they may offer some insights into possible general-election trends. This round of contests might be the last significant ones for some time, if more states announce primary postponements.

States that move their contests later than June 9 will need a waiver from the party to avoid losing delegates to the July convention, the DNC wrote in a memo this week.

Voters, sobered by the crisis, also cast ballots in local and state contests as they confronted school closures, travel limitations, event cancellations and a stressed global economy. Germs were also on their minds.

At a polling location inside a Miami fire station, workers wore gloves as they inspected voter identification cards and dispensed hand sanitizer to the visitors. Some voters arrived with their own pens, gloves and disinfecting wipes.

Officials in Chicago, the biggest city within the three states that voted Tuesday, said election-day turnout was running extremely low as nervous voters stayed home. Still, many had cast ballots early. Officials said the previous primary record for such voting was easily surpassed and vote-by-mail applications more than tripled compared with 2016.

James Allen, a Chicago Board of Election Commissioners spokesman, told reporters Tuesday that city election officials failed last week to convince Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker to cancel in-person voting and replace it with vote-by-mail balloting.

That triggered a critical response from Mr. Pritzker's office. Spokeswoman Jordan Abudayyeh said in a statement that the governor's office had offered "to provide the National Guard to help staff the election" as well as assistance in recruiting volunteers to fill in for election workers anxious about staffing polling places.

"The governor cannot unilaterally cancel or delay an election," she said. "Elections are the cornerstone of our democracy and we could not risk confusion and disenfranchisement in the courts. No one is saying this is a perfect solution. We have no perfect solutions at the moment. We only have the least bad solutions."

Some Chicago polls opened late because workers didn't show up or equipment wasn't delivered on time, while some voters were confused about where they were supposed to vote after about 200 of the city's 2,069 precinct voting locations had to be moved.

Voting-rights advocates said they fielded questions from confused voters and poll workers in multiple states because of changes made to polling locations to avoid nursing homes and other vulnerable sites.

"It's unprecedented for us to be addressing this much confusion around basic questions that voters have during a primary election, like where is my polling place," Ami Gandhi, senior counsel at the Chicago Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights, told reporters.

Share Your Thoughts


What results do you expect from Tuesday's primaries, and why? Join the conversation below.

She said there has been a lack of guidance for people who are homebound as a result of coronavirus concerns. "Those who live in nursing homes or other similar facilities who no longer have the option of voting in their residence are really in a tough situation," Ms. Gandhi said.

More than half of state primaries and caucuses have been held, and turnout was trending higher before the outbreak pushed people back into their homes to try to slow the spread of the virus.

"I would guess that the election-day component of the turnout may be down," said David Hopkins, a political-science professor at Boston College.

Voting, like virtually every aspect of the presidential race, has been transformed by the outbreak.

The large rallies that for a year fueled Mr. Sanders's campaign have been replaced by online appearances transmitted into the homes of cloistered supporters. Mr. Biden is restructuring his fundraising operation, which had previously leveraged in-person events. Uncertainty remains about how campaigning will be affected for the general election.

Mike Casca, a spokesman for Mr. Sanders, said in an emailed statement Tuesday that the campaign wasn't conducting its usual get-out-the-vote efforts.

"We are making clear to voters that we believe going to the polls amid the coronavirus outbreak is a personal decision and we respect whichever choice they make," he said. "We are also passing along guidance from the CDC on staying safe during the crisis."

Unlike previous events held on the eve of primaries, Mr. Sanders during a virtual rally Monday evening didn't ask his supporters to vote for him. Mr. Biden tweeted Tuesday that people should "vote by mail or curbside vote if you can. If you vote in person, please wash your hands, don't touch your face, and stay 6' from others in line."

The crisis and postponement of state contests later in March and early April makes it especially hard for Mr. Sanders to gain ground on Mr. Biden, Mr. Hopkins said.

"The race has sort of been frozen in place," he said. "If he wants to stay in the race, there isn't going to be much of a race for a while."

WSJ Newsletter


Get an early-morning coronavirus briefing each weekday, plus a health-news update Fridays:
Sign up here.

 Eliza Collins, Alexa Corse and Arian Campo-Flores contributed to this article.

title: Democrats Sharpen Criticism of Trump's Health-Care Policy in Coronavirus Pandemic; Trump administration's changes to Affordable Care Act are targets on campaign trail and in political ads
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
The coronavirus pandemic is jolting the political debate over health care in the 2020 election campaign, with Democrats arguing the crisis shows the damage the Trump administration has done to the health-care safety net and the need for a larger federal role in providing coverage.
Health care was already a top issue for voters before the virus began spreading in the U.S. Now, with cases across 46 states and Washington, D.C., coronavirus is providing a platform for Democrats to highlight high medical costs and a lack of coverage, which they say their policy proposals would fix. Democratic presidential candidates are expected to criticize President Trump's response to the virus at Sunday night's debate.
Trump administration officials counter that they have expanded access to more affordable health-care plans. The Trump re-election campaign has sought to criticize some of the most polarizing aspects of the Democratic rivals' health plans, such as coverage for undocumented immigrants. "Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden are two sides of the same extreme coin," the Trump re-election campaign tweeted on March 6. "They both support making American families and workers pay for health care for illegal aliens."
Democrats argue that the Trump administration's changes to the Affordable Care Act have weakened coverage for millions of Americans, and could leave people who need treatment for coronavirus with high health-care bills. They point to the expansion of health plans that can deny coverage and don't have to cover all of the ACA's minimum benefits, as well as an administration plan to back states that want to change Medicaid's open-ended federal funding into a more limited block grant that Democrats say would hurt enrollment.
Republicans have praised the administration's response and actions they say the White House has taken to make health coverage more affordable. They have accused Democrats of using coronavirus to score political points.
Rep. Mark Meadows (R., N.C.), who is set to be Mr. Trump's chief of staff, in a Feb. 25 tweet said that "the left wants to control: your health care."
References to the coronavirus have recently started to appear in political advertising, as groups aligned with Democrats try to leverage the topic.
A TV ad that mentions the virus and is critical of Republican Sen. Steve Daines first appeared in Montana on Thursday, data from ad-tracking firm Kantar/CMAG shows. The spot is sponsored by Protect Our Care, a group that supports the Affordable Care Act.
"Too many Montana families go to sleep at night worried about health care, coverage, costs and now the fear of coronavirus," says the ad, which had run 29 times in Billings and Missoula through Thursday.
"It's absolutely going to be a topic," said Ken Goldstein, a University of San Francisco political-science professor who has studied campaign advertising for decades. "The question for campaigns and strategists and ad makers is how you make it a topic and when you make it a topic."
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
How might a Democratic health-care plan benefit Americans during a health crisis? Join the conversation below.
At a time when Americans have many concerns related to the outbreak on their minds, he said, running political ads now on the outbreak has advantages and disadvantages.
"It may not be the best time to inject political messages," Mr. Goldstein said. "On the other hand, people are going to be watching a lot of television and be on the internet and seeing ads. We are about to see record internet usage, video usage and TV ratings."
Democratic presidential candidates are on the offensive on the campaign trail. Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, a proponent of Medicare for All, said at a March 9 rally that the coronavirus outbreak shows the "insanity" of a system where people can't afford to see a doctor.
Former Vice President Joe Biden, who has pushed his own plan that would expand the ACA and add an option for people to buy into a federal health plan, blamed Mr. Trump for taking steps to weaken the U.S. health system.
"Protecting the health and safety of the American people is the most important job of any president—and unfortunately, this virus laid bare the severe shortcomings of the current administration," Mr. Biden said Thursday. "Our government's ability to respond effectively has been undermined by the hollowing-out of our agencies and the disparagement of science. "
Billionaire and former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg was among the first to use the virus in TV ads as part of a political campaign. He ran two different spots on the topic, including one that was three minutes long, before he dropped out of the Democratic presidential primary.
Support for the ACA grew to 55% of Americans in February, the highest since the law was enacted 10 years ago, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation. The support is also up from 51% in October, before coronavirus cases emerged in the U.S.
The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee ran digital ads critical of Trump officials who initially declined to ensure that any vaccine would be affordable. House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy of California criticized the ads as playing politics with coronavirus.
The criticisms tap into a growing public angst about the virus and the administration's response.
"People see Trump making it easier for them to get coronavirus and then harder for them to get health care," said Jesse Ferguson, a Democratic strategist. "That seems like a challenging agenda to sell to voters."
According to a Quinnipiac University poll released on March 9, 49% of voters disapprove of the way Mr. Trump is handling the coronavirus response, while 43% approve,
There are sharp divides along political parties, similar to the president's overall job approval rating: 87% of Republicans approve, 83% of Democrats disapprove, and 50% of independents disapprove.

title: U.S. News: Sanders Stays In Race, Biden Urges Unity
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Sen. Bernie Sanders, facing a shrinking path to the Democratic presidential nomination, made a case for continuing in the 2020 race as front-running rival Joe Biden sought to unite the party behind his candidacy.
Mr. Sanders said on Wednesday he intended to participate in a scheduled debate Sunday in Phoenix, where he said he would press the former vice president to move in a more liberal policy direction on issues such as health care and college affordability. The senator from Vermont also offered a frank assessment of his chances a day after Mr. Biden strengthened his bid for the nomination with victories in Tuesday's contests, most notably a blowout in Michigan.
The previous evening "was not a good night for our campaign," Mr. Sanders said in Burlington, Vt. He said his campaign often hears on the trail that voters see Mr. Biden as a better bet against President Trump in November, even as some of Mr. Sanders's progressive policy ideas are popular among Democrats.
"While our campaign has won the ideological debate, we are losing the debate over electability," Mr. Sanders said.
Mr. Biden won in Michigan by 17 percentage points over Mr. Sanders, and he also scored victories in Missouri, Mississippi and Idaho with a coalition of African-Americans, suburbanites and older voters. It was a further sign of Mr. Biden's surge in a matter of weeks from a candidate who appeared headed for a third failed presidential bid to the delegate leader and front-runner. The wins also prompted calls from inside the party to unite around his candidacy and direct its full attention to defeating Mr. Trump, a Republican.
"Last night, Joe Biden expanded his coalition and continues to demonstrate he is the candidate who can unite the Democratic Party," T.J. Ducklo, a Biden campaign spokesman, said Wednesday.
The former vice president's turnaround has reordered the contest for the Democratic nomination over the past few weeks and put pressure on Mr. Sanders to prove he has a viable path forward.
On Wednesday morning, Mr. Sanders was declared the winner in North Dakota, while the candidates were locked in a tight race in Washington state.
Tad Devine, the chief strategist of Mr. Sanders's 2016 campaign who most recently helped the presidential campaign of Andrew Yang, said in an interview he didn't see "a realistic pathway to the nomination" for Mr. Sanders.
"The question he has to confront this time, which was not on the play last time, is: Are you going to enable another four years of Donald Trump by participating in this process longer? And are you going to handicap Biden's ability to defeat Trump? That's a very big issue," said Mr. Devine, who noted he hadn't spoken to the senator since the last presidential bid.
Mr. Biden addressed the senator's supporters Tuesday evening as he sought to position himself as the candidate the party could rally around.
"I want to thank Bernie Sanders and his supporters for their tireless energy and their passion," Mr. Biden said in Philadelphia. "We share a common goal and together, we'll defeat Donald Trump. We'll defeat him together."
Encouraged by Tuesday's results, Mr. Biden's allies began making plans for a monthslong battle against Mr. Trump.
Unite the Country, a pro-Biden super PAC, said in a memo to supporters that "the functional primary phase of this election is over."
The group said it had raised nearly $10 million, "with triple that in commitments," during the past 10 days.
Mr. Biden's strong performance, after winning 10 states a week ago on Super Tuesday, also spurred two deep-pocketed liberal groups to get behind him and say the general-election campaign against Mr. Trump was starting. Priorities USA and American Bridge had remained neutral throughout the primary.
With those groups lining up behind Mr. Biden, Sunday's debate took on more importance as it will be the first time the two men will go head-to-head.
Rep. Tim Ryan (D., Ohio), a Biden supporter, said on CNN that he would welcome a debate of ideas this weekend but cautioned that Mr. Sanders shouldn't use the opportunity to tear down Mr. Biden.
"I think at this point, trashing each other is not in the best interest of, not just the Democratic Party, but bringing some unity to this country," he said.
Biden deputy campaign manager Kate Bedingfield said Wednesday on CNN that the campaign wouldn't tell Mr. Sanders what to do. Instead, she made an appeal to his supporters and young voters.
"I think there is a tremendous amount that we agree on, and I would say to Bernie Sanders supporters that if they're looking for a home, they've got one with Joe Biden," Ms. Bedingfield said.
Mr. Biden's edge over Mr. Sanders in convention delegates was 861 to 710 Wednesday afternoon, according to a Wall Street Journal tracker. The Biden campaign suggested in a memo Wednesday night that it may have a lead of more than 300 delegates over Mr. Sanders after next week's primaries in four states.
"Should our broad base of support remain. . .it will be nearly impossible for Sanders to recoup his current delegate disadvantage," the campaign said. The Sanders campaign didn't respond to the memo.
The campaigns have competed for votes against the backdrop of growing concerns over the spread of the coronavirus. Both candidates have questioned Mr. Trump's handling of the crisis, and on Tuesday they each canceled rallies in Cleveland.
---
Sabrina Siddiqui and Eliza Collins contributed to this article.

title: Joe Biden's Primary Wins Show Limits of Campaign Cash; His successes at polls came despite rivals' large war chests, new fundraising reports show; familiarity with voters played big role
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Just a few weeks ago, Joe Biden was fresh off a primary win in South Carolina but had raised less than half as much campaign cash in February as the Democratic presidential front-runner at the time, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.
Big-money groups had sprung up in February to help two of Mr. Biden's 2020 competitors, and another, Michael Bloomberg, gave his own campaign almost half a billion dollars during the month to gin up support for his long-shot bid.
Three days into March, none of that would matter. Mr. Biden followed up South Carolina with a winning spree, and almost all other Democratic presidential candidates quickly dropped out. The former vice president's only remaining rival, Mr. Sanders, faces an unlikely path to the nomination.
New presidential fundraising reports filed with the Federal Election Commission late Friday reveal the extent of the campaign cash disparity just before the Democratic nomination contest narrowed to a two-person race. And they offer the latest evidence that money—whether a multibillion-dollar personal fortune or fount of small donations online—isn't as important in presidential primaries as familiarity.
"The thing that Joe Biden had from the beginning that most of the rest of the candidates didn't was name recognition and brand recognition," said Addisu Demissie, who was New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker's presidential campaign manager until he ended his run in January. "There are so many residual benefits to being that well-known that money can't buy."
"It isn't a coincidence that the final two candidates are the former vice president and the runner-up in the last presidential election," Mr. Demissie said, pointing out that the Vermont senator also began the race as a widely known figure.
The eventual Democratic nominee will face a financially formidable Republican opponent, President Trump. Combined with the Republican National Committee and connected fundraising committees, the president's re-election effort brought in $86 million in February and ended the month with about $225 million in the bank, according to the RNC.
Despite his firm footing for re-election, Mr. Trump—who on March 17 officially locked up the Republican nomination—was financially overmatched in the Republican primary four years ago, and his campaign spent about $242 million
less than Democratic nominee
Hillary Clinton's did in 2016.
A reality television star before he became a politician, Mr. Trump enjoyed wide media coverage and name recognition during the 2016 campaign. That helped offset his need to spend big on TV advertising, political strategists said.
Mr. Biden had a national profile from decades in the U.S. Senate and as President Obama's No. 2., and he enjoyed the strong support of black Democrats in South Carolina and in states that voted in March. But his fundraising lagged behind that of several of his key rivals.
Mr. Biden's February finance reports offer a snapshot of how dire his cash situation was before he overtook Mr. Sanders to become the party's front-runner. Mr. Biden's campaign raised $18 million in February, about half of the $35 million his campaign says it has raised so far in March amid his winning streak.
In February, Mr. Sanders, who has shunned large donors who power many other campaigns, set a personal fundraising record by collecting almost $48 million.
The Biden campaign spent $13 million that month, when the other major candidates accepting donations in the race spent almost $100 million collectively. That doesn't include Mr. Bloomberg, whose campaign spent $467 million in February.
Mr. Bloomberg picked up a disappointingly small number of delegates out of his $935 million overall investment. Still, some of Mr. Bloomberg's wealth will be helping the party's eventual nominee. On Friday, he said
he would transfer
$18 million from his presidential bid to the Democratic National Committee.
Much like the Republican primary in 2016, super PACs spending millions of dollars also appeared to have little effect on the race. The new filings Friday revealed that Persist PAC, which backed Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, was largely funded by physician and Silicon Valley philanthropist Karla Jurvetson.
Dr. Jurvetson donated $14.6 million of the $15.1 million the group raised in the 11 days it operated in February. The bulk of that money went to TV advertising as the super PAC tried to help Ms. Warren revive her campaign after disappointing finishes in Iowa and New Hampshire.
The Massachusetts senator had centered her campaign on denouncing what she saw as the corrupting influence of money in politics and had criticized the use of such super PACs by the wealthy. But as her campaign struggled, Ms. Warren
accepted the help
, calling it a political necessity.
Ultimately, it didn't make much of a difference. Ms. Warren dropped out of the presidential race on March 5 after failing to win a caucus or primary.
Write to Chad Day at
Chad.Day@wsj.com
and Julie Bykowicz at
julie.bykowicz@wsj.com

title: Facebook to Keep Targeted Political Ads but Give Users More Control; The social-media giant breaks with other tech firms, says regulators—not companies—should rule on political ads
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
In a break with other tech companies, Facebook Inc. said it wouldn't limit how political advertising targets potential voters, but would instead give users tools to see fewer of those ads on its platforms.
Facebook's stance—that companies shouldn't decide how campaigns are able to reach voters—is at odds with other tech firms' approach to handling political advertising in the run-up to the 2020 election.
Operators of online platforms are under increasing pressure to curb the spread of misleading or false information in the wake of the 2016 presidential campaign, which U.S. intelligence agencies have said was subject to foreign meddling online.
Facebook's announcement Thursday highlighted the divide in opinion on what the company's role should be in elections, as critics—including some Democratic presidential candidates—said the latest decision leaves the door wide open for disinformation.
Share Your Thoughts
What limits to political ads would you want to put on your own Facebook account, if any? Join the conversation below.
Facebook has acknowledged that the spread of disinformation, including through targeted ads, is a problem and has expressed a desire for federal regulation of political advertising online. But its announcement in September that it would exempt politicians' and certain other ads from its third-party fact-checking program fed skepticism about its commitment to combating disinformation on its platform.
The company based its latest decision "on the principle that people should be able to hear from those who wish to lead them, warts and all, and that what they say should be scrutinized and debated in public," according to a blog post from Rob Leathern, Facebook's director of product management. "This does not mean that politicians can say whatever they like in advertisements on Facebook."
The post said all Facebook users have to follow its community standards, which ban hate speech, harmful content and content designed to intimidate voters or stop them from exercising their right to vote.
The company's announcement Thursday also included changes that Facebook said will boost transparency in its ad library relating to how political advertisers deploy their messages on its platforms.
Facebook's approach, including giving users more control over what they see,
contrasts with moves
by Twitter Inc. and Alphabet Inc.'s Google.
Google earlier this week launched its new policy globally barring advertisers from targeting political messages based on users' interests inferred from their browsing or search histories, among other changes. Twitter stopped accepting most political ads in November.
Facebook acknowledged it considered restricting targeting but ultimately chose not to do so.
The Wall Street Journal previously reported Facebook was weighing, among other steps, raising the minimum number of people who can be targeted in political ads on its platform from 100 to a few thousand. The practice
known as microtargeting
has been criticized for enabling political actors to single out groups for misleading or false ads that aren't exposed to broader public scrutiny.
Facebook said its data showed more than 85% of ad spending by U.S. presidential candidates is for messages aimed at an audience of more than 250,000 people.
The social-media giant said it consulted with a number of nonprofits, political groups and election campaigns—both Democratic and Republican—before reaching its decision.
"Ultimately, we don't think decisions about political ads should be made by private companies, which is why we are arguing for regulation that would apply across the industry," Mr. Leathern said, echoing comments Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg has made about the need for federal regulation of political advertising.
Reaction to Facebook's latest decision again showed divergent opinions on how the company should treat political ads.
Trump campaign spokesman Tim Murtaugh said Facebook's decision not to limit targeting allows more Americans to be involved in politics. In any case, he said, there is no escaping political messaging.
"If users do elect to see fewer political ads it still won't stop them from being bombarded by ads from the news media, which are biased and just as political, because there's a loophole in the rule for the media," Mr. Murtaugh said.
Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D., Minn.) criticized Facebook's decision. "Facebook is doubling down on a policy that hurts our democracy," the presidential candidate said in a statement that reiterated her call for
comprehensive federal rules
on digital political ads.
The campaign of Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden also was critical of the company. "Today's announcement is more window dressing around their decision to allow paid misinformation," said campaign spokesman Bill Russo.
Tara McGowan, chief executive of Acronym, a progressive nonprofit that tracks political-ad spending among other work, said she largely agreed with Facebook's move to not limit political targeting but hopes the company does more to rein in misinformation and hate speech.
Roughly $3 billion is expected to be spent on political advertising online for the 2020 U.S. election. But with Election Day less than a year away, a lack of uniform rules for the ads has led to confusion about exactly what is allowed on digital platforms, how intensely new policies will be enforced and whether
advertising strategies and budgets
will need to change further.
Watchdogs, including lawmakers and advocacy groups, have called for greater oversight of political advertising following revelations that
Russian entities purchased digital ads
designed to influence the 2016 presidential election.
Facebook's announcement comes two days after the New York Times reported on an internal post by Facebook executive Andrew Bosworth, in which he said he believed the platform played a central role in the 2016 presidential election.
"So was Facebook responsible for Donald Trump getting elected? I think the answer is yes, but not for the reasons anyone thinks. He didn't get elected because of Russia or misinformation or Cambridge Analytica. He got elected because he ran the single best digital ad campaign I've ever seen from any advertiser. Period," Mr. Bosworth wrote.
Facebook said seeing fewer political and social-issue ads was a common request from users and that it aims to roll out its new user-control feature in the U.S. early this summer on its main platform and on Instagram. It will later expand to other locations. Other features aimed at increasing ad transparency will launch in the current quarter.
Facebook said while its users have been able to hide all messages from a specific advertiser in their ad preferences, they soon will be able to stop seeing ads based on how an advertiser constructed its list of targeted users.
In addition, users will be able to opt in to see messages that are directed at a group that didn't automatically include them.
Efforts to block political advertising likely wouldn't have a large impact on Facebook's top line. In October Mr. Zuckerberg said on an earnings call he estimated political ads would account for less than 0.5% of the company's total revenue in 2020.
Related
*
Political Ads Are Flourishing Online. Few Agree How to Regulate Them.

*
Facebook Weighs Steps to Curb Narrowly Targeted Political Ads

Write to Emily Glazer at
emily.glazer@wsj.com
