title: Key Swing Senator, Lamar Alexander, to Vote Against New Witnesses in Impeachment Trial; Another GOP swing vote, Sen. Susan Collins, said she would vote in favor of hearing new testimony
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—A Republican senator who party leaders feared might join Democrats in seeking new testimony said Thursday night he will vote against calling witnesses, bolstering the GOP's chances of bringing the
impeachment trial of President Trump
to a rapid conclusion.
Sen. Lamar Alexander (R., Tenn.) announced his plan after senators wrapped their second and
final day of questioning
Mr. Trump's legal team and House Democratic impeachment managers, during which the two sides sparred over the
limits of executive and congressional power
while revealing little new information.
Mr. Alexander said he believed that Democrats proved their core allegation that Mr.
Trump withheld aid from Ukraine
to pressure Kyiv to launch investigations into former Vice President Joe Biden and his son. But he said those actions, while inappropriate, didn't merit the president's removal from office, and therefore no witnesses were needed.
"There is no need for more evidence to prove something that has already been proven and that does not meet the U.S. Constitution's high bar for an impeachable offense," Mr.
Alexander tweeted
.
Mr. Alexander had notified Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) of his decision before announcing it. Mr. McConnell, leaving the Capitol on Thursday, said only: "Tomorrow's a big day."
Another GOP swing vote, Sen. Susan Collins of Maine, said she would vote in favor of hearing new testimony, saying that hearing from witnesses would allow each side "to more fully and fairly make their case, resolve any ambiguities and provide additional clarity." But Democrats need four Republicans to join them for the vote to be successful.
While Mr. Alexander's decision doesn't mean Republicans are certain to have enough votes to block new testimony, it suggests the GOP is in a good position ahead of Friday's vote, which is likely to pave the way for Mr. Trump's swift acquittal. Mr. Alexander, who was spotted reading Jon Meacham's "Impeachment: An American History" in the Senate chamber earlier Thursday, had remained silent over the course of the week about how he might vote.
In addition to Ms. Collins, Sen. Mitt Romney (R., Utah) has said he is interested in hearing from witnesses. And Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R., Alaska) said late Thursday she is still on the fence.
On Tuesday, Mr. McConnell told Republicans they didn't yet have the
votes to block the measure
. In the days since, Republicans have expressed more confidence.
At Thursday's GOP lunch, Mr. McConnell didn't disclose where the vote count on witnesses stood, and Republican leaders said they didn't yet know what Friday would bring. "It's going to be very, very close," Sen. Mike Braun (R., Ind.) said.
Some Republican senators are suggesting that if they succeed in blocking witnesses on Friday, they will push to end the trial that night, even if that means a vote to acquit Mr. Trump could occur in the wee hours of the morning on Saturday.
Meanwhile, preparing for the possibility of a defeat on the witness vote, Democrats are exploring parliamentary maneuvers that they could use to fight such an abrupt end to the trial and draw attention to what they consider an unfair process.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
What are your biggest takeaways from the impeachment Q&A? Why? Join the conversation below.
House Democrats over two days of questioning focused on the need for the chamber to call new witnesses—in particular, Mr. Trump's former national security adviser John Bolton. On Sunday,
a draft was leaked of Mr. Bolton's forthcoming book
, in which he wrote that Mr. Trump told him he was freezing security aid to Ukraine until it opened investigations into Mr. Joe Biden, a leading Democratic presidential candidate, and other matters.
Mr. Bolton has said
he would testify if subpoenaed
by the Senate. The Republican president has denied Mr. Bolton's account and has called the impeachment case against him a hoax.
Ms. Murkowski, in a question posed to the president's legal team, said the dispute over Mr. Bolton's book "weighs in favor of calling additional witnesses" and asked why the Senate shouldn't call Mr. Bolton, suggesting she was leaning toward voting for new testimony.
But later, she and Mr. Alexander signed on to a question asking, Even if the reports of the contents of Mr. Bolton's book were accurate, "isn't it true that the allegations would still not rise to an impeachable offense?" The Trump defense team agreed.
Democrats argued witnesses were central to the trial process.
"God forbid we should hear what a relevant witness has to say," said Rep. Adam Schiff (D., Calif.), the lead House manager and chairman of the chamber's Intelligence Committee. He proposed limiting witness testimony to one week, responding to concerns from Republicans and some Democrats about prolonging the trial with new testimony and the court battles that could ensue from any new subpoenas. The presidential nomination contests begin on Monday in Iowa.
Democrats have argued that Mr. Trump was trying to cheat in this year's election. Mr. Trump's lawyers tried to turn the tables on Democrats, accusing them of using impeachment to interfere in this year's vote. "That is the most massive election interference in our history," said White House counsel Pat Cipollone, echoing a tweet by Mr. Trump days earlier. "Let's leave it to the people of the United States."
Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, on Thursday played down the possibility that Chief Justice John Roberts, who is presiding over the trial, could step in to break a 50-50 tie over calling witnesses. Mr. Schumer said Democrats remain focused on getting to 51 votes. It isn't clear how Mr. Roberts would handle a 50-50 tally, and the Senate rules are silent on the matter.
Thursday's session began on a dramatic note as the chief justice declined to read a question submitted by Sen. Rand Paul (R., Ky.) that included the name of a person identified by some people as the anonymous whistleblower who helped set off the impeachment inquiry. The whistleblower's lawyer hasn't confirmed the person's name.
Mr. Trump's lawyers used Thursday to try to challenge basic elements of Democrats' impeachment case. Deputy White House counsel Pat Philbin argued that on a July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, Mr. Trump wasn't asking "specifically for an investigation" into Mr. Biden and his son Hunter. A rough transcript of the call released by the White House shows that Mr. Trump asked his Ukrainian counterpart to look into the Bidens, saying "whatever you can do with the Attorney General would be great."
Mr. Trump and his allies have alleged that it was corrupt for the elder Mr. Biden during the Obama administration to seek the ouster of a Ukrainian prosecutor who had once investigated a Ukrainian gas company where his son sat on the board. Mr. Biden sought the prosecutor's removal as part of a broad international effort to combat corruption in Ukraine. The Bidens have denied any wrongdoing, though Hunter Biden has said it was poor judgment to serve on the Burisma board, which paid him $50,000 a month, while his father was involved with Ukraine policy as vice president.
Mr. Philbin also argued that "the evidence just doesn't stack up" to show Mr. Trump linked aid or a White House meeting to Ukraine opening investigations. But he didn't address the possibility of testimony by Mr. Bolton, who, based on his leaked manuscript, could offer such evidence.
Thursday's session also renewed focus on the activities in Ukraine of Rudy Giuliani, Mr. Trump's personal lawyer. In response to a question from a bipartisan group of senators—including two Republicans who have indicated they may vote in favor of new testimony—about whether Mr. Trump could assure the nation he wouldn't direct private citizens such as Mr. Giuliani to carry out foreign policy without a formal designation, Mr. Philbin replied: "I want to make clear that there was no conduct of foreign policy being carried out here by a private person."
That is sharply at odds with testimony House investigators heard in the fall. Several witnesses testified that Mr. Trump directed administration officials to work with Mr. Giuliani, who doesn't hold an official position, on resolving his concerns about Ukraine before he would agree to a meeting with the new Ukrainian president. State Department officials periodically reached out to Mr. Giuliani to ensure they were giving the new Ukrainian administration the proper messages to satisfy Mr. Giuliani's concerns.
Mr. Schiff called the assertion "startling." He noted that the president's lawyers have argued that critics of Mr. Trump's dealings with Ukraine objected to his policy, not his conduct. "They have now acknowledged that the person in charge of this was not conducting policy," Mr. Schiff said.
Democrats also tangled with the president's legal team on Thursday over a controversial theory raised a day earlier by Trump lawyer Alan Dershowitz: that because Mr. Trump believes his re-election is in the public interest, even if he had political motivations in pressing Ukraine to open an investigation into the Bidens, it wouldn't be impeachable.
"What we have seen over the last couple days is a descent into constitutional madness," Mr. Schiff said.
Mr. Dershowitz wasn't present for Thursday's session. On Twitter, he clarified his remarks, saying a president's lawful behavior couldn't "be turned into a criminal or impeachable offense just because it was motivated in part by electoral considerations."
Related Coverage
*
Live Coverage of Trump's Impeachment Trial

*
Trial Offers Hints on Where Senators Stand on Witnesses

*
White House Says John Bolton's Manuscript Can't Be Published As Is

*
Where Things Stand in the Trump Impeachment Trial—and What's Next

*
Sen. Collins's Focused Approach Could Help Alter Impeachment Trial

*
Six Days in the Senate: How Democrats, Trump Team Tried the Impeachment Case

Democratic House managers, acting as prosecutors, are arguing that senators should convict Mr. Trump for abusing his power by withholding nearly $400 million in U.S. military aid to Ukraine as leverage for the country to open investigations that would aid his re-election efforts. The aid was ultimately released under bipartisan pressure from Congress. The House managers also accuse Mr. Trump of trying to cover up his alleged misconduct by obstructing congressional investigations into the matter. Mr. Trump has denied any wrongdoing.
Ms. Collins, along with a handful of other senators, on Thursday asked Democrats whether there were legitimate circumstances under which a president could ask a foreign country to investigate a U.S. citizen—including a political rival—who wasn't under investigation by the U.S.
"It would be hard to contemplate circumstances where that's appropriate," Mr. Schiff responded. Mr. Philbin said it was legitimate for the president to ask for a foreign investigation into a matter where a U.S. citizen broke the law abroad.
Andrew Duehren and Natalie Andrews contributed to this article.
Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at

title: Cautious Voters Venture Out to Cast Ballots in Three States; Some left their houses for first time in days amid coronavirus pandemic to visit unevenly staffed polling places
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
For many voters going to the polls Tuesday in three states, the trip was their first time out of their homes since they started practicing social distancing to deal with
the coronavirus pandemic
.
Some were successful in casting their ballots—with hand sanitizer at the ready, while others had trouble even locating an operating polling site.
Mike Kontos, a 37-year-old real-estate agent who cast his ballot at a fire station in Miami, voted for former Vice President Joe Biden with gloves and disinfectant wipes he brought with him after being cooped up at home for several days. He said Mr. Biden could be boosted by the Trump administration's handling of the coronavirus outbreak.
"If he plays it right, he could have a good chance," Mr. Kontos said, as voters trickled into the polling site with no lines.
While at least five states
have postponed their primaries
because of the pandemic, voters in Florida, Illinois and Arizona headed to the polls Tuesday, with many counties reporting a low turnout for in-person voting. Ohio's primary had also been scheduled for Tuesday, but the governor postponed in-person voting there and
polling places were closed
.
The Democratic presidential primary field has narrowed in recent weeks to just Mr. Biden and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, and polls in all three states have shown Mr. Biden with a lead.
Stephen Watson, 53, a health-care executive who also voted in Miami, said his trip to the polling station was his first outing after self-quarantining for two weeks because of symptoms he said were consistent with Covid-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus: a temperature of 103 degrees, cough and shortness of breath. He said he wasn't able to confirm he had the virus because he couldn't get tested.
Mr. Watson also voted for Mr. Biden. "We don't need a revolution," he said,
echoing one of Mr. Biden's lines about Mr. Sanders
. "We just need good leadership."
In Illinois, there were widespread reports of voters not being able to cast their ballots after polling places closed when election judges didn't show up. Some found handwritten signs telling them the polling site had closed and posted photos on social media.
Election organizers were scrambling to find new polling-place workers in Chicago and suburban counties after hundreds dropped out over concerns about the virus.
Matthew Lindner, 38, who works in marketing in Chicago, said his polling site was moved from a senior citizens home to a church in his neighborhood, with no communication from election officials about the change. A sign at the senior citizens home and the election website confirmed the new location.
But when he got to the church to vote at 8 a.m., poll workers told him that voting machines hadn't made it to the site yet.
"I'm livid with the state," he said. "This is not the first election we've had in Chicago. I think it's 100% related to the pandemic. I've never seen anything like this."
Mr. Lindner returned to the polling site about five hours later to cast his ballot. The equipment had arrived less than an hour before, and about a dozen people were in line—spaced out about two feet apart. There was no hand sanitizer in sight.
When he reached the front of the line, he and some others were told their precinct had been moved again—to a local library.
LaDonna Miller, 26, a clinical counselor in Chicago, voted early for Mr. Sanders on Monday after hearing about officials still trying to find enough election workers for Tuesday. "They said there was a shortage of judges," she said. "I had a fear of my polling place being properly staffed."
Ms. Miller said she waited for two hours in a line with other voters and grew concerned about the conditions they faced. "We were very clustered together and not following any of the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's] guidelines," she said.
Christina Cosentino, 28, a graduate student in Joliet, Ill., said she decided to mail in her ballot for Mr. Biden instead of going to the polls during the outbreak. "Actually," she said. "I only know a few people who voted today."

title: State Street: Contagion Fears May Postpone State's Democratic Primary
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
New York officials are debating whether to move the state's Democratic presidential primary from April 28 to a date in June as the number of coronavirus infections grows.
State Sen. James Skoufis, a Democrat from Orange County, introduced a bill that would move the nominating contest to June 23, which is already the date of primary elections for members of Congress as well as the state Assembly and Senate.
State health officials project the outbreak will reach its peak in around 45 days. Mr. Skoufis said he was concerned about the possibility of the virus spreading at polling places and said consolidating elections would save taxpayer money.
"Joe Biden is going to be the Democratic nominee, so there's no responsible reason why we should continue on with an April primary," said Mr. Skoufis, who had endorsed Pete Buttigieg's candidacy.
The April 28 elections were shaping up to be Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders's last stand against the former vice president. Mr. Biden has amassed 1,181 delegates, compared with Mr. Sanders's 885.
Good-government advocacy groups including Citizens Union and Common Cause NY also support the postponement.
Republicans canceled their presidential primary after President Trump was the only candidate who submitted the required nominating signatures. Douglas Kellner, a Democratic commissioner of the State Board of Elections, said moving the presidential primary would be up to the state Legislature and Gov. Andrew Cuomo. Mr. Kellner supports the idea.
"I think that the date is arbitrary and the risks to the public outweigh the relative importance of keeping our democratic functions operational," he said.
Mr. Cuomo said Sunday that he was exploring ways to make it easier for people to vote by mail in the primary. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio last week postponed a March 24 special election for Queens borough president because of the outbreak. Spokesmen for Assembly Speaker Carl Heastie and Senate Majority Leader Andrea Stewart-Cousins, both Democrats, didn't respond to a request for comment.
April 28 had become the so-called "Acela Primary" because voting was also scheduled in Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland and Rhode Island -- all of which are serviced by Amtrak's express train. The governors of Maryland and Connecticut already delayed their contests until June 2, and officials in Pennsylvania and Rhode Island are also considering changes.
New York State Democratic Chairman Jay Jacobs said he believes it is premature to reschedule the primary. Mr. Jacobs said voting on June 28 would cause logistical problems: It will take officials around 10 days to certify the results, and the party's state committee must hold a meeting to name at-large delegates before the Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee, which starts on July 13.
"At the moment, I choose to be optimistic and look at reports that show it might be abating by the date of our primary," Mr. Jacobs said of the coronavirus outbreak.
The Democratic National Committee has rules in place that could reduce the number of convention delegates awarded to a state if it holds a primary after June 9. Mr. Jacobs said he was confident the DNC would reconsider its regulations in light of the outbreak; a DNC spokeswoman didn't respond to an email seeking comment.
There are also special elections on April 28 for a congressional seat in western New York, a state Senate seat around Syracuse and three Assembly seats. Political strategists said the virus has already prompted campaigns to focus their efforts online as door-to-door canvassing has been curtailed to prevent the spread of the virus.
---
jimmy.vielkind@wsj.com

title: U.S. News: Biden Calls Trial Claims 'Hit Job' on Him
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
CLINTON, Iowa -- Before President Trump, no American president had ever sought re-election in the middle of an impeachment.
Former Vice President Joe Biden is contending with a similar distinction in the Democratic primaries, as a White House candidate caught up in the impeachment of Mr. Trump, whose trial centers on his pressing Ukraine to investigate Mr. Biden, a possible opponent in this year's election.
Days before the Iowa caucuses, Mr. Biden is trying to turn Republican efforts to damage him in the impeachment trial into a badge of honor and a sign of his resilience. His campaign hopes it will help him appeal to Democratic voters struggling to answer the contest's biggest question: Which Democrat is best positioned to defeat Mr. Trump in November's general election?
"This whole impeachment trial for Trump is just a political hit job to smear me," Mr. Biden told an audience Tuesday night in Clinton, a community along the Mississippi River. "That's how scared Trump is about having to run against me."
When Iowa Republican Sen. Joni Ernst suggested the Senate's trial in Washington could undercut Mr. Biden's appeal in Iowa, his campaign quickly seized upon her comments and posted a digital ad.
Mr. Trump's lawyers argued this week that the president was justified in seeking investigations into Mr. Biden and his son Hunter Biden, who served on the board of the Ukrainian natural-gas company Burisma while Mr. Biden was vice president. Mr. Biden has said he did nothing wrong in pressuring Ukraine to fire a prosecutor who had at one time been involved in investigating Burisma and who was widely viewed as insufficiently aggressive on corruption. Mr. Biden has also noted he was carrying out the Obama administration's Ukraine policy, which was in line with international partners on rooting out corruption.
Mr. Biden rarely hears questions from voters about the impeachment trial. But the uncertainty over how long it will last has loomed over the final week in Iowa.
Sens. Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar have been forced to scrap most of their Iowa campaign schedules to attend the trial.
The possibility of testimony at the impeachment trial from witnesses, such as former national security adviser John Bolton, could mean the proceeding spills over into campaigning ahead of the Feb. 11 New Hampshire primary.
It also could increase the likelihood that Mr. Biden's son, or even Mr. Biden himself, might be called to testify.
He told reporters this week that he had "nothing to defend. This is all a game."
Republicans, meanwhile, haven't been subtle about trying to use the trial to undermine Mr. Biden's candidacy.
Ms. Ernst, who is seeking re-election this year, told reporters that she was "really interested" to see how the arguments made by Mr. Trump's legal team "informs and influences the Iowa caucus voters."
Mr. Biden pounced, reading aloud the senator's comments during his events in Iowa. The campaign placed a homemade sign on the wall that said, "Joni -- We're w/ Joe."
"She spilled the beans," said Mr. Biden, who told his supporters, "You can ruin Donald Trump's night by caucusing for me, but also you can ruin Joni Ernst's night."
One of Ms. Ernst's Senate colleagues, meanwhile, bought airtime in Iowa to bolster Mr. Trump's defense. Sen. Rick Scott (R., Fla.) cut a 30-second ad accusing Mr. Biden of getting away with a pressure campaign against Ukraine and helping his son profit from his position, charges the Bidens and supporters have denied.
"I just see that as part of the desperation of the Republicans in facing him, that they've got to try to drag him and his son into this," said Jeff Hermiston, a retired teacher from West Liberty, Iowa, who saw Mr. Biden at a recent event and plans to caucus for him.

title: Trump, Democrats Press Their Case as Impeachment Nears Its End; Likely acquittal this week has the president looking ahead to November
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—An emboldened President Trump turned his focus Sunday to his re-election bid, arguing a growing economy would help him in November, as Democrats' lead impeachment manager vowed to press for the president's removal even as the Senate is virtually certain to acquit him.
"It was all nonsense," Mr. Trump said of impeachment during a Fox News interview. "It's a very serious thing. It should never happen to another president."
In a separate television appearance, Rep. Adam Schiff (D., Calif.) said that in closing arguments in the impeachment trial Monday, Democrats would continue pressing to remove Mr. Trump from office over his Ukraine pressure campaign.
"It's enormously important that the country understand exactly what this president did," Mr. Schiff said. The Senate should remove Mr. Trump from office, Mr. Schiff said, "because he is threatening to still cheat in the next election by soliciting foreign interference."
The televised comments by Messrs. Trump and Schiff came just ahead of the Iowa caucuses Monday, the State of the Union address Tuesday and the expected acquittal of Mr. Trump by Senate Republicans on Wednesday. They also came as
new polling showed voters' views of him
were little-changed by his impeachment.
In Iowa, site of the nation's first presidential nominating contest, Democratic contenders were crisscrossing the state trying to appeal to the many voters who have said they would make their choice based on who they think has the best chance to unseat the Republican president in November.
"I just want Trump out," said Sandy Suplee, a 58-year-old laborer from Pella, Iowa. She said she would set aside her personal preferences among the candidates to support former Vice President Joe Biden, whom she believes has the best odds of winning.
For Trump supporter Susan Ohnysty, a 60-year-old in West Des Moines, impeachment was a "waste of time," adding that the articles of impeachment "were not meeting the standards of a high crime."
On Friday,
the Senate voted 51-49
to reject Democrats' demands to call new witnesses in the impeachment trial. That
effectively ended the impeachment effort,
even though the trial is set to resume for four hours of closing arguments Monday, followed by a vote on the articles of impeachment Wednesday.
A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll found a majority of voters said they believed Mr. Trump abused his power by asking Ukraine to investigate a potential political opponent in order to influence the coming election, and also that Mr. Trump obstructed Congress by not cooperating with the impeachment inquiry.
But there wasn't majority support for removing him from office. The poll found 49% said he should be allowed to finish his term, compared with 46% who said he should be removed.
Mr. Trump's job approval in the January poll stood at 46%, with 51% disapproving, in line with results throughout the Trump presidency.
Mr. Schiff, when pressed in an interview on CBS on what Democrats would do after Mr. Trump's likely acquittal, said he wasn't looking beyond the trial.
"I'm not letting the senators off the hook," Mr. Schiff said. "We're still going to go into the Senate this week and make the case why this president needs to be removed."
Asked if Democrats would consider subpoenaing former national security adviser John Bolton—
whose coming book alleges
that the president told him he wanted to hold up aid to Ukraine until he got the investigations he wanted—Mr. Schiff declined to answer definitively but said there are several possible options.
In a separate television appearance on Sunday, one of the president's attorneys in the Senate trial, Alan Dershowitz, argued that there is no need to seek out new information.
"The articles of impeachment did not charge an impeachable offense," Mr. Dershowitz said on Fox News. "So the right answer is to dismiss it and cut it off right there. No amount of witnesses could have changed that conclusion."
Mr. Dershowitz also reframed one of his arguments last week, about whether Mr. Trump could have believed his re-election was in the national interest.
"If the president did something completely lawful, the fact that part of his motivation may have been to help his election cannot be the quid pro quo," he said. "I don't believe that a president can do anything if he thinks it is in the national interest."
The Senate impeachment trial commanded 11 days of attention and appeared to be heading for a final vote Saturday. But a decision to break until a resumption this week was bipartisan, Sen. John Thune (R., S.D.) said.
That gave Democratic senators campaigning for president a chance to hit the trail in Iowa, while others got a chance to relax.
Sen. Lindsey Graham headed home to South Carolina, where a pulled pork platter awaited him. "We all need a break," Mr. Graham, a Republican, said. "This is as close to purgatory as any of us want to get."
Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, a Democratic presidential hopeful, missed a scheduled campaign appearance at a Friday evening town hall in Des Moines, leaving her campaign co-leaders to hold down the fort.
However, the Senate trial adjourned in enough time for Ms. Warren to show up at a hastily arranged late-night campaign event at a brewery across the street from the town-hall venue.
Some in the White House saw an upside to the timing, with Mr. Trump giving his State of the Union address before his likely acquittal. Eric Ueland, the White House legislative liaison, told reporters it would bring focus to what he said were Mr. Trump's accomplishments while contrasting with the various investigations into the president.
"It's a strong one-two punch," he said.
Catherine Lucey, Sabrina Siddiqui and Joshua Jamerson contributed to this article.
Write to Alex Leary at
alex.leary@wsj.com

title: Joe Biden's South Carolina 'Firewall' Faces Test with Black Voters; Interviews in rural Allendale County find African-Americans are deciding between Biden and Steyer ahead of state's primary
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
ALLENDALE, S.C.—If South Carolina is former Vice President Joe Biden's firewall against Sen. Bernie Sanders in the Democratic presidential primary race, interviews with black voters here indicate some cracks have formed.
Most of nearly two dozen likely voters who discussed their plans for Saturday's primary said they were trying to decide between Mr. Biden, who has long benefited from strong support from African-Americans, and billionaire Tom Steyer, who has campaigned heavily in the state.
Allendale County, tucked along the Georgia border away from the cities candidates typically focus on, carries symbolic weight in the first 2020 primary where black voters will play a significant role: It has the state's highest proportion of nonwhite voters, a Wall Street Journal analysis of state data found.
"I feel very strongly about Joe Biden, but he's making me nervous right now," said Lottie Lewis, a town council member here. Besides Mr. Biden, she is considering Mr. Steyer and planned to meet this week with some of his representatives.
More than three-quarters of Allendale County's roughly 5,800 registered voters are nonwhite, and U.S. census data indicates 73.8% of the county's residents are black. South Carolina's Democratic primary electorate was 61% black in 2016, exit polls showed
South Carolina's black vote isn't concentrated only in urban areas, as is the case in some other parts of the U.S. Twelve of the state's 46 counties have registered-voter populations that are more than half nonwhite, making the rural vote important in the primary.
Polling averages in the state show Mr. Biden leading, followed by Mr. Sanders and Mr. Steyer.
South Carolina is critical for Mr. Biden. He has decadeslong ties to the state and needs a win to brighten his campaign narrative after poor showings in nominating contests in Iowa and New Hampshire and a second-place finish in Nevada. His once-dominant lead in South Carolina polls has narrowed, and Mr. Sanders, the self-described democratic socialist from Vermont, has intensified his campaign in the state this week.
In
Tuesday night's debate in Charleston
, Mr. Biden showed no hesitation when asked whether he would win Saturday. "I will win South Carolina," he said. On Wednesday,
Mr. Biden secured the important endorsement
of Rep. James Clyburn, the most influential Democrat in the state.
But Mr. Sanders has momentum after victories in Nevada and New Hampshire and a split decision in Iowa with Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Ind. Only one voter interviewed here mentioned Mr. Buttigieg as someone they were thinking about backing on Saturday.
Mr. Buttigieg was among the few candidates who visited Allendale County, which is an hour or more from the state's major population centers. Sen. Cory Booker of New Jersey, who is no longer in the race, is the only other to make a stop here so far,
according to a tracker run by The Post and Courier newspaper
in Charleston.
In recent weeks, Mr. Steyer has largely had South Carolina to himself. Most of the other candidates focused more on Nevada, New Hampshire and some of the 14 states that host contests March 3. Mr. Steyer has spent more in the state on advertising than any other 2020 candidate, at $22.4 million, according to data from advertising tracker Kantar/CMAG.
Nate Hartley, a retired information technology manager who remains undecided, said he was intrigued. "Tom Steyer has hit really hard here," he said. "Every week, I get some kind of contact from him."
Mr. Hartley said he didn't see Mr. Biden "pulling back up from where he is" in the race and thought Mr. Sanders was too progressive. "Bernie wants to end capitalism," he said.
Patricia Johnson, a retired elementary school teacher, said she already had voted via an absentee ballot for Mr. Steyer. She said she did so, in part, because of Mr. Steyer's wealth and his potential ability to compete against President Trump in a general election. "We all know money talks," she said. "He could match Trump dollar for dollar on advertising."
Ms. Johnson said she liked Mr. Biden but was concerned about his association with Mr. Trump's impeachment over, in part, his pressing Ukraine to investigate the former vice president's family. Mr. Trump wanted a probe into Mr. Biden's oldest son, who sat on the board of a Ukrainian company at a time when his father was pushing anticorruption efforts there. The Bidens have denied wrongdoing.
"If he's the nominee, there would be so much drama involving Ukraine with him and Trump," Ms. Johnson said. "I've had enough drama."
In an interview, Mr. Steyer said he thought he was in second or third place in South Carolina and "moving up." He attributed his success with black voters to his focus on racial issues and spending more time in South Carolina than "any other" candidate.
"I deal explicitly with race," he said. "I have a decadeslong history of working with people in the African-American community and Latino community, and actually taking part when it had nothing to do with me running for president."
Allendale, the county seat, has seen better days. Before Interstate 95 was built in the 1960s to the east, it was a booming town along a north-south highway that moved commerce and tourists between the Northeast and Florida. It is now mostly dependent on agriculture, timber and government employment. Almost a third of residents live in poverty, double the state average.
One recent development that has brought smiles to many here was the Super Bowl win of the Kansas City Chiefs. Cornerback Bashaud Breeland attended the town's high school.
Related
*
Joe Biden's Allies Launch Effort to Woo Centrist Voters

*
Joe Biden's Black-Voter Support Shows Signs of Strain

*
Sanders Leads Democratic Primary Field as Biden Slips, WSJ/NBC News Poll Finds

Wilbur Cave, the executive director of a housing nonprofit, said he was undecided about his vote. Mr. Steyer's commitment to the state had impressed him. "I like that he put a lot of energy and time and resources into South Carolina," he said.
Pam Love, an attendance clerk at an elementary school, said she was also leaning toward supporting Mr. Steyer after seeing him speak last weekend in a neighboring county. "I like how he reaches out to the minority community," she said.
Clifford Smith, a pig farmer, said he was originally a supporter of Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts before switching to Mr. Biden. He is concerned, however, about the former vice president's lackluster performance on the campaign trail. "I don't know what his problem is," he said. "It was his to lose and he's losing it."
Write to John McCormick at
mccormick.john@wsj.com

title: Biden Notches Key Win in Michigan, Also Takes Missouri, Mississippi and Idaho; Michigan offers 125 delegates, the biggest prize of the night, while also being a key battleground state in November
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Joe Biden triumphed in the key state of Michigan, while also winning in Missouri, Mississippi and Idaho, as he built his delegate lead over Bernie Sanders with a coalition of African-Americans, suburbanites and older voters in Tuesday's round of Democratic presidential nominating contests.
Opening a new phase in the race, the former vice president put distance between himself and Mr. Sanders—and built upon his momentum from
wins in 10 Super Tuesday states
last week. Mr. Biden quickly sought to unite the party after prevailing in Michigan, which offered 125 delegates, the biggest prize of the night. Mr. Sanders won the North Dakota caucuses, while the results in Washington, the second-biggest delegate haul of the day, were too close to call.
"I want to thank Bernie Sanders and his supporters for their tireless energy and their passion," Mr. Biden said in remarks at Philadelphia's National Constitution Center. "We share a common goal and, together, we'll defeat Donald Trump; we'll defeat him together."
Mr. Biden has presented himself as the Democrat best able to challenge President Trump in general election battlegrounds such as Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan, which was the first of those states to weigh in on the Democratic race. His win there, by one measure, is his most significant yet and could allow him to argue that he should be the party's nominee. With about 64% of precincts reporting, Mr. Biden had about 53% of the vote to about 38% for Mr. Sanders. The Vermont senator narrowly defeated Hillary Clinton in the state in the 2016 nominating contest.
Mr. Biden was projected the winner in Mississippi, Missouri and Michigan shortly after the states' polls closed, an early sign of his clout in three states with large African-American voting blocs. Black voters made up about two-thirds of the electorate in Mississippi, exit polls showed. Mr. Biden had won more than 80% of support in the state, with about 89% of precincts reporting.
The former vice president campaigned ahead of the Missouri primary among African-Americans in St. Louis and Kansas City. With about 93% of precincts reporting, Mr. Biden had about 60% of the vote in Missouri.
Mr. Sanders returned to his home in Burlington, Vt., and did not speak publicly after the election results. A campaign aide said he intended to participate in Sunday's debate in Phoenix.
Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York, a top Sanders surrogate, expressed disappointment as the election results streamed in. "There's no sugar-coating it. Tonight's a tough night. Tonight's a tough night for the movement overall," Ms. Ocasio-Cortez said on Instagram.
Mr. Biden entered Tuesday with a delegate edge of 670 to 574 over Mr. Sanders, according to
a Wall Street Journal delegate tracker
, even as Super Tuesday states such as California and Colorado, which Mr. Sanders carried, continue to process election results.
Mr. Sanders sought to steady his campaign on Tuesday. Moderates in the Democratic Party rapidly
coalesced around Mr. Biden
after he won South Carolina's primary last month. Some in the party's establishment have expressed fears that Mr. Sanders, a self-described Democratic socialist who won the New Hampshire and Nevada contests, would be too liberal for many voters in the general election.
The campaigns competed for votes against the backdrop of
growing economic concerns
over
the spread of the coronavirus
. Mr. Sanders and Mr. Biden both canceled rallies in Cleveland Tuesday, ahead of Ohio's primary next week, citing public health concerns. Both candidates have
questioned Mr. Trump's handling of the crisis
in recent days.
Exit polls coming in with the results showed Mr. Biden winning handily among black and older voters and performing well with those who had at least a college degree. Mr. Biden was also prevailing in cities such as St. Louis, Kansas City and Detroit and in their surrounding suburban areas—including Oakland County, Mich., a key general election battleground.
Mr. Sanders maintained a substantial advantage over Mr. Biden among young voters, exit polls showed. The Vermont senator staked much of his campaign on motivating the young, and others disenchanted with current politics, to come to the polls.
Mr. Biden, while campaigning in Michigan, spoke of the Obama administration's bailout of General Motors and Chrysler, two titans of the state's auto industry, more than a decade ago.
"We bet on you," Mr. Biden said during a visit to a Fiat Chrysler assembly plant in Detroit earlier Tuesday. "If I end up being the president, you'll never have a better friend in the White House."
During a Detroit rally on the eve of the primary, Mr. Biden was joined by California Sen. Kamala Harris and New Jersey Sen. Cory Booker, two former presidential rivals who recently endorsed Mr. Biden's candidacy. The pair—who have been discussed by some Democrats as potential running mates for Mr. Biden if he wins the nomination—sought to help him appeal to black voters in the state.
Mr. Sanders courted voters at a Dearborn Heights, Mich., polling place on Tuesday, repeating criticisms he has raised about Mr. Biden's record, including the former Delaware senator's past support for the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Mr. Sanders told reporters that was "obviously a very important state" but that he thinks every state is important to try to win. Last week, his campaign dispatched top aides to Michigan, including some who oversaw his Iowa caucus efforts.
"When our record is compared to Biden's, when our vision is compared to Biden's, when we have that debate in Phoenix, I'm feeling pretty good," Mr. Sanders said, referring to Sunday's
primary debate in Arizona
.
Tuesday's nominating contest served as the first opportunity for voters to consider a one-on-one choice between Mr. Biden and Mr. Sanders. Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D., Hawaii) was still seeking the nomination but has been unable to break out of single-digit polling.
Mr. Biden has largely sought to avoid confrontation with Mr. Sanders as he attempts to build support in the party.
The former vice president mostly has only mentioned his opponent to point out that he himself has driven up turnout in primaries so far, not Mr. Sanders. Mr. Biden has argued that he is bringing African-Americans and white blue-collar workers into his coalition.
"Sen. Sanders likes to say, 'We need a record turnout to beat Donald Trump.' He's absolutely right," Mr. Biden has told audiences in recent days, rattling off statistics from Super Tuesday showing a turnout boost in states such as Virginia, Texas and North Carolina.
"Guess who they voted for? They voted for us," Mr. Biden said.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
What do you think the Michigan primary victory will mean and why? Join the conversation below.
Alexa Corse contributed to this article in Detroit
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com
and Sabrina Siddiqui at
Sabrina.Siddiqui@wsj.com

in Washington and Sabrina Siddiqui

title: Democratic Candidates Court Unions With Infrastructure Pitch; Joe Biden, Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar and Tom Steyer say U.S. faces an urgent need to rebuild the nation's roads, bridges and highways
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
LAS VEGAS—Democratic presidential candidates said Sunday that the U.S. faces an urgent need to rebuild the nation's roads, bridges and highways, appealing to union workers ahead of Nevada's Feb. 22 caucuses.
Joe Biden, Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar and Tom Steyer courted several labor unions
Sunday at a forum
sponsored by United for Infrastructure, a nonprofit organization made up of labor unions and trade associations.
The candidates said upgrading the country's aging transportation system has been a promise that President Trump failed to keep during his first term and that their own infrastructure plans could serve as a counterweight to his re-election message.
During his presidency, Mr. Trump has sought $1 trillion in infrastructure improvements. Democrats have noted that his plan would press cities and states to provide at least 80% of the funding.
"Do you remember one of the things that he promised? Infrastructure," said Ms. Klobuchar, a Minnesota senator, recalling the president's victory speech after the 2016 election. "While Congress has kept the funding going in some of the areas, we have not seen the big infrastructure investment that he promised—not one that keeps our country competitive." 





Amy Klobuchar made infrastructure the subject of the first policy rollout of her campaign. PHOTO: Mikayla Whitmore for The Wall Street Journal
Mr. Biden, the former vice president, said the country could simultaneously fix the nation's crumbling infrastructure while ensuring it was improved to become more resilient to climate change. "I think you do both," he said. One of his proposals includes adding 500,000 charging stations for electric vehicles.
"I believe the Band-Aid has been ripped off and people are ready to do rational things," Mr. Biden said, describing a Congress in which both parties might be ready to reach a deal on infrastructure.
The candidates have offered plans to overhaul the nation's transportation network and create construction jobs, intended in part to draw a contrast with the president, whose proposals have languished despite bipartisan attempts in Congress to forge a broad plan
to repair the country's infrastructure.

Organized labor has long been a political force in Nevada and plays a more significant role in the state than in Iowa and New Hampshire, which held the first two presidential nominating contests.
Mr. Biden has proposed
a $1.3 trillion plan
to rebuild roads, bridges and highways and promote a high-speed rail system. Ms. Klobuchar, who made infrastructure the subject of the first policy rollout of her campaign, would spend $1 trillion on the projects, including $650 billion in direct federal funding for infrastructure.
Mr. Buttigieg, former mayor of South Bend, Ind., has outlined a program to put $1 trillion into infrastructure in partnership with states and cities, a plan that he says would create 6 million jobs. Mr. Steyer, meanwhile, has proposed dedicating $2 trillion in public spending to promote "climate-smart" infrastructure.
The plans have also been at the center of how the candidates intend to address climate change.
Mr. Steyer, a billionaire businessman, said that if elected he would declare a climate emergency on his first day in office, and infrastructure spending would work in tandem with his climate-change agenda.
"Everything we're going to do we're going to do from the standpoint of climate," he said.
Mr. Buttigieg, who recently finished his second term as mayor, pointed to the frustration that many municipal leaders had after Mr. Trump released his infrastructure proposal. He said it would have had many state and local officials "do most of the work and come up with most of the money."
Mr. Buttigieg said the nation had "an opportunity to do something different and take the 'Infrastructure week' back from being a punchline and actually make sure it is a template for a better future." He was referring to weeks in which the administration said it planned to push lawmakers to come to terms on legislation, efforts that were sometimes overshadowed by other topics raised by the president. 





Tom Steyer, a billionaire businessman, said that if elected he would declare a climate emergency on his first day in office. PHOTO: Mikayla Whitmore for The Wall Street Journal
The Democratic candidates proposing infrastructure upgrades said they would pay for them largely by undoing Mr. Trump's tax cuts for businesses, along with a variety of other steps.
One funding issue the next administration may be confronted with is how to replenish the Highway Trust Fund, which gets its revenue from federal fuels taxes. The trust fund has faced a shortfall because fuel taxes haven't been raised in a quarter-century while increased vehicle efficiency has cut into gasoline and diesel consumption.
But the candidates said it was unlikely that Congress would approve a gas-tax increase. Mr. Biden, for example, said he would devote $50 billion from the higher taxes on corporations to bolster the trust fund but said flatly, "We're not going to be able to raise the gas tax." He did, however, say that Congress might be able to index the tax for inflation.
The forum Sunday, at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, was moderated by The Wall Street Journal's Gerald Seib and Jeanne Cummings.
The forum was a showcase for the candidates before organized labor.
The most powerful union in Nevada, Culinary 226, which represents about 60,000 members from the hospitality industry, said Friday it
wouldn't endorse a presidential candidate
before the caucuses.
Most of the nation's largest labor unions have stayed on the sidelines in the 2020 primaries, but some labor organizations have signaled plans to become more active.
The candidates said they would honor prevailing wage laws, including the Davis-Bacon law, which they said would ensure that workers receive fair wages. They also vowed to prevent corporations from taking over federal apprenticeship programs, a key concern for building trades and other unions.
The leading Democratic presidential contenders, along with Mr. Trump, were invited to participate in the forum. On the Democratic side, former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren chose not to attend.
The event's host committee included: International Union of Operating Engineers; Transportation Trades Department, AFL-CIO; North America's Building Trades Unions; Transport Workers Union of America; American Society of Civil Engineers; American Public Transportation Association; American Council of Engineering Companies; American Road and Transportation Builders Association; Value of Water Campaign; Association of Equipment Manufacturers; Airports Council International-North America; and Build Together. 





Joe Biden has proposed a $1.3 trillion plan to rebuild roads, bridges and highways and promote a high-speed rail system PHOTO: Mikayla Whitmore for The Wall Street Journal
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com

title: Senate Acquits Trump on Both Impeachment Articles; Vote is largely along party lines and falls short of two-thirds needed to remove the president
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—The Republican-led Senate acquitted President Trump of charges stemming from his efforts to
press Ukraine to announce investigations
that would benefit him politically, bringing to a close a bruising four-month battle fought almost entirely along party lines.
The
third presidential impeachment in U.S. history
intensified the nation's sharp divide over Mr. Trump and previewed many of the arguments likely to be heard ahead of the election this fall. During the trial, Democrats said the Republican president was trying to cheat in the coming election by trying to damage a potential opponent. Republicans said that Democrats were improperly inflating missteps into impeachable offenses and trying to overturn the results of the 2016 election.
The Senate vote to acquit marked a clear victory for the president, underscoring his primacy in the GOP and the end to a process that had hung over the past several months of his presidency. But while Mr. Trump had hoped for a forceful display of unity from Republicans in defense of his actions, he got something less: GOP senators strongly supported his acquittal, but several said the Democrats had proven that he acted improperly—though not in a manner deserving of impeachment—regarding Ukraine.
Mr. Trump was also denied a unanimous not guilty verdict from Republican senators when
Mitt Romney of Utah voted to convict
on the first article of impeachment.
Given the GOP's 53-47 majority in the Senate and the Constitution's requirement that two-thirds of the Senate is required to convict, Mr. Trump's chance of acquittal was always strong. Mr. Trump now becomes the first president to run for re-election after having been impeached.
Mr. Trump and his campaign sought throughout the process to turn impeachment to his political advantage, frequently using his attacks on the investigation in fundraising emails.
On the first article of impeachment, abuse of power, all 47 Democratic-aligned senators and Mr. Romney voted to convict, falling short of the 67 needed to remove the president from office. On the obstruction of Congress article, the vote also failed, with all Democrats and no Republicans finding the president guilty.
The senators read their votes aloud from their desks, and Chief Justice John Roberts announced the outcome. "Donald John Trump, president of the United States…is hereby acquitted," he said.
Mr. Trump, in a tweet after the vote, declared "our Country's VICTORY on the Impeachment Hoax" and wrote that he would make a public statement about his acquittal on Thursday.
Republicans' arguments in favor of acquittal split broadly into two camps. Some argued that House impeachment managers' case was half-baked and that they should have gone to court to pursue the testimony of further witnesses who had been told by the White House not to cooperate. Others in the party said House Democrats had proved their case but that the president's conduct wasn't impeachable.
The impeachment probe grew out of a phone call last summer in which Mr. Trump asked President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine to announce an investigation into Joe Biden, a top Democratic presidential contender, while holding up congressionally approved aid to the country. Mr. Trump has defended the call as "perfect" and has said he did nothing wrong regarding Ukraine. The aid was later released after bipartisan outcry from lawmakers.
The most dramatic moment of the day came two hours before the acquittal vote, when Mr. Romney said in a floor speech that he had decided to vote to convict the president on the first article. "The president is guilty of an appalling abuse of public trust," he said.
Mr. Romney was the first senator in U.S. history to vote to convict a president of his own party. In the impeachment trials of Democratic presidents Andrew Johnson and Bill Clinton, no Democratic senators voted to convict.
The White House, which as late as Wednesday morning had been predicting that all Republican senators would vote to acquit the president, was caught off-guard by Mr. Romney's announcement, aides said.
Immediately after Mr. Romney announced his vote, White House aides began planning to intensify attacks on the Utah senator. Later that evening, Mr. Trump tweeted a video accusing Mr. Romney, the 2012 GOP presidential nominee, of "posing as a Republican" and trying to "infiltrate" the Trump administration.
The White House had also held out hope that a handful of Democrats would side with Republicans and vote to acquit the president, but Democrats remained unified.
Democrats said the acquittal amounted to a defeat for the institution of Congress, and they warned that leaving Mr. Trump in office would make him free to abuse power again.
"The verdict of this kangaroo court will be meaningless," said Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, on Wednesday. "You cannot be on the side of this president and be on the side of truth."
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
How do you think President Trump's acquittal will affect his bid for 2020, if at all? Join the conversation below.
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) said Democrats used impeachment for political goals. "We should all agree that this is the precisely the type of recklessness that the Senate was created to stop," he said on the floor. "The response to losing one election cannot be to attack the office of the presidency."
In a news conference later in the day, Mr. McConnell declined to answer questions about whether he found the president's conduct appropriate.
In the months after House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) opened the inquiry in September, the Democratic-led House called 17 witnesses and hundreds of documents to build its case, formally
impeaching the president in December
. A month later, it handed the articles over to the Senate, which heard arguments from House impeachment managers and Mr. Trump's defense team but rejected calling witnesses it said the House should have pursued.
The tightly choreographed Senate trial was upended late last month by new revelations from former national security adviser John Bolton about the president's pressure campaign on Ukraine. The former official's
revelations in a yet-unpublished memoir
briefly raised the possibility a sufficient number of Republicans would join with Democrats to vote in favor of new witness testimony. But Republicans ultimately voted nearly in unison to oppose hearing from Mr. Bolton and other witnesses.
"Unless there's some bipartisan consensus of treason, bribery or other high crimes and misdemeanors, as there was in the Nixon case, then there shouldn't be an impeachment," Sen. Lamar Alexander (R., Tenn.) said on Tuesday.
While a majority of voters in a recent
Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll
said they believed Mr. Trump abused his power and obstructed Congress, some 49% of respondents said he should be allowed to finish his term, compared with 46% who said he should be removed.
Impeachment also made little impact on Mr. Trump's job-approval rating, which stood at 46% in the January poll—in line with his rating throughout his presidency.
Democrats made clear the trial settled nothing for them, with members of House leadership saying they would likely continue to investigate. A top House Democrat, Rep. Jerrold Nadler of New York, said Wednesday the House would "likely" subpoena Mr. Bolton and continue the investigation. Mr. Bolton's spokeswoman declined to comment on whether he would comply with any subpoena.
Despite his public attacks on the impeachment process, Mr. Trump stayed—at Mr. McConnell's urging—largely on the sidelines of Republican efforts to rally lawmakers against voting for new witnesses and approached his own legal team with a fairly light touch.
The president's sole recommendation to his team came after the defense's first day of arguments, an administration official said. After his lawyers argued for two hours, he called with a request: put Pam Bondi on TV more. He told the team he wanted Ms. Bondi, the former Florida attorney general who joined the White House last fall as an adviser on impeachment, to continue arguing his case on TV in the evenings.
Instead, Mr. Trump focused his attention elsewhere. As the trial unfolded last week, White House officials huddled with GOP House members and their aides in a small room in the vice president's office in the Capitol that one GOP aide described as "mission control." The president, the aide said, insisted advisers not call it a "war room," which he said wrongly suggested Republicans were embattled and that impeachment was an actual crisis.
Michael C. Bender contributed to this article.
Capital Journal in Your Inbox
Get the latest scoops, analysis and insights driving Washington from the WSJ's D.C. bureau, with Capital Journal.
Sign up
.

Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com
and Natalie Andrews at
Natalie.Andrews@wsj.com

title: Joe Biden Offers His Own Plan for Coronavirus Response; Democratic presidential hopeful calls for free testing, a vaccine and help for hospitals preparing for an influx of patients
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden said Thursday that the nation needs to harness a comprehensive public-health and economic response to the coronavirus, offering a look at how he would address a crisis in the White House.
The former vice president, in a speech near his home in Wilmington, Del., said the nation must respond aggressively to combat the spread of the disease, with practices and staff he described as grounded in science.
He said President Trump's labeling of the outbreak as a "foreign virus" during a Wednesday night Oval Office address "does not displace accountability for the misjudgments that have been taken thus far by the Trump administration."
"Let me be crystal clear, the coronavirus does not have a political affiliation," Mr. Biden said. "It will infect Republicans, independents and Democrats alike."
The former vice president outlined a new plan to fight the virus, saying the U.S. should lead a coordinated, global response that prepares hospitals and public-health workers and responds to the economic fallout. "President Trump is welcome to adopt all of it today," he said.
Mr. Trump's campaign said in response that the president had "acted early and decisively" to fight the virus, and he had put the U.S. "on stronger footing than other nations."
"His every move has been aimed at keeping Americans safe, while Joe Biden has sought to capitalize politically and stoke citizens' fears," Tim Murtaugh, the Trump campaign's communications director, said.
The image of Mr. Biden standing before a backdrop of American flags in a conference room at the Hotel DuPont aimed to project steadiness and serve as a counterweight to Mr. Trump, who has been accused by Democrats of providing a halting response to the outbreak.
It came as the coronavirus has forced the presidential campaigns of Mr. Biden, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and Mr. Trump to curtail their public activities. Mr. Biden canceled events in Ohio, Florida and Illinois this week; the campaign is planning "virtual" events in Chicago and Miami in coming days.
Mr. Biden's campaign said in an internal memo Thursday that all staff at its Philadelphia headquarters and around the country would work from home beginning Saturday. The campaign will continue to hold smaller events such as round-tables and house parties, but all fundraisers "will become virtual fundraisers indefinitely."
Mr. Sanders also addressed the pandemic in a speech in Burlington, Vt., using it to highlight Medicare for All, one of his signature policies. He said even without a single-payer health-care system, the government needed to provide care at no cost.
Mr. Trump, meanwhile, canceled a trip to Colorado and Nevada, including an appearance at a Republican Jewish Coalition event in Las Vegas. That event has since been postponed.
The campaign said Thursday night that staff had been instructed to work remotely through Monday so that the office could undergo a deep cleaning. An official described the move as precautionary.
The president has publicly and privately chafed at postponing rallies and had largely defended continuing them as the virus escalated. The campaign had recently been looking at holding a rally in Tampa, but hadn't announced any plans as some allies grew concerned that Mr. Trump should put the activity on pause.
Speaking to reporters Thursday, Mr. Trump said the campaign had been looking at "four or five" rallies, adding that the never-announced event in Tampa was "all sold out."
"I think we'll probably not do it, because people would say it's better to not do. You know, we need a little separation until such time as this goes away," Mr. Trump said. "It's going to go away. It's going to go away."
Mr. Biden's speech came at a pivot point for his campaign as it readies for a likely general election battle against the president. Mr. Biden on Thursday installed Jennifer O'Malley Dillon,
a top former Obama campaign aide, as his new campaign manager
, succeeding Greg Schultz, who will focus on planning for the general election.
Mr. Biden's remarks effectively were a response to the Oval Office address of Mr. Trump, who announced a 30-day ban on most travel from Europe to the U.S.
The former vice president said Americans should have access to free testing for the virus, especially the elderly living in nursing homes, and said the nation needed to swiftly develop a vaccine for coronavirus.
Mr. Biden said the country also needed a strong economic response, and urged Congress to press for emergency paid leave for workers affected by the outbreak, an expansion and broadening of unemployment benefits and temporary loans for small businesses dealing with revenue shortfalls.
Some of those steps, including paid leave, have been pushed by the president, who has said workers affected by the virus should be able to "stay home without fear of financial hardship."
The president has also pressed for payroll-tax relief and said the Small Business Administration will soon offer low-interest loans to small businesses.
Mr. Biden's campaign announced Wednesday its own advisory committee on coronavirus, bringing together several former Obama officials to provide what he described as science-based, expert advice on ways the campaign can minimize health risks for the candidate, staff and supporters.
But more than simply advising the campaign, the list of people served as a preview of the type of administration Mr. Biden might assemble if elected.
The committee includes former Obama homeland security and counterterrorism adviser Lisa Monaco, Dr. David Kessler, the former commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, and Dr. Vivek Murthy, who served as the nation's surgeon general.
Mr. Biden "was there during the economic crisis, he oversaw the bailout. He's been there," said Dr. Zeke Emanuel, an advisory committee member and a vice provost at the University of Pennsylvania. "More importantly, no single person can address these issues."
Catherine Lucey and Eliza Collins contributed to this article.
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com

title: Biden Sweeps Tuesday's Primaries as Voters Confront Coronavirus Fears; The vice president pads his lead over Bernie Sanders in convention delegates
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Joe Biden won all three primaries held Tuesday on a day filled with anxious voting, building a lead in the Democratic presidential nomination race that appears increasingly difficult for Bernie Sanders to overcome.
For up-to-the-minute news on the Democratic presidential primaries, please see
WSJ's Live Coverage

The two-man race lurched forward against major disruptions triggered by
the coronavirus pandemic
as the first balloting was held—in Florida, Illinois and Arizona—since the crisis engulfed the nation. As of Wednesday morning, the former vice president had 52.8% of the delegates allocated so far and 57.6% of the number needed to win the nomination.
In Florida, a critical battleground state in the general election, Mr. Biden won nearly three times as many votes as the Vermont senator and carried all 67 counties. With 99% of Illinois precincts reporting, Mr. Biden had 59.1% of the vote versus 36.1% for Mr. Sanders. In Arizona, with 88% of the vote in, the former vice president had 43.6% against his rival's 31.6%.
The latest large victories for Mr. Biden are likely to place more pressure on Mr. Sanders to exit from the race so the party can focus on President Trump. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released Sunday showed
Mr. Biden was favored nationally, 61% to 32%
, among those who have already voted in the Democratic primary or plan to do so.
Mr. Biden, speaking from his home in Wilmington, Del., said his campaign is moving toward winning the nomination as he reached out to his rival's supporters. He delivered his address via a live stream to avoid gathering supporters during the pandemic.
"We've moved closer to securing the Democratic Party's nomination for president, and we're doing it by building a broad coalition," he said.
Mr. Biden said he and Mr. Sanders "may disagree on tactics, but we share a common vision" on issues such as health care, wealth inequality and climate change. He told young voters inspired by Mr. Sanders, "I hear you, I know what's at stake."
Mr. Biden already is trying to unify the party behind him, endorsing policy proposals related to bankruptcy laws and college tuition
in a bid to woo liberals
. Mr. Sanders acknowledged last week that he's losing the "debate over electability" among Democrats.
During a live stream address Tuesday evening, Mr. Sanders outlined his proposals to blunt the effects of the coronavirus outbreak. He didn't mention the primary elections or his narrowing prospects.
Meanwhile, the Republican National Committee noted Tuesday night that Mr. Trump had secured enough delegates through the GOP primaries to become the party's "presumptive nominee" for president.
"Nobody motivates our base more than President Trump, as evidenced by the historic turnout we've seen in state after state this primary season," Chairwoman Ronna McDaniel said in a statement. "Fueled by both our longtime supporters and the thousands of new voters that continue to join our movement, we are united and enthusiasm is on our side."
Ohio had been expected to hold a primary on Tuesday, but it joined a growing list of states
that have delayed their contests
until May or June in hopes the coronavirus situation will improve.
On the eve of the balloting, a court there rejected a request to postpone the state's primary until June 2 as Republican Gov. Mike DeWine had recommended. The in-person voting was subsequently placed on hold after the state's top health official ordered polls closed.
The Ohio Supreme Court denied a last-minute legal challenge to the postponement, and county election boards were deluged with phone calls from confused, frustrated voters.
In a statement released late Tuesday, Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez called for states with upcoming primaries and caucuses to use vote by mail and other alternatives to casting ballots in person.
"What happened in Ohio last night has only bred more chaos and confusion," he said, adding that states should focus on figuring out how to make voting easier and safer as opposed to postponing primaries "when timing around the virus remains unpredictable."
This round of contests might be the last significant ones for some time, if more states announce primary postponements.
Related
*
Top Takeaways From Tuesday's Primaries

*
Cautious Voters Venture Out to Cast Ballots in Three States

*
Tracking the Delegate Counts

Voters, sobered by the crisis, also cast ballots in local and state contests as they confronted school closures, travel limitations, event cancellations and a stressed global economy. Germs were also on their minds.
At a polling location inside a Miami fire station, workers wore gloves as they inspected voter identification cards and dispensed hand sanitizer to visitors. Some voters arrived with their own pens, gloves and disinfecting wipes.
Officials in Chicago, the biggest city within the three states that voted Tuesday, said election-day turnout was low as nervous voters stayed home. Still, many had cast ballots early. Officials said the previous primary record for such voting was easily surpassed and vote-by-mail applications more than tripled compared with 2016.
James Allen, a Chicago Board of Election Commissioners spokesman, told reporters Tuesday that city election officials failed last week to convince Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker to cancel in-person voting and replace it with vote-by-mail balloting.
Pritzker spokeswoman Jordan Abudayyeh said in a statement that the governor's office had offered "to provide the National Guard to help staff the election" as well as assistance in recruiting volunteers to fill in for election workers anxious about staffing polling places.
Share Your Thoughts
Were you surprised by the results from Tuesday's primaries, and why? Join the conversation below.
"The governor cannot unilaterally cancel or delay an election," she said. "Elections are the cornerstone of our democracy and we could not risk confusion and disenfranchisement in the courts. No one is saying this is a perfect solution. We have no perfect solutions at the moment. We only have the least bad solutions."
Some Chicago polls opened late because workers didn't show up or equipment wasn't delivered on time, while some voters were confused about where they were supposed to vote after about 200 of the city's 2,069 precinct voting locations had to be moved.
Voting-rights advocates said they fielded questions from confused voters and poll workers in multiple states because of changes made to polling locations to avoid nursing homes and other vulnerable sites.
"It's unprecedented for us to be addressing this much confusion around basic questions that voters have during a primary election, like where is my polling place," Ami Gandhi, senior counsel at the Chicago Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights, told reporters.
WSJ Newsletter
Get an early-morning coronavirus briefing each weekday, plus a health-news update Fridays:
Sign up here.

Eliza Collins, Alexa Corse, Arian Campo-Flores and Chad Day contributed to this article.
Write to John McCormick at
mccormick.john@wsj.com
and Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com
