title: In Iowa, Biden Tries to Turn Impeachment Trial to His Advantage; Former vice president points to Republican efforts to damage him as sign of his resilience.
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
CLINTON, Iowa—Before President Trump, no American president had ever sought re-election in the middle of
an impeachment
.
Former Vice President Joe Biden is contending with a similar distinction in the Democratic primaries, as a White House candidate caught up in the impeachment of Mr. Trump, whose trial centers around his pressing Ukraine to investigate Mr. Biden, a possible opponent in this year's election.
Days before
the Iowa caucuses
, Mr. Biden is trying to turn Republican efforts to damage him in the impeachment trial into a badge of honor and a sign of his resilience. His campaign hopes it will help him appeal to Democratic voters struggling to answer the contest's biggest question: Which Democrat is best positioned to defeat Mr. Trump in November's general election?
"This whole impeachment trial for Trump is just a political hit job to smear me," Mr. Biden told an audience Tuesday night in Clinton, a community along the Mississippi River. "That's how scared Trump is about having to run against me."
In a sign of his push to show he's the most electable Democrat, Mr. Biden planned to deliver an address Thursday to supporters in Waukee, a suburb of Des Moines, that would directly take on the president and serve as a prebuttal to Mr. Trump's evening rally at Drake University.
When Iowa Republican Sen. Joni Ernst suggested the Senate's trial in Washington could undercut Mr. Biden's appeal in Iowa, his campaign quickly seized upon her comments and posted a digital ad.
Mr. Trump's lawyers argued this week that the president was justified in seeking investigations into Mr. Biden and his son, Hunter Biden, who served on the board of the Ukrainian natural gas company Burisma while Mr. Biden was vice president. Mr. Biden has said he did nothing wrong in pressuring Ukraine to fire a prosecutor who had at one time been involved in investigating Burisma and who was widely viewed as
insufficiently aggressive on corruption
. Mr. Biden has also noted he was carrying out the Obama administration's Ukraine policy, which was in line with international partners on rooting out corruption.
A career State Department official told lawmakers last year that he
raised concerns in 2015
about Hunter Biden's position at Burisma, which he thought could appear to be a conflict of interest. According to one official with ties to the company, Hunter Biden's compensation was around $50,000 a month.
Hunter Biden has said
that he showed "poor judgment" in joining the board but that he only discussed his work with Burisma with his father once.
Mr. Biden rarely hears questions from voters about the impeachment trial. But the uncertainty over how long it will last has loomed over the final week in Iowa.
Sens. Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar have been forced to scrap most of their Iowa campaign schedules to attend the trial. (A fourth senator running for president, Michael Bennet of Colorado, has focused his long-shot bid on New Hampshire).
The
possibility of testimony
at the impeachment trial from witnesses, such as former national security adviser John Bolton, could mean the proceeding spills over into campaigning ahead of the Feb. 11 New Hampshire primary.
It also could increase the likelihood that Mr. Biden's son, or even Mr. Biden himself, might be called to testify. The former vice president has rejected suggestions of an exchange involving Mr. Bolton and others for his own testimony or that of his son.
He told reporters this week that he had "nothing to defend. This is all a game."
Republicans, meanwhile, haven't been subtle about trying to use the trial to undermine Mr. Biden's candidacy.
Ms. Ernst, who is seeking re-election this year, told reporters on Capitol Hill that she was "really interested" to see how the arguments made by Mr. Trump's legal team "informs and influences the Iowa caucus voters."
Mr. Biden pounced, reading aloud the senator's comments during his events in Iowa. The campaign placed a homemade sign on the wall that said, "Joni—We're w/ Joe."
"She spilled the beans," said Mr. Biden, who told his supporters, "You can ruin Donald Trump's night by caucusing for me, but also you can ruin Joni Ernst's night."
One of Ms. Ernst's Senate colleagues, meanwhile, bought airtime in Iowa to bolster
Mr. Trump's defense
. Sen. Rick Scott (R., Fla.) cut a 30-second ad accusing Mr. Biden of getting away with a pressure campaign against Ukraine and helping his son profit from his position, charges the Bidens and supporters have denied.

This Year's Iowa Caucuses Are Different. Here's How They'll Work.

"I just see that as part of the desperation of the Republicans in facing him, that they've got to try to drag him and his son into this," said Jeff Hermiston, a retired teacher from West Liberty, Iowa, who saw Mr. Biden at a recent event and plans to caucus for him. "I realize it's peripheral to the issue, but it's not the issue."
Mr. Biden has tried to turn the GOP criticism into a sign of his strength as a candidate and his ability to move past such drama. "I hope I've demonstrated that I can take a punch," he said in Cedar Falls, Iowa.
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com

title: Joe Biden's Allies Launch Effort to Woo Centrist Voters; Former vice president notches biggest pre-primary prize in South Carolina—the endorsement of Rep. James Clyburn
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
CHARLESTON, S.C.—Joe Biden and his allies are trying to consolidate
centrist voters
behind his candidacy in the final days before Saturday's
South Carolina primary
, with a key leader in this state endorsing him and a super PAC backing his bid making a major push for large donations.
Mr. Biden is running out of time to turn the presidential race into a one-on-one battle with Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, the Democratic front-runner who ranks a close second in recent polls in this state.
The former vice president notched the biggest pre-primary prize in South Carolina Wednesday, winning the endorsement of Rep. James Clyburn, the top-ranking black lawmaker in Congress and the most influential Democrat in the state.
Mr. Clyburn invoked his late wife, Emily Clyburn, who died in September, and his constituents during an emotional announcement in which he said he wanted the public to know who he would back for president. "I know Joe. We know Joe. But most importantly, Joe knows us," Mr. Clyburn said.
The endorsement comes as a pro-Biden super PAC called Unite the Country has been pressing donors to help it defend Mr. Biden here and in the coming 14-state delegate sweepstakes known as
Super Tuesday
. The super PAC's organizers said in a memo to donors Sunday that "the challenge we face is obvious: Senator Sanders has a solid, though not nearly majority base among Democratic primary voters, and the rest of the Democratic vote is split 4-5-6 ways."
Mr. Biden is competing in a crowded lane of center-left rivals alongside former South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg and Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar, splintering votes among multiple candidates as Mr. Sanders rises. The Vermont lawmaker
won the Nevada primary
last Saturday,
secured a narrow win
in New Hampshire and essentially tied for first in Iowa earlier this month.
Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, who once challenged Mr. Sanders for the hearts of liberals, has used two strong
debate performances
to present herself as the candidate who can unite the party but
is lagging in delegates
so far. And in South Carolina, billionaire activist Tom Steyer has spent more than $21 million in advertising, threatening to siphon votes from Mr. Biden among African-Americans.
As Mr. Sanders aims for victories in coming delegate-rich states such as California and Texas, the dynamics in the race among the group of moderates creates little incentive for any candidate to leave the race unless they run out of money.
Mr. Buttigieg, who narrowly won Iowa and finished second in New Hampshire, is trailing Mr. Sanders in the hunt for delegates. And both Ms. Klobuchar and Ms. Warren have home-state contests on March 3, giving them a potential opportunity to capture delegates.
Mr. Biden, who once led national polls, hopes to use South Carolina as a launchpad for the March states, including many in the South with large African-American communities.
No one wants to cede ground to billionaire Michael Bloomberg, who is pouring hundreds of millions of dollars into states holding primaries in March and
will be on the ballot
for the first time in a matter of days.
That means Mr. Sanders, as the leading liberal in the race, could pile up delegates on Super Tuesday and build a potentially insurmountable lead against a fractured field.
"That's the dilemma," said Matt Bennett, a co-founder of the centrist think tank Third Way. "I don't think anyone has a solution to that problem. Everyone stipulates it would be better if we could get down to one sooner and no one has the faintest idea how that could possibly happen…No one is going to push any of them out of the race at this point."
More
*
Bloomberg Defends Soda, Smoking Curbs as Mayor

*
Immigrant Population to Influence Election, Study Finds

*
Trump Campaign to Open Offices in Black Neighborhoods

*
Rivals Focus on Sanders at South Carolina Debate

Publicly, at least, no one is calling for any of the candidates to drop out.
"I'm not in the life-coaching business, and I'm only giving advice to one candidate and that is Joe Biden," said Rep. Cedric Richmond (D., La.), a co-chairman of Mr. Biden's campaign, when asked if others should step aside. "Other campaigns will have to make their own decisions after we win South Carolina on Saturday."
Jeff Weaver, a senior adviser to Mr. Sanders, recalled his role as Mr. Sanders's driver during the senator's long-shot—and losing—bid for governor in Vermont as a third-party candidate in 1986. "If people want to run, they should run," Mr. Weaver said.
But he added: "It's no secret that there are a few candidates on stage for whom the next week may be decisive in their future prospects."
The pro-Biden super PAC has noted in its pitch to donors that several states holding primaries on March 3 have large African-American populations that could help the former vice president, including Alabama, Arkansas, North Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia.
"It boils down to this: The month of March will decide whether Democrats will nominate Senator Sanders or someone else," organizers said in the memo. "The only other viable option at this point is Joe Biden. But the time to act is now."
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com

title: Trump Uses Campaign Rally to Wade Into Democratic Debate; The president told supporters in Milwaukee that Bernie Sanders was 'surging' and that Democrats were 'wasting their time' with impeachment
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
MILWAUKEE—As six Democratic candidates faced off in Iowa on Tuesday evening, President Trump, less than 400 miles away, sought to insert himself into the process at a rally for his reelection campaign.
Former Vice President Joe Biden? "Sleepy." Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren? "Not going anywhere."
But Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders? "Surging."
Trump campaign aides and political allies view Mr. Sanders, a self-declared socialist, as an easier opponent than other potential contenders. Mr. Trump has tweeted about Mr. Sanders twice this week, saying on Sunday that he was "looking very good" and stoking the
clash between the two leading liberals
in the race. "Elizabeth is very angry at Bernie. Do I see a feud brewing?" he
tweeted
Monday.
Mr. Sanders has
ticked up in recent national polls
, but is separated from Messrs. Biden and Warren by a few percentage points. Unlike Mr. Biden, Mr. Sanders has never polled above 30% among Democrats nationally in this election cycle.
The president also sided with Mr. Sanders in a growing clash between him and Ms. Warren over whether the Vermont senator told Ms. Warren in a 2018 meeting that he didn't believe a woman could win the election. Mr. Warren confirmed that characterization after it was reported by CNN; Mr. Sanders has denied it.
"I don't believe that he said this," Mr. Trump told a packed arena in Milwaukee. "I don't particularly like him, the nasty guy, but…[it's] not the kind of thing he'd say."
Mr. Trump had low expectations for the Democrats' face-off. "Nobody is watching," he said. "They haven't been doing great on the debates, I have to tell you."
Mr. Trump also sought to create a split screen between his actions as president and Democrats' efforts to oust him from office, a strategy that campaign aides have said they intend to pursue over the course of the election year.
"While we're creating jobs and killing terrorists, Democrats in Congress are wasting America's time with demented, hoaxes and crazy witch hunts," the president said.
The House is set to vote Wednesday to name impeachment managers and send the articles of impeachment to the Senate. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) said he expects to
start the president's impeachment trial next Tuesday
, when Mr. Trump is scheduled to be in Davos, Switzerland, for the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum.
Tuesday's rally marked the president's second of the election year and his first time in Wisconsin since July, when he traveled to Milwaukee to give a speech on trade.
Wisconsin, a state Mr. Trump won in 2016 by fewer than 23,000 votes, is a key battleground in the 2020 race. Top Democrats had already collectively t
raveled to the state 10 times
by September, and Wisconsin is one of four states where a top Democratic group, Priorities USA, plans to spend $150 million before the convention this summer in Milwaukee.
The Trump campaign has also signaled it plans to make Wisconsin a priority. Lara Trump, a senior adviser to the campaign and the president's daughter-in-law, traveled there for an event Monday. Jared Kushner, a senior White House adviser and the president's son-in-law, was also in Milwaukee on Tuesday for a criminal justice event.
Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at
Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com

title: Democrats, Trump Team Make Final Arguments in Impeachment Trial; President is set to be acquitted by Senate later this week after vote not to seek new witnesses or documents
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—House managers said President Trump was a threat to American democracy, while his defense team countered that Democrats were trying to undermine two elections, in their final arguments in his Senate
impeachment trial
on Monday.
With Democrats set to fall well short of the two-thirds threshold needed to remove Mr. Trump from office in the final vote later this week, they used their turns at the lectern to issue a warning to the Senate, focusing on what they saw as the danger presented by Mr. Trump remaining in office.
"He has betrayed our national security and he will do so again," said Rep. Adam Schiff (D., Calif.), the lead impeachment manager and chairman of the House Intelligence Committee. "He has compromised our elections and he will do so again. You will not change him. You cannot constrain him. He is who he is.… Now, do impartial justice and convict him."
The
two articles of impeachment
center on Mr. Trump's pressing Ukraine
to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden
and other matters that could help Mr. Trump politically in this year's election, and the president's alleged efforts to obstruct Congress's inquiry into those actions.
Mr. Trump has denied wrongdoing and again called impeachment a hoax on Twitter on Monday.
His legal team, in their presentation, painted Democrats' pursuit of impeachment as purely political, driven by a longstanding dislike of Mr. Trump, a Republican.
"At the end of the day, this is an effort to overturn the results of one election and to try to interfere in the coming election that begins today in Iowa," said White House counsel Pat Cipollone.
Iowa's caucuses
on Monday evening kicked off the Democratic and GOP nominating contests.
"What the House Democrats have done to this nation, to the Constitution, to the office of the president, to the president himself and to this body is outrageous," said another Trump team lawyer, Jay Sekulow.
More on the Trump Impeachment Trial
*
Trump, Democrats Press Their Case as Impeachment Trial Nears Its End

*
Senate Rejects Witnesses in Trump Impeachment Trial

*
How Republicans Scotched the Idea of Witnesses in Impeachment Trial

The two sides gave their final pitches Monday to the jury of 100 senators who had largely made up their minds on impeachment, broadly unmoved by three weeks of presentations and arguments.
An acquittal for Mr. Trump is expected on Wednesday. Twenty Republicans would have to join the entire Democratic caucus to vote to remove the president. No Republicans have said they favor impeachment, and just two supported Democrats' effort last week to seek more evidence in the trial, which failed 51-49.
Democratic senators emerged from the trial frustrated that most GOP senators
had rejected bringing in new witnesses and information
. Republicans countered that the House impeachment probe should have sought more evidence, which was blocked by the White House, before turning the matter over to the Senate.
"I'm trying to find the Senate rule that says for senators to plug their ears with cotton so they don't have to listen to the hard facts," Sen. Ron Wyden (D., Ore.) said.
Some Republicans, including Sens. Pat Roberts of Kansas and Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, said they believe Mr. Trump engaged in improper behavior, but that it didn't rise to an impeachable offense. But others were unconvinced.
Mr. Trump's defense team "raised a reasonable doubt as to the crime—the whatever—that was alleged," Sen. Bill Cassidy (R., La.) said.
Democrats allege in the first article of impeachment that Mr. Trump attempted to interfere with this year's presidential election by pressing Kyiv to probe Mr. Biden, a front-runner for the Democratic nomination. The second article accuses Mr. Trump of obstructing Congress's investigation by preventing witnesses from testifying and defying subpoenas for documentary evidence.
Mr. Trump and his allies have argued that Mr. Trump's interest in Mr. Biden was legitimate, alleging it was corrupt for Mr. Biden during the Obama administration to seek the ouster of a Ukrainian prosecutor who once investigated a Ukrainian gas company where Mr. Biden's son Hunter sat on the board. Mr. Biden sought the prosecutor's removal as part of a broad international effort to combat corruption in Ukraine.
The Bidens have denied wrongdoing. Hunter Biden has said it was poor judgment on his part to serve on the Burisma board while his father was involved with Ukraine policy as vice president.
What isn't clear is whether the acquittal vote will be bipartisan. Some Democratic senators, such as Joe Manchin of West Virginia, Doug Jones of Alabama and Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, are undecided. Mr. Jones, representing a state that backed Mr. Trump by 28 points in the 2016 election, is the most vulnerable Democratic senator this cycle.
Mr. Manchin said Monday he remained undecided on how he will vote on the impeachment articles, but introduced a measure to censure Mr. Trump, saying it would "allow this body to unite across party lines…to formally denounce the president's actions."
While censure was mentioned at times last year by some House Democrats as an alternative to impeachment, it hasn't been seriously discussed by Republican or Democratic leadership. Many Senate Republicans said Mr. Trump did nothing wrong, and those who find his actions problematic haven't called for him to be rebuked by Congress.
"Too late. It's too late," said Sen Roy Blunt (R., Mo.), a member of GOP Senate leadership, about censure.
Mr. Trump is scheduled to give his State of the Union speech Tuesday, in the chamber where the House approved the articles of impeachment against him in December. Some Republicans hoped he would move beyond impeachment in the annual speech.

A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll
published on Sunday found a majority of voters said they believed Mr. Trump abused his power by asking Ukraine to investigate a potential political opponent in order to influence the coming election, and that Mr. Trump obstructed Congress by not cooperating with the impeachment inquiry. But there wasn't majority support for removing him from office. The poll found 49% said he should be allowed to finish his term, compared with 46% who said he should be removed. Mr. Trump's job approval in the January poll stood at 46%, with 51% disapproving, in line with results throughout the Trump presidency.
Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.

title: Partisanship, Uncertainty Constrained Obama's Russia Response, Senate Report Finds; Report details prolonged interagency disagreements among senior officials who were caught off guard by Russia's 2016 election interference operations
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—The Obama administration struggled to develop a coordinated and effective response to Russian interference in the 2016 election, constrained in its options by partisanship in Washington and a lack of timely definitive attribution that Moscow was responsible, according to a bipartisan Senate report released Thursday.
The report, from the Senate Intelligence Committee, is the
first detailed government review
of how the Obama administration attempted to grapple with Russia's interference in the months leading up to the 2016 contest. The retrospective look came as U.S. agencies, states and social-media companies are preparing for a return of attempted foreign intervention in the 2020 contest.
The partially redacted 54-page report suggested high-level warnings of potential retaliation that top Obama officials delivered to senior Russian officials in the weeks before the election may have had limited impact on deterring Moscow's activities.
"The committee found that after the warnings, Russia continued its cyber activity, to include further public dissemination of stolen emails, clandestine social-media-based influence operations, and penetration of state voting infrastructure through Election Day 2016," the report said.
Several factors, both external and internal, hamstrung how President Obama and his advisers were able to address Russia's aggression, the report said, including a "heavily politicized environment" in Washington and a concern that public warnings could serve one of the Kremlin's chief aims by undermining confidence in the election.
But the report also detailed prolonged interagency disagreements among senior officials who were caught off guard by Russia's interference operations during the summer and fall of 2016—for example, officials interviewed for the report said they first learned of a hack on the Democratic National Committee from media reports, and viewed it as a case of routine espionage.
Conflicting cultures among intelligence agencies contributed to a delay in releasing a brief and somewhat vague public statement in October 2016 blaming Russia for the interference, which included
hacked Democratic emails
that were subsequently published by WikiLeaks and the peddling of divisive content on social media by Russia trolls and bots.
"After discovering the existence, if not the full scope, of Russia's election interference efforts in late-2016, the Obama administration struggled to determine the appropriate response," Sen. Richard Burr, the Republican chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said.
Sen. Mark Warner, the top Democrat on the panel, said he remained concerned that structural problems that contributed to the Obama administration's stalled response hadn't been ameliorated.
"A legitimate fear raised by the Obama administration—that warning the public of the Russian attack could backfire politically—is still present in our hyperpartisan environment," Mr. Warner said.
Former senior Obama administration officials didn't immediately respond to requests for comment.
Many of the core findings of the Senate report, including the interagency tensions, have been previously described.
The U.S. intelligence community
, former special counsel Robert Mueller and the Senate committee have all previously concluded that Russia, at the direction of President Vladimir Putin,
sought to disrupt the 2016 presidential contest
to boost then-candidate Donald Trump's electoral prospects and denigrate his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton.
The report doesn't address in depth how Mr. Trump and his campaign dealt with the Russian interference.
Mr. Trump has frequently questioned
U.S. intelligence agencies' finding that Russia meddled in the 2016 election. In July 2016, he
publicly encouraged Russia to find missing emails
from a computer server used by Mrs. Clinton during her time as secretary of state. Mr. Mueller's report found no evidence that the Trump campaign conspired with Russia on election interference efforts.
The White House didn't immediately respond to a request for comment on the Senate report.
The report buttresses previous accounts describing how top Obama officials ran into resistance from some Republican leaders on Capitol Hill when they briefed them on classified intelligence on Russia's activities and asked for a bipartisan congressional statement of concern.
At a Sept. 8, 2016, congressional briefing, Lisa Monaco, Mr. Obama's homeland security adviser, recalled that Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stated you "security people should be careful that you're not getting used." Ms. Monaco interpreted Mr. McConnell's comments as suggesting the intelligence on Russian activities was being inflated or used for partisan ends, the report said.
A spokesman for Mr. McConnell didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.
Former Vice President Joe Biden, who is running for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, said during a CNN town hall Wednesday night that it wasn't clear how expansive and sophisticated the Kremlin's interference operations were until after he and Mr. Obama left the White House. Despite "overwhelming circumstantial evidence" of Russia's involvement, Mr. Biden said, Mr. McConnell and other Republican leaders rejected the need to issue emphatic public denunciations of Moscow's conduct.
The Senate Intelligence Committee also found that the White House's decision to sharply limit sharing within the executive branch of information about Russia's unprecedented information warfare hampered the Obama administration's response.
Initial White House meetings on the subject were restricted to a "small group" that excluded the secretaries of State, Defense and Treasury, and chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, although they were included in later meetings.
The meetings were "cloak-and-dagger," and their purpose not identified on internal planning documents, former Deputy Attorney General Sally Yates told the committee.
Committee member Sen. Angus King, co-chair of a commission expected to recommend a national cyberspace strategy next month, said in an interview that "we're in a much better place" to deal with election interference than in 2016, with state-level election systems more resilient and U.S. intelligence agencies more prepared.
But Mr. King, a Maine independent who caucuses with Democrats, said adversaries are evolving as well. Four years ago, Russia's efforts to disrupt U.S. politics via social media emanated from St. Petersburg. "Now, they may be routing things through Liberia, Moldova, Thailand, who knows?"
In appended minority views, Democratic Sens. Ron Wyden and Martin Heinrich said the committee's work was inadequately thorough and suffered from a lack of access granted to the panel's own staff to investigative materials—echoing a flaw highlighted in the report.
"It is bizarre that the committee would not heed its own recommendation and grant access to this information to its own staff," Sen. Wyden said.
Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.
Write to Dustin Volz at
dustin.volz@wsj.com
and Warren P. Strobel at
Warren.Strobel@wsj.com

title: U.S. News: Ohio to Close Primary Polls Over Virus Fears
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON -- As former Vice President Joe Biden and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders square off for a third straight Tuesday of big primary contests, the coronavirus pandemic is increasingly pulling the attention of Americans away from the Democratic presidential race and causing uncertainty around voting.
An Ohio court on Monday evening rejected Republican Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine's request to postpone the state's Tuesday primary. But the primary was still thrust into chaos as Mr. DeWine declared that the state's top health official will order polls closed on Tuesday as a "health emergency."
"During this time when we face an unprecedented public health crisis, to conduct an election tomorrow would force poll workers and voters to place themselves at an unacceptable health risk of contracting coronavirus," Mr. DeWine tweeted hours after a judge ruled in favor of the primary taking place as planned.
Those developments came as Georgia, Louisiana and Kentucky, which had been set to hold primaries in the coming weeks, postponed them.
Three other states set to hold primaries Tuesday -- Arizona, Florida and Illinois -- appeared to be moving forward as planned, but each state moved some polling places away from nursing homes and other vulnerable sites.
On Monday, the Florida Democratic Party called on Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis to release an updated statewide list of polling sites and said party workers had begun calling and texting more than 126,700 voters who, by their estimate, live in an affected precinct and haven't yet voted.
Asked if the state planned to release a comprehensive list, a spokesman for the Florida Department of State said that voters should check with their local election supervisors.
In Illinois, the Board of Elections said the state is proceeding with Tuesday's primary as scheduled despite an order from Gov. J.B. Pritzker requiring that all restaurants and bars close for dine-in customers for a period of two weeks.
The board's spokesman said early voting has been encouraged and local election authorities have received guidance for coronavirus safety in their polling places. "Primary voting typically is a swift transaction that can be done at a safe distance from other voters," Matt Dietrich, the spokesman, said.
Across the country, voters are likely to see several precautionary measures, such as frequently cleaned voting machines, hand sanitizer and more breaks for poll workers to wash their hands.
Mr. Biden is strongly favored in the states scheduled to vote Tuesday and could further cement his path to the nomination if he scores big victories over Mr. Sanders, whose aides acknowledged the senator faces an uphill battle.
In last week's Washington state primary, Mr. Biden narrowly defeated Mr. Sanders, according to projections Monday from the Associated Press. Mr. Biden's victory means he won five of the six states that held contests March 10.
The pandemic has drastically altered the shape of the campaigns, with strict guidance against large gatherings nationwide. Mr. Biden and Mr. Sanders have both relied on digital events since last Tuesday, when both canceled election-night rallies.
---
Dustin Volz contributed to this article.

title: Presidential Candidates Use Spanish Ads, Events to Court Latinos in Primary Race; Hispanics could surpass black voters as largest minority voting bloc in U.S. next year
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Sen. Elizabeth Warren's campaign translates some Nevada events from English to Spanish in real time to engage with Spanish-speaking audience members. Organizers for South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg routinely hand out materials targeting Latino voters at naturalization ceremonies.
Former Vice President Joe Biden's campaign runs Spanish-language phone banks in states like Nevada. And the campaign of Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders says it has held at least 250 bilingual volunteer events with more than 3,200 attendees.
Democratic presidential candidates and
President Trump
are seeking new ways to use Spanish-language events and messages to make inroads with an estimated 32 million eligible Latino voters,
a key constituency
that could surpass black voters as the largest minority voting bloc in the U.S. next year.
In 2018, the number of Hispanics who turned out to vote reached 11.7 million, nearly double the 6.8 million in 2014, which Pew Research Center said was the single largest increase on record from one midterm election to another.
Activists have warned the Democratic Party against taking these voters for granted in the general election, but Latinos are also being wooed in the primaries in states where they make up a significant chunk of the electorate.
More than half of U.S. Latinos live in three states—California, Florida and Texas—that account for a big share of delegates to the 2020 Democratic National Convention. Nevada also has a large Latino population and plays an outsize role in picking the nominee because its caucuses are the third state contest.
Campaigns "should be spending a lot of time, energy and resources looking at what makes this community of voters tick," said political strategist Lorena Chambers. "What's going to compel them to come out and vote? We want to be excited about voting."
She said that isn't limited to advertising in Spanish. "It has to be culturally correct," she said, adding that if Spanish is used, it is important to keep in mind differences based on bilingual households, age or the country of origin. Recent Pew Research Center studies have shown English is rising among younger Latinos but Spanish is often still spoken at home.
Spokespeople from Spanish-language television network Univision Communications Inc. and Comcast Corp.'s Telemundo said they each have ad buys from more than one presidential campaign. They said the networks have seen more interest in political advertising to the growing number of Latino voters than in the past election cycles.
Andrew Polsky, chief revenue officer of Hispanic mobile-ad company Adsmovil, said his firm is working with presidential candidates on ads geared toward Latino voters. He expects more such advertising as the primaries pick up next year.
Of the roughly 25 million U.S. Hispanics in Adsmovil's data-management program, 14.9 million prefer to receive messages in Spanish and 10.6 million prefer English, according to the company.
So far, Mr. Sanders's campaign in particular has made Latino voters central to its strategy. National polls show him and Mr. Biden at the front of the pack among Latinos.
The Sanders campaign, which says it has at least 80 Latino staffers nationwide, has launched Spanish-language phone banks and sends text messages in Spanish to remind Latino voters to register to vote or attend events. His campaign is running ads in Spanish that highlight issues dominating the Democratic primary, such as health care, climate change and income inequality.
Last month, he unveiled an immigration plan designed by three campaign staffers who are undocumented immigrants and beneficiaries of former President Obama's Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program. And in mid-December, New York Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who has endorsed Mr. Sanders, participated in a Nevada town-hall meeting that was entirely in Spanish.
Mr. Biden's campaign, meanwhile, has rolled out endorsements from dozens of Latino leaders, including some members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus. Spanish-language ads released by his campaign draw a contrast with Mr. Trump and his immigration policies, casting the former vice president as best positioned to unite a divided country.
Melissa Michelson, a political-science professor at Menlo College in California whose work has focused on Latino and minority politics, said voters in that group are driven by the same priorities as the broader Democratic electorate.
"They're concerned about electability," Ms. Michelson said. "They want a candidate who's going to beat Donald Trump."
Mr. Trump's re-election campaign has been courting Latino voters with advertising, events and volunteer training in Florida, the battleground he narrowly won in 2016, and more than a dozen other swing states, a senior Trump campaign official said. It has been running Spanish-language digital ads since March, the official said.
Ads in Spanish and English are designed to appeal to Hispanic diaspora communities who fled socialist countries, like Venezuela, but also focus more broadly on job opportunities, the tax bill, the economy and criminal-justice reform.
The campaign also plans to increase in the coming months Spanish-language ads geared toward increasing Latino turnout at Trump rallies, the official said.
Still, some of the messaging stands in contrast to the Trump campaign's Facebook ads targeting the broader electorate, which highlight his attempts to crack down on immigration and ask supporters to sign petitions to "deport illegals."
Democrats contend that Mr. Trump's rhetoric on immigration has cemented their standing among Latinos.
Other top-polling Democratic candidates, such Ms. Warren and Mr. Buttigieg, are still seeking to gain traction among Latino voters.
Mr. Buttigieg's campaign has focused not just on the early battleground of Nevada, where it recently bought Spanish-language radio and digital ads, but also on rural parts of Iowa and New Hampshire, where it contends Latino voters are being overlooked. Mr. Sanders has also dedicated some of his ad spending to reaching Latino voters in Iowa.
Ms. Warren has homed in on Nevada, where her campaign has had Spanish speakers on the ground since its launch, according to her Nevada political director Michelle Villegas.
A September poll from Univision found 73% of Latinos said they plan to vote for the Democratic nominee in the general election next year, whereas 16% planned to vote for Mr. Trump, and 11% were undecided.
Write to Sabrina Siddiqui at
Sabrina.Siddiqui@wsj.com
and Emily Glazer at
emily.glazer@wsj.com

title: Nevada Win Gives Sanders The Inside Track --- Victory bolsters his case as front-runner, worrying Democrats seeking a centrist
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
HOUSTON -- Bernie Sanders's resounding victory in the weekend's Nevada caucuses cast him as the clear front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination and enhanced the Vermont senator's argument that he can build a diverse coalition of voters ahead of potentially decisive contests.
At the same time, the senator's latest win, and his momentum ahead of next Saturday's South Carolina primary and the Super Tuesday contests March 3, are stirring increasing anxiety among some establishment Democrats who believe a more centrist nominee would have a better chance to beat President Trump in November and help carry down-ballot candidates across the finish line. If Mr. Sanders, a self-described democratic socialist, performs well on March 3, when more than one-third of the total convention delegates are up for grabs, it could be difficult for any Democratic rival to overtake him.
Mr. Sanders has said he can expand the electorate by bringing in new voters, which would help him overcome any concerns about ideology in a general election.
Nevada, a more diverse state than mostly white Iowa and New Hampshire, gave Mr. Sanders the first opportunity to show he can build the "multigeneration, multiracial coalition" he has said will propel him. This year's Nevada caucuses are on track to break turnout records.
"We have won the popular vote in Iowa, we won the New Hampshire primary, we won the Nevada caucus," Mr. Sanders told supporters in Houston on Sunday, at a rally ahead of the March 3 Texas primary. "Don't tell anybody this, these folks get very, very agitated and nervous, we're gonna win here in Texas, and in November, we're going to defeat Trump here in Texas."
Mr. Sanders's strong position shows the appeal of running as antiestablishment on both sides of the aisle; Mr. Trump, after all, ran as a GOP outsider in 2016. The Vermont senator's position would have been unimaginable five years ago, when the independent, who has never changed his party affiliation to Democrat in the Senate, launched his first long-shot bid for the presidency.
But with his policy positions long seen as far to the left of many Democrats, many party veterans are haunted by the memory of liberal Sen. George McGovern's 49-state loss to GOP President Richard Nixon in 1972. A nomination of Mr. Sanders would mark a decisive break with the more center-left path forged by Bill Clinton in 1992 and Barack Obama in 2008.
Mr. Sanders leads Mr. Trump in a poll of a general-election matchup, although his margin is thinner than those of some other top contenders.
With about 88% of Nevada precincts reporting Sunday evening, former Vice President Joe Biden -- a more moderate candidate who was the national polling leader for most of 2019 -- was in second place, followed by Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Ind., and Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts. Billionaire activist Tom Steyer looked set to place fifth while Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar followed closely behind in sixth.
Mr. Biden attended church services on Sunday in a predominantly black neighborhood of North Charleston, S.C. In an acknowledgment of Mr. Sanders's strength in the three prior contests, Mr. Biden told reporters: "Whoever wins this primary is going into Super Tuesday very strongly, and I think it's going to be Bernie and me going into Super Tuesday."
According to entrance polls in Nevada, Mr. Sanders won nearly every demographic segment -- including voters ages 17 to 64, white voters, Latino voters and first time caucus-goers. The only segments he lost to Mr. Biden were black voters, voters over age 65 and voters opposed to a single-payer health-care system.
Mr. Sanders's coalition will be put to the test in the next round of states. In his unsuccessful 2016 primary bid against Hillary Clinton, he struggled to bring in support from minorities.
While Mr. Sanders trails Mr. Biden in South Carolina, a Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released Friday showed the two men running even among black Democratic primary voters nationally, a crucial part of Mr. Biden's constituency.
Mr. Biden mingled with churchgoers who generally represent his base of support. Ken Morris, a 68-year-old retired member of the Marine Corps, said he believed Mr. Sanders couldn't win the general election.
"There's not too many people who believe in socialism," Mr. Morris said. "Joe is more centrist. More people trust him. You can't beat a guy who is all the way to the right by going all the way to the left."
Voters, particularly those who are younger, say Mr. Sanders's consistency on the issues of health care, climate change and education is why they back him. Some older voters who were skeptical of Mr. Sanders say they see he has the momentum -- backed by a swell of enthusiastic young supporters -- to win.
Steve McCormack, a 49-year-old business owner from the Houston suburb of The Woodlands, attended Mr. Sanders's Houston rally on Sunday. Mr. McCormack voted for Florida Sen. Marco Rubio in the 2016 GOP primary and sat out the general election.
But this cycle, Mr. McCormack said is going to vote "blue no matter who," and he believes Mr. Sanders may be the nominee.
"I see it might be going this way" toward Mr. Sanders winning the primary, he said.
But some Democrats and groups looking to boost centrists aren't ready to concede.
"The race is not over, said Jonathan Kott, executive director of the Big Tent Project, which is running ads opposing Mr. Sanders in South Carolina. "You have a lot of people still in the race, you have a lot of people that could win in different states."
---
Natalie Andrews, Chad Day, Joshua Jamerson, Tarini Parti and Emily Glazer contributed to this article.

title: Bernie Sanders's Revolution Has a Math Problem; The Vermont senator would need to win roughly 63% of the remaining unallocated Democratic delegates to win the presidential nomination
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
The political revolution Bernie Sanders hoped would sweep him into the White House has run into the cold, hard realities of math: He needs to win roughly 63% of the remaining unallocated Democratic delegates to overtake Joe Biden and win the presidential nomination.
To capture that many delegates, the Vermont senator would likely need to notch a victory in every state by significant margins because Democrats award delegates proportionally rather than using a winner-take-all system. That means the former vice president would continue to collect some, even if he lost momentum.
"The math would require an unprecedented turn of events that has Joe Biden winning these contests by 30 to 40 percentage points, to Bernie winning by 30 to 40 percentage points to cover lost ground and get back into this race," said George Hornedo, a delegate strategist for Pete Buttigieg's former presidential campaign. "That's just not going to happen unless there is some catastrophic event."
Mr. Hornedo said no Democratic candidate in modern history has ever come back from a delegate deficit as large as the one Mr. Sanders faces. Mr. Biden leads by 296 delegates as of late Wednesday afternoon, following
double-digit victories in a trio of states
—Arizona, Illinois and Florida—on Tuesday.
Those victories follow wins in about three-fourths of the states that voted earlier this month.
In an email to supporters Wednesday, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager, Faiz Shakir, said Mr. Sanders and his wife, Jane Sanders, would head back Wednesday to Burlington, Vt., where they will
assess the path forward
.
"No sugarcoating it, last night did not go the way we wanted," Mr. Shakir wrote. "And while our campaign has won the battle of ideas, we are losing the battle over electability to Joe Biden."
The Sanders campaign declined to comment on his difficult path.
"The margins that Biden is winning by are telling us that people are ready for this to be done," said Mr. Hornedo. "He has a lead that is insurmountable."
The delegate math is made even more complicated by the coronavirus pandemic that has upended normal life, including the voting process. Multiple states have already delayed their contests and more may do so.
During this year's earliest primaries and caucuses, Mr. Sanders benefited from a crowded field that splintered the vote and delegates among multiple candidates. In a two-way race, he is no longer being boosted by the vote fracturing.
This week's primaries are a good example of why it would be so hard for Mr. Sanders to catch up. While not all delegates have been allocated yet, Mr. Biden has so far won 66.9% of those awarded from Tuesday's contests.
A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released Sunday showed the race doesn't look better for Mr. Sanders going forward. Mr. Biden led by 63% to 30% among primary voters in states that had already held primaries or caucuses and by 60% to 34% in the states that had yet to vote.
The first candidate to reach 1,991 delegates, or a majority of the total delegates, will be the nominee. But the system is set up so that can't happen quickly.
Even if Mr. Sanders were to drop out of the race this week, it would likely take Mr. Biden until at least early May to secure the delegates needed to win the nomination. That assumes more contests aren't pushed back later because of the national crisis.
Mr. Sanders has said he would do everything he could to help Mr. Biden win a general election if he were to lose the nomination.
In an interview with the Journal last week, Jane Sanders said she was hoping the campaign would turn around. But if Mr. Biden becomes the nominee, "Our role is clear: Help him to defeat Donald Trump," she said.
Then, Mrs. Sanders said, the Sanders family and progressive allies would keep up the leftward pressure on a Biden administration.
Write to Eliza Collins at
eliza.collins@wsj.com.
and John McCormick at
mccormick.john@wsj.com

title: Big Michigan Turnout a Boost for Joe Biden—and a Warning for President Trump; State's Democrats flocked to the polls, specifically to back Biden; if they do the same in November, Trump may struggle for a repeat victory
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Nearly 380,000 more people voted in Michigan this year than in the state's 2016 Democratic primary, a 30% increase. And yet Sen. Bernie Sanders, in all-but-complete results, wound up with fewer votes than last time. Former Vice President Joe Biden, alone, benefited from the surge.
Of all the statistics arising from
Mr. Biden's dominating victories
in four primaries on Tuesday, those numbers are among the most revealing about the Democratic Party as it sorts out its presidential nominee.
Political analysts said the results signaled that Mr. Biden was unifying the party, leaving Mr. Sanders with few voter groups with which to build a competing coalition. And the big uptick in Democratic turnout, they said, suggested that Michigan likely would be tougher for President Trump than in 2016, when he carried the state by fewer than 11,000 votes.
"I don't know how you read the results any other way than that Michigan will be a more challenging state for the president,'' said Whit Ayres, a pollster and analyst whose clients have included Republican senators and presidential candidates.
Tim Murtaugh, communications director for Mr. Trump's re-election campaign, said that his coalition is growing and that the Michigan results showed high enthusiasm for the president. Mr. Trump, he said, "has energized young voters like no other Republican candidate before him, while it's clear that Joe Biden will have a youth problem." Exit polls showed Mr. Biden trailing Mr. Sanders by four-to-one among voters under age 30 in Michigan.
Mr. Biden's victories on Tuesday were sweeping. He carried every county in Missouri, Mississippi and Michigan on the way to winning four of the five states where the outcome was known, losing only North Dakota. Messrs. Biden and Sanders were tied as of Wednesday in a sixth primary, in Washington state, where the count was incomplete.
Within those tallies were signs of the broad coalition that Mr. Biden has been able to build, and of what that might mean both for the primaries to come and in November.
In Michigan, Mr. Biden benefited from the same surge of affluent, college-educated voters who
helped revive his campaign in Super Tuesday voting
last week and make him the Democratic primary front-runner. But he also won substantial victories among blue-collar voters in Michigan, the first Midwestern industrial state to vote and one of the most important battlegrounds for the fall.
While Mr. Sanders has promised to ignite a grass-roots, workers' movement, it was Mr. Biden who united the Democratic Party's professional class and its working class.
Combined with Mr. Biden's strength among black voters, the results suggest that Mr. Sanders is having trouble building support beyond his base of young voters—a shrinking share of the voter pool, compared with 2016—and Hispanic voters, who didn't have a large presence in the states that voted on Tuesday.
Mr. Biden can point to Tuesday's results to support his claim to have the stronger appeal among two voting groups important to his party's prospects in November.
One is the white, working-class voters of the industrial Midwest, whom Mr. Trump moved so successfully into the GOP in Michigan, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Ohio. The other group is college-educated, suburban voters who swung behind Democratic candidates in 2018 and gave them a majority in the House.
Two counties in Michigan show Mr. Biden's strength with these groups—and how much ground Mr. Sanders has lost since his 2016 campaign.
With its cluster of hospitals and "medical mile,'' Kent County includes Grand Rapids, the state's second-largest city, and has many of the voters with college and advanced degrees who are increasingly aligning with the Democratic Party. Mr. Sanders won it by 25 percentage points in 2016. In a significant reversal, he narrowly lost the county on Tuesday.
Voting surged by 50% over 2016 levels in Kent County, but Mr. Sanders barely kept pace with his vote total from the last election. The additional voters came out to support Mr. Biden. Mr. Ayres saw it as a continuation of a trend from 2018, in which moderate, suburban voters rejected Republican incumbents and helped return Democrats to a majority in the House.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
What do the results from Tuesday's primaries reveal to you about the electorate in 2020? Join the conversation below.
Macomb County, outside Detroit, includes auto industry employers and many blue-collar workers. Mr. Sanders had kept the race close there in 2016, winning 47% of the vote. But he was routed on Tuesday, carrying only 35% to Mr. Biden's 51%.
Bernie Porn, president of the polling firm Epic MRA, said he believed many voters who cast ballots on Tuesday had skipped primaries in the past and voted only in general elections, an idea that can be tested in about a month, when the state updates its voter data.These voters tend to be less ideologically driven than are core members of a political party—that is, more welcoming of Mr. Biden than of Mr. Sanders, who calls for "revolutionary'' change.
Kent County represents the Democrats' aspirations for drawing new, suburban voters to the party. Macomb County represents its hopes to regain blue-collar voters who were once a pillar of the party's support.
Both counties backed Mr. Trump in 2016, then two years later supported Democrats for the Senate and governor by narrow margins, raising the party's hopes that they could win the counties this fall.
More
*
Takeaways From Tuesday's Election Contests

*
Biden Notches Key Win in Michigan Primary

*
Tracking the Delegate Counts

Write to Aaron Zitner at
Aaron.Zitner@dowjones.com
and Dante Chinni at
Dante.Chinni@wsj.com

title: Both Sides Take a Last Shot at Trial Of President
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON -- House managers said President Trump was a threat to American democracy, while his defense team countered that Democrats were trying to undermine two elections, in their final arguments in his Senate impeachment trial on Monday.
With Democrats set to fall well short of the two-thirds threshold needed to remove Mr. Trump from office in the final vote later this week, they used their turns at the lectern to issue a warning to the Senate, focusing on what they saw as the danger presented by Mr. Trump remaining in office.
"He has betrayed our national security and he will do so again," said Rep. Adam Schiff (D., Calif.), the lead impeachment manager and chairman of the House Intelligence Committee. "He has compromised our elections and he will do so again. You will not change him. You cannot constrain him. He is who he is. . . . Now, do impartial justice and convict him."
The two articles of impeachment center on Mr. Trump's pressing Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and other matters that could help Mr. Trump politically in this year's election, and the president's alleged efforts to obstruct Congress's inquiry into those actions.
Mr. Trump has denied wrongdoing and again called impeachment a hoax on Twitter on Monday.
His legal team, in their presentation, painted Democrats' pursuit of impeachment as purely political, driven by a longstanding dislike of Mr. Trump, a Republican.
"At the end of the day, this is an effort to overturn the results of one election and to try to interfere in the coming election that begins today in Iowa," said White House counsel Pat Cipollone. Iowa's caucuses on Monday evening kicked off the Democratic and GOP nominating contests.
"What the House Democrats have done to this nation, to the Constitution, to the office of the president, to the president himself and to this body is outrageous," said another Trump lawyer, Jay Sekulow.
The two sides gave their final pitches Monday to the jury of 100 senators who had largely made up their minds on impeachment, broadly unmoved by three weeks of presentations and arguments.
An acquittal for Mr. Trump is expected on Wednesday. Twenty Republicans would have to join the entire Democratic caucus to vote to remove the president. No Republicans have said they favor impeachment, and just two supported Democrats' effort last week to seek more evidence in the trial, which failed 51-49.
Democratic senators emerged from the trial frustrated that most GOP senators had rejected bringing in new witnesses and information. Republicans countered that the House impeachment probe should have sought more evidence, which was blocked by the White House, before turning the matter over to the Senate.
"I'm trying to find the Senate rule that says for senators to plug their ears with cotton so they don't have to listen to the hard facts," Sen. Ron Wyden (D., Ore.) said.
Some Republicans, including Sens. Pat Roberts of Kansas and Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, said they believe Mr. Trump engaged in improper behavior, but that it didn't rise to an impeachable offense. But others were unconvinced.
Mr. Trump's defense team "raised a reasonable doubt as to the crime -- the whatever -- that was alleged," Sen. Bill Cassidy (R., La.) said.
Democrats allege in the first article of impeachment that Mr. Trump attempted to interfere with this year's presidential election by pressing Kyiv to probe Mr. Biden, a front-runner for the Democratic nomination. The second article accuses Mr. Trump of obstructing Congress's investigation by preventing witnesses from testifying and defying subpoenas for documentary evidence.
Mr. Trump and his allies have argued that Mr. Trump's interest in Mr. Biden was legitimate, alleging it was corrupt for Mr. Biden during the Obama administration to seek the ouster of a Ukrainian prosecutor who once investigated a Ukrainian gas company where Mr. Biden's son Hunter sat on the board. Mr. Biden sought the prosecutor's removal as part of a broad international effort to combat corruption in Ukraine.
The Bidens have denied wrongdoing. Hunter Biden has said it was poor judgment on his part to serve on the Burisma board while his father was vice president.
What isn't clear is whether the acquittal vote will be bipartisan. Some Democratic senators, such as Joe Manchin of West Virginia, Doug Jones of Alabama and Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, are undecided. Mr. Jones, representing a state that backed Mr. Trump by 28 points in the 2016 election, is the most vulnerable Democratic senator this cycle.
Mr. Manchin said Monday he remained undecided on how he will vote, but introduced a measure to censure Mr. Trump, saying it would "allow this body to unite across party lines . . . to formally denounce the president's actions."
While censure was mentioned at times last year by some House Democrats, it hasn't been seriously discussed by Republican or Democratic leadership. Many Senate Republicans said Mr. Trump did nothing wrong, and those who find his actions problematic haven't called for him to be rebuked by Congress.
"Too late. It's too late," said Sen Roy Blunt (R., Mo.), a member of GOP Senate leadership, about censure.
Mr. Trump is scheduled to give his State of the Union speech Tuesday, in the chamber where the House approved the articles of impeachment against him in December. Some Republicans hoped he would move beyond impeachment in the annual speech.
A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll found a majority of voters said they believed Mr. Trump abused his power by asking Ukraine to investigate a potential political opponent. But there wasn't majority support for removing him from office.
---
Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.

title: Biden Emphasizes Foreign Policy Background Amid Iran Tensions; The former vice president's record is under scrutiny from Democratic rivals
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—Joe Biden is highlighting his decades of foreign policy experience, warning that what he calls President Trump's brinkmanship with Iran could push the nation into another Middle East conflict.
But as Mr. Biden is calling attention to his foreign policy experience as a globe-trotting vice president and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, his rivals are questioning his judgment on national security decisions. Among them: his 2002 vote to authorize the Iraq war during the George W. Bush administration and his initial opposition to the raid that killed Osama bin Laden.
The former vice president called Mr. Trump "dangerously incompetent" in remarks in New York Tuesday. He pressed the Trump administration to justify the
killing of Iran's top military leader
last week and blasted the president's decision to leave the 2015 Iran nuclear agreement.
"We are alone now—we're alone, and we will have to bear the cost of Donald Trump's folly," Mr. Biden said.
The Trump administration has said the strike that killed Qassem Soleimani, the second most powerful man in Iran, was necessary to avert an "imminent" threat to Americans. Mr. Trump said the intelligence he relied on to order the strike is classified for now but that details would be shared with members of Congress on Wednesday.
Related
*
Iran Threatens Retaliatory Attack; U.S. Says It Acted in Self-Defense

*
Warren Proposes Bankruptcy Overhaul in Return to Signature Issue

*
Warren Is 'With Bernie'—Except When It Comes to Capitalism

With less than a month before the Iowa caucuses, the Trump administration's escalating tensions with Iran could both elevate Mr. Biden among his Democratic rivals in the eyes of some voters and invite scrutiny.
The focus on Mr. Biden's foreign policy resume will also test voters' interest in Washington experience against the backdrop of a president who has often disrupted norms and flouted international conventions. If elected, Mr. Biden would enter office with more than four decades in Washington, vastly more than the four years Mr. Obama accumulated before winning the White House. (Mr. Trump and Mr. Obama's two predecessors, Presidents George W. Bush and Bill Clinton, had no Washington experience before their presidencies.)
"Fear historically instills in people a desire for stability and something they know," said Jen Psaki, a State Department spokeswoman under Mr. Obama. "If it follows that historical context, ultimately the fact that Joe Biden is a familiar face and has a long interest and history in foreign policy—and has sat in the Situation Room—could be comforting to people watching."
Until this month, foreign policy hasn't played a central role in the 2020 Democratic primary, taking a back seat to domestic issues such as health care, the economy and electability.
A
CNN poll
in November showed Mr. Biden with a significant advantage among Democrats on foreign policy. But Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and former South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg have tried to turn Mr. Biden's foreign policy record into a liability, focusing on his vote to authorize the invasion of Iraq. Mr. Obama used Hillary Clinton's Iraq vote against her in the run-up to his Iowa caucuses win a dozen years ago, as did Mr. Sanders during their 2016 primary race. Mr. Sanders had opposed the Iraq resolution as a House member.
In an interview Monday with CNN, Mr. Sanders said that Mr. Biden had "voted and helped lead the effort for the war in Iraq, the most dangerous foreign policy blunder in the modern history of this country."
Mr. Buttigieg, who served in Afghanistan as a Naval intelligence analyst, has called the Iraq invasion the worst foreign policy decision of his lifetime. He said it shows "why years in Washington is not always the same thing as judgment."
At an event last weekend in Des Moines, Iowa, a young man pressed Mr. Biden on his Iraq war vote and the bin Laden raid and asked, "How can we trust your judgment?"
Mr. Biden suggested that he was misled on Iraq by President George W. Bush, saying that Mr. Bush had told him he only wanted to send in inspectors to determine whether Saddam Hussein had nuclear weapons.
"The president then went ahead with 'Shock and Awe,' and right after that and from the very moment he did that, I opposed what he was doing," Mr. Biden said.
Mr. Biden's past statements, however, suggest he did not immediately oppose the war once it began in March 2003. In July 2003, Mr. Biden said during a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing, "I voted to go into Iraq, and I'd vote to do it again."
Discussing in Des Moines, Iowa, the bin Laden raid, Mr. Biden said that he had suggested in the Situation Room in front of other advisers that Mr. Obama "do another pass to determine whether (bin Laden was) there." However, he said, in the Oval Office, he had privately offered this advice to Mr. Obama: "Mr. President, follow your instincts, go."
At a 2012 House Democratic retreat, however, Mr. Biden said that his recommendation to Mr. Obama had been: "Don't go." Republicans have seized on Mr. Biden's different versions on the matter.
"Biden can't get his story straight. He used to say he advised Obama AGAINST the bin Laden raid. Now he denies it. Biden's foreign policy failures are a glaring liability for his 2020 campaign," tweeted Ronna McDaniel, the chairwoman of the Republican National Committee.
Mr. Biden's advisers dismiss such criticism of his record.
"The Republicans are going to try to manufacture issues, as this president has, as the Republican party has, about Joe Biden and about any other Democrat they think can be competitive in the general election against Donald Trump," said Anita Dunn, a top adviser to Mr. Biden.
Alex Leary contributed to this article.
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com
and Sabrina Siddiqui at
Sabrina.Siddiqui@wsj.com

title: Michael Bloomberg Ends Presidential Bid and Endorses Joe Biden; In three months, former New York City mayor spent hundreds of millions of dollars
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Michael Bloomberg is ending his presidential bid and endorsing Joe Biden, after the former New York City mayor spent hundreds of millions of dollars of his own money in an expensive bet on
Super Tuesday
states that was
ultimately unsuccessful
.
"After yesterday's results, the delegate math has become virtually impossible—and a viable path to the nomination no longer exists," Mr. Bloomberg said Wednesday.
"I've always believed that defeating Donald Trump starts with uniting behind the candidate with the best shot to do it. After yesterday's vote, it is clear that candidate is my friend and a great American, Joe Biden," he said. "I will work to make him the next president of the United States."
His endorsement is the latest in
a string of successes
for Mr. Biden, the former vice president, who picked up the
backing of three other ex-rivals
for the Democratic nomination before Super Tuesday.
Mr. Bloomberg called Mr. Biden Wednesday, according to a campaign aide for the former mayor, who said they had a "great conversation."
Mr. Bloomberg announced his decision in a senior staff meeting on Wednesday. An email was then sent out to all staffers, followed by a staff call with campaign manager Kevin Sheekey and states director Dan Kanninen, according to the aide.
The former New York City mayor had earned just a few dozen delegates by Wednesday, as they were still being allocated, after spending $215 million
on TV and radio ads
in the 14 states that voted. The only contest he won was in American Samoa. Mr. Bloomberg is expected to address his staff and supporters at an event in New York City Wednesday afternoon.
Mr. Bloomberg pitched himself as a nonideological executive focused on beating President Trump, with the slogan "Mike Will Get It Done" and his seemingly limitless resources. In the days before the polls opened in Super Tuesday states, Mr. Bloomberg pointed to the administration's handling of the coronavirus outbreak to argue that he would be a more competent leader, spending $1.5 million on a prime-time, three-minute ad on two television networks.
Overall, Mr. Bloomberg, who is worth $62 billion, spent at least $620 million to build a massive campaign operation of more than 2,400 people across the country and to blanket the airwaves and digital platforms.
Before dropping out, he had insisted for days that he was "in it to win it," while acknowledging that the only path for him to secure the Democratic nomination was through a contested convention.
Mr. Bloomberg had committed to keeping his organization even if he left the presidential race, saying he would pivot it toward helping the Democratic nominee and beating Mr. Trump. On Wednesday, following his endorsement of Mr. Biden, Mr. Bloomberg's advisers were still figuring out how that commitment would shape up.
Related
*
Biden, Sanders Look to Next Contests as Bloomberg Exits

*
Warren Loses Primary in Home State

*
Top Takeaways From Super Tuesday

*
Where the Race Goes From Here

*
Tracking the Delegate Counts

"Mike has always said he would put all of his resources in defeating Trump and has never shied away from tough battles," said Tim O'Brien, senior adviser for the campaign. "He deeply admires Joe Biden and will back his candidacy to the fullest extent."
Mr. Bloomberg launched his campaign in late November after growing concerned about the rise of liberal Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren. His advisers pointed to polling at the time that showed former Vice President Joe Biden, the most prominent moderate Democrat in the 2020 field, was within the margin of error in hypothetical matchups with Mr. Trump. Other candidates, they believed, would lose in the November election.
Mr. Bloomberg skipped the first four nominating contests because of his late entry, banking on the delegate-rich Super Tuesday states. And after Mr. Biden suffered big losses in Iowa and New Hampshire, Mr. Bloomberg appeared to have an opening.
But late in February came Mr. Biden's landslide
victory in South Carolina
, and the former vice president won the endorsements of three former presidential candidates. Mr. Biden ended up
racking up delegates on Super Tuesday
, crushing Mr. Bloomberg and other contenders in several states.
The former mayor's reasoning for entering the race was shattered by Mr. Biden's string of victories, leaving Mr. Bloomberg with no choice Wednesday morning but to drop out, according to people familiar with his decision-making.
Based on its internal data, Mr. Bloomberg's campaign saw a big shift after South Carolina, according to a campaign aide. In states where many people voted early or by mail, such as Colorado and Utah, Mr. Bloomberg performed better.
Mr. Bloomberg's momentum going into Super Tuesday was also blunted after he suffered one abysmal and one mediocre debate performance. The three-term New York mayor was grilled on the debate stage, in interviews and on the campaign trail about
stop-and-frisk
, a policing practice that his administration enforced and that a federal judge ruled was unconstitutional for violating the rights of minorities.
Mr. Bloomberg apologized for the practice before launching his White House bid and continued to do so during his campaign, including when audio of him staunchly defending the practice surfaced.
He also saw criticism over allegations of inappropriate comments toward women who worked for him at Bloomberg LP. Ms. Warren hammered him during the first Democratic debate for signing nondisclosure agreements with some of those women. Two days later, Mr. Bloomberg announced he would release three women who had made complaints against him from their agreements.
With Mr. Bloomberg bowing out of the race, the news unit of his financial data and media company announced it was casting aside restrictions that limited investigative coverage of him and his Democratic rivals. The rules had drawn criticism from Republicans because the company continued investigating Mr. Trump's administration. At times, the administration barred Bloomberg News reporters from some campaign events.
"Now that Mike has said he is leaving the race for president, we will return to our normal coverage of the election; we will follow exactly the same coverage rules for the Democratic presidential candidates and President Donald Trump," the news arm's editor in chief, John Micklethwait, wrote in a memo to staff.
Mr. Micklethwait said the company would add lines disclosing any financial support Mr. Bloomberg gives to other Democratic candidates to any stories about the race.
Lukas Alpert contributed to this article.
Write to Tarini Parti at
Tarini.Parti@wsj.com
