title: New Hampshire Democratic Debate: The Moments That Mattered; Days before the first-in-nation primary, Pete Buttigieg and Bernie Sanders drew the most attention after their strong finish in Iowa
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Seven Democratic presidential candidates
took the stage
in New Hampshire on Friday night, days ahead of the state's the first-in-the-nation primary next week.
The top finishers in the
Iowa caucuses
this week, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and former South Bend, Ind. Mayor Pete Buttigieg drew the most attention from their rivals. Former Vice President Joe Biden and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, whose Iowa results fell short of what they'd hoped, tried to make their case to voters across the country. Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar, billionaire climate activist Tom Steyer and entrepreneur Andrew Yang also shared the debate stage. The candidates squared off over experience and who was best suited to take on President Donald Trump in the general election.
Pete Buttigieg was in opponents' crosshairs.
"We have a newcomer in the White House, and look where it got us."—Amy Klobuchar
Why this matters: Ms. Klobuchar was citing President Trump's political novelty as she hit Pete Buttigieg over his inexperience compared with the other top Democratic contenders. Ms. Klobuchar and Joe Biden trained their ire on Mr. Buttigieg, the 38-year-old former mayor of South Bend, Ind., who appears to have tied with Mr. Sanders to win the Iowa caucuses this week. The trio of more moderate candidates are vying for independents in New Hampshire and center-left Democrats across the country.
As she warned that the country shouldn't take another risk on a political newcomer, Ms. Klobuchar also chided Mr. Buttigieg, "Mayor Pete, while three of us were jurors in the impeachment hearing, you said you wanted to turn the channel and watch cartoons. It's easy to go after Washington. It's much harder to lead."
Mr. Buttigieg responded to those kinds of attacks by contrasting himself to the third-term Minnesota senator and Mr. Biden, a senator and vice president for 4½ decades. "We cannot solve the problems before us by looking back," Mr. Buttigieg said.
Bernie Sanders pressed on identifying as a "democratic socialist."
"Bernie said he wrote the damn bill, but didn't say how he'll pay for the damn thing."—Joe Biden
Why this matters: Mr. Biden hammered Mr. Sanders over his refusal to talk about how he would fund his Medicare for All plan. The candidates opened the three-hour debate with a discussion of their health care plans—and immediately showed more willingness to confront each other than in past debates. Early on, a moderator asked the candidates to raise their hands if they thought having a democratic socialist at the top of the ticket was a problem. Ms. Klobuchar appeared to be the only candidate on the stage to do so.
Earlier, Mr. Biden had said that Mr. Trump would apply the label socialist to "everyone running with Bernie if he's the nominee." Mr. Sanders responded to such criticism by saying Mr. Trump lies about everything, so it doesn't matter what people worry he might say. He also argued he could bring broad swaths of Americans together by rallying them around more affordable health care and decrying income inequality.
Michael Bloomberg looms large despite not being on stage.
"I don't think anyone ought to be able to buy their way into the nomination or being president of the United States."—Elizabeth Warren
Why this matters: The debate moderators asked the candidates on stage what they thought about billionaire former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg's self-financed effort to win the Democratic nomination despite sitting out the first four primary contests. Mr. Bloomberg hasn't qualified for any of the debates so far, but the Democratic National Committee recently changed its criteria in such a way that he could be on future stages.
Ms. Klobuchar cited her working-class upbringing and spouted another Trump-themed zinger. "I don't think people look at the guy in the White House and think, 'Can we get someone richer?'"
A moderator baited Mr. Sanders on the topic by saying the former mayor had said "we need evolution, not revolution," a riff on Mr. Sanders's campaign theme. Mr. Sanders called it "nonsense" that Mr. Bloomberg can spend hundreds of millions of dollars on his own campaign, and plugged his 1.5 million donors who had given an average of just over $18 each.
Candidates wrestle with abortion and the Supreme Court.
"I will never nominate any person to the Supreme Court or the federal courts in general who is not 100% pro Roe V. Wade."—Bernie Sanders
Why This Matters: Other candidates on stage gave sometimes meandering answers to a question about whether they would only nominate Supreme Court judges who would keep abortion legal. "I would only appoint judges that would respect precedent. And one of those key precedents is Roe v. Wade," Ms. Klobuchar said. Mr. Biden gave a lengthy answer about the kinds of justices he had backed in the past.
Mr. Sanders said that he would only nominate justices fully supportive of upholding Roe v. Wade, referring to the 1973 court decision that legalized abortion. Billionaire Tom Steyer said he, too, has a litmus test and argued that all of the candidates were in agreement. "Everybody on this row feels exactly the same way about a woman's right to choose," he said.
Candidates forced to disavow their own surrogates
"I believe he's sorry for what he said."—Joe Biden
Why this matters: Mr. Steyer confronted Mr. Biden over a remark that his longtime friend and campaign surrogate in South Carolina Dick Harpootlian made. Mr. Harpootlian, a Democratic state senator, said the head of the state's black legislative caucus only backed Mr. Steyer because he was paid to do so, something other black lawmakers decried as a racist remark. Mr. Harpootlian denies that his comment was racially motivated, according to the Associated Press, and on the debate stage, Mr. Biden said he'd spoken to Mr. Harpootlian and believed he was sorry.
Soon after, a debate moderator asked Mr. Sanders about an opinion piece his campaign co-chair Nina Turner wrote asserting that Mr. Biden has "repeatedly betrayed black voters." Mr. Sanders said he did not agree with Ms. Turner's assessment. "Joe Biden is a friend of mine, and I'm not here to attack him," he said.
Write to Julie Bykowicz at
julie.bykowicz@wsj.com

title: Joe Biden Faces Competition for Diverse Coalition From Bernie Sanders; The race for the Democratic nomination heads to South Carolina, where black voters make up more than half of the party electorate
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
LAS VEGAS—Joe Biden has made the case for months that he can best appeal to black, Latino and moderate voters. But after the Nevada caucuses, Bernie Sanders is the one beginning to show the makings of a broad electoral coalition.
The Vermont senator's
decisive victory Saturday
was powered by a diverse set of voters, including overwhelming support among Latinos and young people drawn to his calls for an expansive government-run health care program and the elimination of student debt.
Mr. Sanders's ability to build upon that coalition will help dictate whether he is able to prevent the former vice president from notching a victory on Feb. 29 in South Carolina, where
black voters
make up more than half of the Democratic electorate. If Mr. Sanders edges Mr. Biden out there, he could be poised for a dominant run on March 3, when
a series of contests
including the diverse states of California, Texas and North Carolina will award about one-third of the delegates for the nomination.
"In Nevada, we have just put together a multi-generational, multi-racial coalition which is not only going to win in Nevada, it's going to sweep this country," Mr. Sanders said in San Antonio on Saturday night.
Mr. Biden took the stage at a Las Vegas union hall as results trickled in, seizing upon projections of a second-place finish—albeit distant—that he said would revitalize his campaign. By Sunday morning, he was at a Baptist church in North Charleston, S.C., opening a weeklong push to win the primary.
Beyond his connection with diverse voters, Mr. Biden's electability pitch has also centered on his ability to persuade suburban voters and disaffected Republicans in general election battleground states such as Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin.
Mr. Biden's campaign manager, Greg Schultz, said that despite Mr. Sanders's victories in New Hampshire and Nevada, he had not been able to generate the surges in voting that the senator has promised would help him beat President Trump in the November election.
"Their campaign continues to say, directly and indirectly, look at turnout, look at turnout, look at turnout," Mr. Schultz said. "And in none of the first three contests has there been this surge in turnout in what they think is their greatest asset."
Nevada's Democratic Party said about 75,000 people voted early ahead of Saturday's primaries, and turnout was expected to surpass the 85,000 who participated in 2016. But it was unclear if it would exceed the 118,000 who caucused in 2008. New Hampshire's turnout was higher than primaries in 2008 and 2016, while Iowa's turnout cleared the 2016 race there but fell short of 2008 numbers.
Entrance polls in Nevada showed Mr. Sanders capturing about half of Hispanic voters and triumphing among those with college degrees and without, union and non-union households and every age group except those age 65 and older, who supported Mr. Biden. The former vice president was backed by about one third of African-American voters, giving him an edge over Mr. Sanders, who was backed by about one quarter of black voters.
Maria Cardona, a Democratic strategist who isn't affiliated with a presidential campaign, credited Mr. Sanders with cultivating strong ties with the Latino community since the 2016 election, particularly among young people and millennials. She noted that since the last election, four million Latinos have turned age 18, giving Mr. Sanders a significant advantage that he could take into a general election.
"Sanders has done a really good job of transforming the electability argument. And the pendulum is swinging toward him right now," she said.
Mr. Biden's message focuses on protecting the Obamacare health care law he helped pass alongside President Obama and his work to curb gun violence.
Both issues sought to draw bright lines with Mr. Sanders, who has advocated for a Medicare-for-all health care overhaul that would eventually eliminate the private insurance system and who voted against legislation to institute background checks for gun purchases.
Days before the caucuses, Mr. Biden delivered a speech that emphasized Mr. Sanders's past support for providing gun manufacturers with protections from lawsuits, a position that the Vermont senator has since recanted.
After crippling losses in Iowa and New Hampshire, Mr. Biden will try to use his second-place finish in Nevada to help convince voters in South Carolina that he can serve as a more moderate alternative to Mr. Sanders.
South Carolina has long been viewed as a firewall for the Biden campaign. Depending on his performance, it could serve as a springboard into delegate-rich states or Mr. Biden's political Waterloo as he seeks the presidency for the third time.
"I think he does have momentum," Mr. Biden said of Mr. Sanders after attending church services Sunday in predominantly black North Charleston, S.C. But he added: "Whoever wins this primary is going into Super Tuesday very strongly, and I think it's going to be Bernie and me going into Super Tuesday."
Joshua Jamerson in North Charleston, S.C., contributed to this article.
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com

title: Democratic Candidates Sanders and Biden Report Jump in Fundraising; President Trump built campaign war chest to over $100 million in fourth quarter
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—Sen. Bernie Sanders collected $34.5 million in the fourth quarter, outpacing former Vice President Joe Biden, as both Democratic presidential candidates reported a fundraising surge with one month to go until the Iowa caucuses.
While Democrats brace for a costly—and potentially lengthy—primary season, Republican President Trump faces no significant intraparty opposition and continued to amass campaign cash. His campaign said it raised $46 million in the final three months of last year, its best fundraising quarter to date, and had a war chest of about $103 million.
The Democratic field's quarterly tallies so far more than double Mr. Trump's haul. But unlike the incumbent president, the Democratic hopefuls are entering a period of heavy spending in a primary still crowded with 14 candidates, even after
the exit of former Secretary of Housing
and Urban Development Julián Castro on Thursday.
Mr. Biden said he raised $22.7 million in the fourth quarter, his best number of the year. Mr. Biden, who has relied on larger donors who pay to attend fundraising events, told supporters in a video posted Thursday that his online contributions have increased.
Several other candidates have released their quarterly totals in recent days. Pete Buttigieg, the former South Bend, Ind., mayor, said Wednesday that
he had raised $24.7 million
, while tech entrepreneur and political newcomer Andrew Yang said Thursday that he raised $16.5 million, a sharp increase from the third quarter. Hawaii Rep. Tulsi Gabbard raised $3.4 million in the fourth quarter, according to her campaign.
Another top contender, Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, hasn't disclosed her fourth-quarter haul but said in
a fundraising plea last week
that she had raised $17 million headed into the final days of the quarter, a slowed pace from her third quarter, when she brought in $24.6 million.
None of the Democratic candidates have released their current cash on hand. All presidential campaigns must report fourth-quarter fundraising and spending activities to the Federal Election Commission by Jan. 31.
The Iowa caucuses are Feb. 3, and the New Hampshire primary is Feb. 11. The Democratic field also faces a potential shake-up deeper into the voting calendar, when former New York Mayor
Michael Bloomberg begins competing
in the states that vote March 3, a date known as Super Tuesday. The billionaire businessman entered the race just before Thanksgiving and has already spent $132 million on TV and radio commercials, according to advertising tracker Kantar/CMAG.
Mr. Biden was embarking on a bus tour of eastern Iowa on Thursday, boosted by the endorsement earlier in the day of Rep. Abby Finkenauer (D., Iowa), the first member of the state's congressional delegation to endorse a 2020 candidate. Meanwhile, Mr. Sanders unveiled a new campaign bus and recently increased his TV commercial bookings, according to Kantar/CMAG.
Mr. Sanders's latest haul, which is expected to lead the Democratic pack, is the most that any 2020 Democratic candidate has raised in a single quarter, and highlights the strength of his small-dollar fundraising operation. The Vermont senator has raised about $96 million since entering the race in February, through five million donations that averaged $18, his campaign said.
Mr. Sanders and Ms. Warren have sworn off events where they woo donors who can give the legal maximum of $2,800. Instead, they are counting on an army of smaller contributors who give online. That is also how Mr. Sanders funded his 2016 bid, when he raised more than $230 million but lost the primary to Hillary Clinton.
Mr. Biden has raised $59.5 million since his late April kickoff. Mr. Biden's campaign said its average contribution amount for the fourth quarter was $41.
Mr. Trump's campaign didn't share information about its average donation size, but he has done well with small online donors in addition to bigger givers. In all, his campaign raised about $143 million last year.
His incumbency enables him to ask individual donors for as much as $360,600 each, money that gets doled out to both his own campaign and to his fundraising partners: the Republican National Committee and state GOP parties. The campaign didn't disclose the joint fundraising totals on Thursday.
The eventual Democratic nominee will also be able to create a bigger-ticket fundraising operation.
Sitting presidents almost always enjoy strong fundraising for re-election. Former President Barack Obama raised about $40 million in the fourth quarter of 2011, and former President George W. Bush raised $47.5 million in the fourth quarter of 2003, according to Federal Election Commission reports. Mr. Bush's campaign had almost $100 million in available cash at the start of his re-election year, the FEC reports show.
Mr. Trump gave himself an advantage by kicking off his re-election campaign the day he was inaugurated. While recent presidents typically have waited until their third year in office to return to the campaign trail, Mr. Trump immediately arranged to fundraise for re-election and never stopped holding the large political rallies that helped him win office in 2016.
Related
*
Trump's Campaign War Chest Tops $100 Million Heading Into Election Year
(Jan. 2, 2020)
*
Bernie Sanders's Doctors Say He Is Healthy After Heart Attack
(Dec. 30, 2019)
*
2020 Democrats Think Attacking Bernie Sanders Is 'Not Smart Strategy'
(Dec. 14, 2019)
*
Biden's Cash on Hand Is Dwarfed by Rivals' Hoards
(Oct. 16, 2019)
Ken Thomas and Catherine Lucey contributed to this article.
Write to Julie Bykowicz at
julie.bykowicz@wsj.com

title: Buttigieg, Sanders Take Lead as Iowa Results Remain in Flux; Muddled reporting of the first contest brings little clarity to the Democratic presidential race
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
DES MOINES, Iowa—After a day of confusion and recriminations over a
technical mishap that snarled the vote count
, the first wave of delayed results from
Iowa's presidential caucuses
showed Pete Buttigieg and Sen. Bernie Sanders at the top of the Democratic pack.
The early numbers, representing nearly three-quarters of precincts, suggested a possible split verdict that could have one candidate winning the popular vote and another securing the most delegates, the measure state and national party officials have said should determine the victor.
A close finish between Mr. Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Ind., and Mr. Sanders, of Vermont, would also underscore the larger Democratic primary battle between progressives and more-moderate candidates in a field still totaling close to a dozen.
More broadly, the muddled results and fallout from the chaotic count stoked tensions among the candidates and concerns among party officials that the process is doing little to find a strong nominee who can unite the party.
Former Vice President Joe Biden, a longtime front-runner who has built his campaign on the idea that he is that candidate, appeared headed for a
worse-than-expected finish
. He is competing with Mr. Buttigieg and Sen. Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota among the more moderate candidates, and the Iowa results suggest he was beaten by someone in Mr. Buttigieg who was barely known a year ago and who has never governed anything larger than a city of about 100,000 people.

Full Results

The moderate contenders also face a growing challenge from billionaire Michael Bloomberg, who wasn't on the ballot but who has risen in polls after spending several hundred million dollars on advertising. He said on Tuesday that he would
further step up spending and hiring.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, representing the more liberal wing of the party, was below Mr. Buttigieg in the early results but above Mr. Biden.
Ms. Klobuchar, who frequently says on the campaign trail that she has never lost an election since fourth grade, appeared headed for a fifth-place finish in Iowa.
Though the state's population is small and not very diverse, Iowa's caucuses have had a reasonably good record in recent history of picking the eventual winner of the Democratic nomination: Al Gore in 2000, John Kerry in 2004, Barack Obama in 2008 and Hillary Clinton in 2016. The caucuses have been less predictive among Republicans in recent election cycles.
There are indications the Democratic Party is unlikely to resolve its debate over candidates and vision soon. All four of the top candidates heading into the caucuses had campaign war chests large enough to sustain them through February, including the
New Hampshire primary next week.

A self-described democratic socialist, Mr. Sanders has recently shown strength in national polls. That has triggered concerns among centrist Democrats who worry President Trump, a Republican, would use Mr. Sanders's political identity to damage the party's prospects in November.
The release of the results followed a brief news conference Tuesday afternoon with Iowa Democratic Party Chairman Troy Price, who said the nearly- one-day delay for even partial results was unacceptable and happened because of "multiple reporting challenges" as about 1,700 precincts began to feed results into state party headquarters.
Mr. Price declined to say when all of the state's results would be made public. "We're going to take the time we need," he said.
The state party is collecting paper records completed during the precinct meetings. It has attributed the holdup to a software glitch that triggered inconsistencies in data obtained from a mobile app used to report vote tallies.
"We know this data is accurate," Mr. Price said. "We also have a paper trail."
With 71% of precincts reporting, Mr. Buttigieg had the largest share of delegates to the state party convention, while Mr. Sanders had the second most. But Mr. Sanders led in the raw vote so far, followed by Mr. Buttigieg.
Ms. Warren and Mr. Biden were third and fourth, respectively, in both counts.
Mr. Buttigieg, a 38-year-old openly gay man who is the youngest in the race, could see a bump following what appears to be the best showing of any moderate. He has positioned himself as a voice for generational change—most of his top opponents are septuagenarians—who is willing to work across the political aisle.
In New Hampshire, Mr. Buttigieg has also recorded strong support in polls, but he faces a stiffer challenge in the more ethnically diverse states of Nevada and South Carolina this month, as he has so far received virtually no support in polls from black and Latino voters.
The muddled reporting gave all the top candidates room to frame the result as a win. Speaking to reporters Tuesday evening in New Hampshire after the release of some Iowa results, Mr. Buttigieg was asked what it would mean to his candidacy if he ends up finishing in second or third place. "It still amounts to an astonishing victory for our vision," he said.
In a statement, a senior adviser to Mr. Sanders called the early numbers gratifying. "In the partial data released so far, it's clear that in the first and second round more people voted for Bernie than any other candidate in the field," Jeff Weaver said.
Ms. Warren said at her first New Hampshire event on Tuesday, "We know that three of us will be dividing up most of the delegates coming out of Iowa. I'm feeling good."
Capital Journal in Your Inbox
Get the latest scoops, analysis and insights driving Washington from the WSJ's D.C. bureau, with Capital Journal.
Sign up
.
Mr. Biden, during an appearance in Nashua, N.H., expressed optimism after arriving from Iowa. "It's like my mother said, 'Hope springs eternal,'" Mr. Biden said. "We're not giving up."
State party officials in Nevada, where the second caucus of the nominating season will be held, on Feb. 22, pledged that they wouldn't experience the same failures as Iowa.
"We will not be employing the same app or vendor used in the Iowa caucus," Nevada State Democratic Party Chair William McCurdy said in a statement. "We had already developed a series of backups and redundant reporting systems, and are currently evaluating the best path forward."
Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez said the app that misfired in Iowa wouldn't be used in any other state, either.
"What happened last night should never happen again," Mr. Perez said. "We have staff working around the clock to assist the Iowa Democratic Party to ensure that all votes are counted."
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
Do you expect either Elizabeth Warren or Bernie Sanders to have an advantage in the New Hampshire primary? Why or why not? Join the conversation below.
Meanwhile, Mr. Trump pounced on the uncertainty, calling the Democratic caucuses an "unmitigated disaster" in a Tuesday morning tweet, ahead of his State of the Union address that evening.
The reporting was complicated in this year's caucuses by additional data. In response to calls for greater transparency following the close 2016 contest between Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton, the state party was to release for the first time the raw total for votes from both rounds of voting, along with the traditional share of delegates won.
Mr. Sanders has been ahead of his rivals in recent state polls in New Hampshire, but Ms. Warren, Mr. Biden and Mr. Buttigieg have been within striking distance.
New Hampshire Democratic Party Chairman Raymond Buckley said it is "highly unusual to have at this point so many competitive campaigns. Usually we are down to three at the most."
Eliza Collins, Joshua Jamerson, Ken Thomas, Sabrina Siddiqui and Tarini Parti contributed to this article.
